EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with a low pressure system southeast of New Jersey moved into Monmouth County on the 13th. Three day storm totals (from the 11th through the 14th)  in the county averaged between four and eleven inches with the highest amounts near the coast. This led to flooding on area creeks and rivers. The flooding was exacerbated by the strong onshore flow that slowed the water's escape into the ocean. Matters were complicated further when dams failed on both Spring Lake and Mill Pond and Deal Lake overflowed. Nearly twelve hundred people were evacuated and a state of emergency was declared.  The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the flooding during this week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey.  In Asbury Park and Loch Arbour Village, Deal Lake overflowed and forced the evacuation of about 65 homes in Loch Arbour and 30 homes in Asbury Park. Gas service was shut to the homes in Asbury Park. In Eatontown Borough, Eatoncrest Apartments flooded as water was three to four feet deep in areas. In Belmar Borough, flooding occurred along Lake Como and along the Shark River. About 100 people were evacuated near the Shark River. A levee along the river broke. Lake Como flooding also affected Spring Lake Borough. In Monmouth Beach, flooding along the Shrewsbury River affected several blocks.  In Ocean Township, flooding along the Poplar Brook caused the evacaution of the entire 104 unit Poplar Village Senior Citizens Center. After the brook receded, twenty-two units were deemed uninhabitable. Many carpets, furniture and appliances were ruined. In Rumson Borough, flooding along the Shrewsbury River closed roads near the Sea Bright-Rumson Bridge. In Howell Township, seven units of the Friendship Gardens (Senior Citizen) complex were evacuated as the North Branch of the Metedeconk River flooded. Metedeconk River flooding also affected Freehold and Wall Townships. The failure of a dam on Wreck Pond caused the flooding of Spring Lake Borough, Spring Lake Heights Borough, Sea Girt and Wall Township. A mandatory evacuation of Spring Lake Borough was implemented at 11 a.m. EDT on the 14th. About 150 families evacuated. People were trapped between the pond and the ocean. High water vehicles, rowboats and front end loaders carried people on the south end of the borough to safety. Dozens of homes were flooded, mainly along Ocean Road and Union Avenue. The borough sewage treatement plant flooded. Saint Catherine's Grammar School was hit hard with up to two and a half feet of water on its first floor. In Spring Lake Heights Borough Shore Road and Jersey Avenue flooded with cars under water. In Wall Township, the cost of repairing the Wreck Pond Dam was estimated at $4.2 million dollars. The Brighton Avenue Bridge was also damaged. About 11 homes were evacuated, three were classified as uninhabitable. Elsewhere in the township, flooding along Whalepond Brook inundated Branch Road. On the other side of the township, a dam breach on Mill Pond within Allaire State Park caused significant water damage and a roadway collapse in the Historic Village within the park. Only the general purposes building was flooded within the Historic Village.The Manasquan River at Squankum reached its 7.5 foot flood stage at 145 p.m. EDT on the 13th, crested at 9.62 feet at 1115 a.m. EDT on the 14th and was back within bankful at 1053 p.m. EDT on the 14th. Specific storm totals included 11.58 inches in Manasquan and 10.15 inches in Tinton Falls.The old frontal boundary that produced the heavy rain on the 8th stalled in the nearby Atlantic. A series of low pressure systems lifted north along this boundary. Moisture from dissipated tropical depression number 22 was ingested into this system from near Bermuda. A high pressure system over nearby Canada and New England helped block any northward or eastward progression of the frontal boundary and the low pressure systems until the 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: NA
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed over Central New Jersey on the afternoon and evening of the 14th. The antecedent airmass featured tropical moisture. As the thunderstorms moved northward into Western Union County, they produced between 3 and 5 inches of rainfall in a relatively short period of time. A resident of Scotch Plains needed to be rescued from an SUV when the waters rapidly rose. In Fanwood, small streams swiftly overflowed onto property, causing minor damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains occurred in parts of Northeast New Jersey on the 15th. The cause was the interaction between offshore tropical storm Ophelia and a cold front to the west of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding of roads. Water higher than car windows. Rescues performed by the local fire department near Railroad Ave. and Lafayette.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains occurred in parts of Northeast New Jersey on the 15th. The cause was the interaction between offshore tropical storm Ophelia and a cold front to the west of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains caused a creek to rise rapidly in Irvington. The creek subsequently flooded a portion of the Garden State Parkway with 3 to 4 feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with a low pressure system southeast of New Jersey moved into Mercer County during the early morning of the 12th. This led to considerable roadway flooding as well as flooding along the Assunpink Creek and Stony Brook. A 103-year-old man was evacuated from his Princeton home after it was flooded. The Stony Brook overflowed in the township and also forced the closure of four roadways and also flooded the business district. Flooding along the Assunpink Creek forced the closure of Mulberry Street in Trenton. Flooding also closed roads in Hamilton, Lawrence and West Windsor Townships. At least 10 motorists were rescued from flooded vehicles. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the flooding during this week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey.The Assunpink Creek in Trenton was above its 7 foot flood stage from 409 a.m. EDT through 854 p.m. EDT on the 12th. It crested at 9.78 feet at 1130 a.m. EDT. The Stony Brook in Princeton was above its 10 foot flood stage from 837 a.m. EDT through 958 a.m. EDT on the 12th. It crested at 10.32 feet at 845 a.m. EDT. Three day storm totals (from the 11th through the 14th)  in the county averaged between 2.5 and 4.5 inches, although the majority of the heavy rain fell during the morning of the 12th. Specific totals included 4.30 inches in Windsor, 3.80 inches in Trenton and 2.44 inches in Washington's Crossing. The cold frontal boundary that produced the heavy rain on the 8th stalled in the nearby Atlantic Ocean. A series of low pressure systems lifted north along this boundary. Moisture from dissipated tropical depression number 22 was ingested into this system from near Bermuda. A high pressure system over nearby Canada and New England helped block any northward or eastward progression of the frontal boundary and the low pressure systems until the 14th. The heavy rain the past week cemented October 2005 as being the wettest October on record for the state of New Jersey since state records began in 1895.  The preliminary statewide average precipitation total of 11.91 inches was 8.40 inches wetter than normal and would also be the wettest month on record surpassing the August 1955 statewide average of 11.44 inches. October 2005 was also the wettest October on record at Atlantic City International Airport with a precipitation total of 9.04 inches.The October precipitation total in Trenton was 9.92 inches, 7.30 inches wetter than normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with a low pressure system southeast of New Jersey moved into Somerset County during the early morning of the 12th. Three day storm totals (from the 11th through the 14th)  in the county averaged between three and four inches, although the majority of the heavy rain fell during the morning of the 12th. Flooding along River Road (Millstone River) in Montgomery and Hillsborough Townships reached into the basements of about 20 to 30 homes. Several vehicles were stranded on flooded roadways throughout the county. In Montgomery Township, tributaries to the Millstone River inundated roads. The worst road flooding was along River Road, Griggstown Causeway and Kingston Road. Somerset County Routes 601 and 518 were also closed. The Mill Pond Bridge was closed and remained closed because of flood damage. All the closed roads prompted school officials to cancel classes for the 12th in the township. In Branchburg Township, Neshanic Station nearly became an island because of flooding along Pleasant Run and the South Branch of the Raritan River. A few roads near the Millstone River were also closed in Franklin Township. The village of Bound Brook was under a volunitary evacuation order, which was rescinded when flooding along the Raritan River did not reach expected values. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the flooding during this week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey.The Raritan River at Manville was above its 14 foot flood stage from 159 p.m. EDT on the 12th through 314 a.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 16.64 feet at 845 p.m. EDT on the 12th. The Raritan River at Bound Brook was above its 28 foot flood stage from 5 p.m. EDT on the 12th through 630 a.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 30.64 feet at 1145 p.m. EDT on the 12th. The Millstone River at Griggstown was above its 10 foot flood stage from 802 a.m. EDT on the 12th through 4 a.m. EDT on the 16th. It crested at 17.01 feet at 5 p.m. EDT on the 12th. Farther downstream, the Millstone River at Blackwells Mills was above its 9 foot flood stage from 2 p.m. EDT on the 12th through 1034 p.m. EDT on the 14th. It crested at 12.9 feet at 832 p.m. EDT on the 12th. The North Branch of the Raritan River at North Branch was briefly above its 12.3 foot flood stage from 3 p.m. EDT through 414 p.m. EDT on the 12th. It crested at 12.39 feet at 345 p.m. EDT. Farther downstream, the North Branch of the Raritan River at the village of South Branch was above its 7 foot flood stage from 628 a.m. EDT through 1105 p.m. EDT on the 12th. It crested at 9.95 feet at 730 p.m. EDT. Three day storm totals included 4.28 inches in Belle Mead, 3.90 inches in Bound Brook, 3.80 inches in Somerville, 3.64 inches in Middlebush, 3.60 inches in Martinsville and 3.08 inches in North Plainfield. The cold frontal boundary that produced the heavy rain on the 8th stalled in the nearby Atlantic Ocean. A series of low pressure systems lifted north along this boundary. Moisture from dissipated tropical depression number 22 was ingested into this system from near Bermuda. A high pressure system over nearby Canada and New England helped block any northward or eastward progression of the frontal boundary and the low pressure systems until the 14th. The heavy rain the past week cemented October 2005 as being the wettest October on record for the state of New Jersey since state records began in 1895.  The preliminary statewide average precipitation total of 11.91 inches was 8.40 inches wetter than normal and would also be the wettest month on record surpassing the August 1955 statewide average of 11.44 inches. October 2005 was also the wettest October on record at Atlantic City International Airport with a precipitation total of 9.04 inches.The October precipitation total in Trenton was 9.92 inches, 7.30 inches wetter than normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with a low pressure system southeast of New Jersey moved into Hunterdon County during the early morning of the 12th. Three day storm totals (from the 11th through the 14th) in the county averaged between two and four inches, although the majority of the heavy rain fell during the morning of the 12th. Minor flooding and sporadic road closures were reported in East Amwell Township, Clinton Township, Flemington Borough, Franklin Township, Raritan Borough, Readington Township, Tewksbury Township, Union Township and West Amwell Township. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the flooding during this week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey.The South Branch of the Raritan River at Stanton was above its 8 foot flood stage from 632 a.m. EDT through 1012 a.m. EDT on the 12th. It crested at 8.48 feet at 815 a.m. EDT.  Actual three day storm totals included 3.95 inches in Wertsville, 3.72 inches in Flemington, 3.60 inches in Clinton, 3.04 inches in Readington and 2.08 inches in Stockton.The old frontal boundary that produced the heavy rain on the 8th stalled in the nearby Atlantic. A series of low pressure systems lifted north along this boundary. Moisture from dissipated tropical depression number 22 was ingested into this system from near Bermuda. A high pressure system over nearby Canada and New England helped block any northward or eastward progression of the frontal boundary and the low pressure systems until the 14th. The preliminary statewide average precipitation total of 11.91 inches was 8.40 inches wetter than normal and would also be the wettest month on record surpassing the August 1955 statewide average of 11.44 inches. October 2005 was also the wettest October on record at Atlantic City International Airport with a precipitation total of 9.04 inches.The October precipitation total in Trenton was 9.92 inches, 7.30 inches wetter than normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with a low pressure system southeast of New Jersey moved into Morris County during the early morning of the 12th. Three day storm totals (from the 11th through the 14th)  in the county averaged between two and five inches with the highest amounts in the eastern part of the county. The majority of the heavy rain fell during the morning of the 12th. The heavy rain caused small stream flooding during the morning of the 12th and then spread into the Passaic Basin where flooding lasted for a week. The worst effects were in the borough of Lincoln Park where flooding from both the Passaic and Pompton Rivers forced the evacuation of about 150 residents in the borough's Midwood section, many by boat. More than 30 roads were closed in the borough, some had up to four feet of water on them. One school bus became stuck in the flood waters. There were no injuries. In nearby Pequannock Borough, U.S. Route 202 was closed because of flooding. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the flooding during this week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey.The Passaic River at Chatham was above its 6 foot flood stage from 9 a.m. EDT on the 12th through 315 p.m. EDT on the 16th. It crested at 6.66 feet at 1145 a.m. EDT on the 12th. Farther downstream at Pine Brook, the Passaic River was above its 19 foot flood stage from 1145 a.m. EDT on the 12th through 745 a.m. EDT on the 19th. It crested at 20.62 feet at 830 a.m. EDT on the 15th. Farther downstream at Two Bridges, the Passaic River was above its 9 foot flood stage from 622 p.m. EDT on the 12th through 545 p.m. EDT on the 18th. It crested at 12.18 feet at 1030 p.m. EDT on the 14th. Three day storm totals included 5.68 inches in Chatham, 4.40 inches in Boonton, 2.79 inhce in Lake Hopatcong, 2.60 inches in Morristown nd 2.32 inches in West Wharton.  The cold frontal boundary that produced the heavy rain on the 8th stalled in the nearby Atlantic Ocean. A series of low pressure systems lifted north along this boundary. Moisture from dissipated tropical depression number 22 was ingested into this system from near Bermuda. A high pressure system over nearby Canada and New England helped block any northward or eastward progression of the frontal boundary and the low pressure systems until the 14th. The heavy rain the past week cemented October 2005 as being the wettest October on record for the state of New Jersey since state records began in 1895.  The preliminary statewide average precipitation total of 11.91 inches was 8.40 inches wetter than normal and would also be the wettest month on record surpassing the August 1955 statewide average of 11.44 inches. October 2005 was also the wettest October on record at Atlantic City International Airport with a precipitation total of 9.04 inches.The October precipitation total in Trenton was 9.92 inches, 7.30 inches wetter than normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a very slow moving cold front and copious moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Tammy produced periods of very heavy rain across Sussex County from the evening of the 7th into the evening of the 8th. Storm totals averaged from seven to ten inches. The heavy rain caused widespread poor drainage flooding as well as flooding along the creeks in the county. U.S. Route 206 in Newton was closed from the afternoon of the 8th into the 9th. Sussex County Route 618 was flooded in Fredon Township. Other roads were closed in Fredon and Newton as well as in Vernon, Hampton and Andover. The Flat Brook at Flatbrookville was above its 6 foot flood stage from 1224 a.m. EDT through 357 p.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 7.37 feet at 515 a.m. EDT on the 9th. Storm totals included 9.84 inches in Andover, 9.31 inches in Sussex, 8.63 inches in Hamburg and 8.62 inches at Wantage. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the subsequent flooding during the upcoming week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey. The cold front moved from near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania at 8 p.m. EDT on the 7th, to the Susquehanna Valley in Pennsylvania at 2 a.m. EDT on the 8th, to the Poconos and Berks County in Pennsylvania and just west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland at 8 a.m. EDT on the 8th. The cold front stalled as waves of low pressure road northeast along it. At 2 p.m. EDT on the 8th, the cold front just edged into northwestern New Jersey and the Philadelphia northwest suburbs and was still west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland. At 8 p.m. EDT that evening the cold front barely moved into the Philadelphia New Jersey suburbs and the Delmarva Peninsula. The cold front and waves of low pressure cleared the Delaware and New Jersey coasts between Midnight EDT and 2 a.m. EDT on the 9th. The slow movement and stalling coupled with an unstable air mass and tropical moisture associated with Tammy helped enhance the torrential downpours. The flooding would have been even worse if not for the unseasonably dry weather that preceded this event from the middle of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a very slow moving cold front and copious moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Tammy produced periods of very heavy rain across Warren County from the evening of the 7th into the evening of the 8th. Storm totals averaged from seven to ten inches. The heavy rain caused widespread poor drainage flooding as well as flooding along the creeks in the county. The greatest roadway flooding was reported in Blairstown. In spite of the heavy rain, the Delaware River did not flood. While the Delaware River did not flood, the large within bank rise of the river disturbed coal ash deposits at the bottom of the river and caused arsenic levels to rise above acceptable levels for two days. Both the Pohatcong and Lopatcong Creeks flooded within the county. In Phillipsburg, in addition to the Pohatcong Creek flooding, a retaining wall collapsed. The heavy rain contributed to the death of a two-year-old boy during a traffic accident on Interstate 80 in Knowlton. Storm totals included 10.30 inches in Columbia, 10.04 inches in Mountain Lake, 9.79 inches in Blairstown and 8.11 inches in Stewartsville. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the subsequent flooding during the upcoming week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey. The cold front moved from near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania at 8 p.m. EDT on the 7th, to the Susquehanna Valley in Pennsylvania at 2 a.m. EDT on the 8th, to the Poconos and Berks County in Pennsylvania and just west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland at 8 a.m. EDT on the 8th. The cold front stalled as waves of low pressure road northeast along it. At 2 p.m. EDT on the 8th, the cold front just edged into northwestern New Jersey and the Philadelphia northwest suburbs and was still west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland. At 8 p.m. EDT that evening the cold front barely moved into the Philadelphia New Jersey suburbs and the Delmarva Peninsula. The cold front and waves of low pressure cleared the Delaware and New Jersey coasts between Midnight EDT and 2 a.m. EDT on the 9th. The slow movement and stalling coupled with an unstable air mass and tropical moisture associated with Tammy helped enhance the torrential downpours. The flooding would have been even worse if not for the unseasonably dry weather that preceded this event from the middle of August.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a very slow moving cold front and copious moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Tammy produced periods of very heavy rain across Mercer County during the morning and evening of the 8th. The last period of very heavy rain caused creeks in the county to flood. Storm totals averaged four to seven inches. The heavy rain caused widespread urban and poor drainage flooding in addition to the creek flooding. Roads were closed in Princeton, West Windsor, Trenton, Hamilton and Ewing. Along the Assunpink Creek, in Trenton, flooding reached into Mulberry Street and Nottingham Way. One business was flooded, but flood waters did not reach any homes. In Ewing, flooding along the Assunpink put both Sullivan Way and Western Avenue under water. The Assunpink Creek in Trenton was above its 7 foot flood stage from 743 p.m. EDT on the 8th through 845 a.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 9.88 feet at 330 a.m. EDT on the 9th. Storm totals included 6.80 inches in Princeton, 5.27 inches in Hamilton, 5.00 inches in Trenton, 4.40 inches in Windsor, 4.25 inches in Hightstown and 4.11 inches in Washington's Crossing. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the subsequent flooding during the upcoming week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey. The cold front moved from near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania at 8 p.m. EDT on the 7th, to the Susquehanna Valley in Pennsylvania at 2 a.m. EDT on the 8th, to the Poconos and Berks County in Pennsylvania and just west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland at 8 a.m. EDT on the 8th. The cold front stalled as waves of low pressure road northeast along it. At 2 p.m. EDT on the 8th, the cold front just edged into northwestern New Jersey and the Philadelphia northwest suburbs and was still west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland. At 8 p.m. EDT that evening the cold front barely moved into the Philadelphia New Jersey suburbs and the Delmarva Peninsula. The cold front and waves of low pressure cleared the Delaware and New Jersey coasts between Midnight EDT and 2 a.m. EDT on the 9th. The slow movement and stalling coupled with an unstable air mass and tropical moisture associated with Tammy helped enhance the torrential downpours. The flooding would have been even worse if not for the unseasonably dry weather that preceded this event from the middle of August. In spite of rainfall totals of up to around ten inches upstream, the Delaware River did not flood.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a very slow moving cold front and copious moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Tammy produced periods of very heavy rain across Morris County during the morning and evening of the 8th. The evening period of very heavy rain caused many of the smaller creeks and brooks to flood in the county. Flooding later spread to the Pompton and Passaic Rivers. Storm totals averaged seven to ten inches. The heavy rain also caused widespread poor drainage flooding. In Lincoln Park, homes along Beaver Brook Road were evacuated. East Hanover Township, Morris Plains Borough, Morris Township, Denville Township, Montville Township and Hanover Township had many roads closed due to flooding including New Jersey State Route 53 in Morris Plains and Denville. Flooding along the Whippany Creek inundated four roads with up to three feet of water. Basements were flooded in Montville. The Den Brook in Denville and the Watnong Brook in Morris Township also flooded.  The Passaic River at Chatham was above its 6 foot flood stage from 919 p.m. EDT on the 8th through 311 a.m. EDT on the 9th and again from 930 p.m. EDT on the 10th through 3 a.m. EDT on the 11th. It crested at 6.5 feet at Midnight EDT on the 9th. Farther downstream, the Passaic River at Pine Brook was above its 19 foot flood stage from 215 a.m. EDT on the 10th through 1030 a.m. EDT on the 11th. It crested at 19.07 feet at 315 p.m. EDT on the 10th. The Pompton River at Pompton Plains was above its 16 foot flood stage from 121 a.m. EDT through 827 p.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 17.89 feet at 1130 a.m. EDT. The Whippany Creek in Morristown was above its 6 foot flood stage from 701 p.m. EDT on the 8th through 939 a.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 6.71 feet at 1130 p.m. EDT on the 8th.Storm totals included 9.80 inches in Morris Plains, 9.75 inches in Butler, 9.48 inches in Ironia, 8.60 inches in Jefferson Township, 8.42 inches in Boonton, 8.03 inches in Chatham and 7.24 inches in Morristown. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the subsequent flooding during the upcoming week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey. The cold front moved from near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania at 8 p.m. EDT on the 7th, to the Susquehanna Valley in Pennsylvania at 2 a.m. EDT on the 8th, to the Poconos and Berks County in Pennsylvania and just west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland at 8 a.m. EDT on the 8th. The cold front stalled as waves of low pressure road northeast along it. At 2 p.m. EDT on the 8th, the cold front just edged into northwestern New Jersey and the Philadelphia northwest suburbs and was still west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland. At 8 p.m. EDT that evening the cold front barely moved into the Philadelphia New Jersey suburbs and the Delmarva Peninsula. The cold front and waves of low pressure cleared the Delaware and New Jersey coasts between Midnight EDT and 2 a.m. EDT on the 9th. The slow movement and stalling coupled with an unstable air mass and tropical moisture associated with Tammy helped enhance the torrential downpours. The flooding would have been even worse if not for the unseasonably dry weather that preceded this event from the middle of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with a low pressure system southeast of New Jersey moved into Warren County during the early morning of the 12th. This led to the partial washout of New Jersey State Route 57 in Hackettstown. Three day storm totals (from the 11th through the 14th)  in the county averaged between two and five inches, although the majority of the heavy rain fell during the morning of the 12th. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the flooding during this week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey. Specific storm totals included 4.67 inches in Belvidere, 2.80 inches in Columbia and 1.93 inches in Phillipsburg. The old frontal boundary that produced the heavy rain on the 8th stalled in the nearby Atlantic. A series of low pressure systems lifted north along this boundary. Moisture from dissipated tropical depression number 22 was ingested into this system from near Bermuda. A high pressure system over nearby Canada and New England helped block any northward or eastward progression of the frontal boundary and the low pressure systems until the 14th. The heavy rain the past week cemented October 2005 as being the wettest October and month on record for the state of New Jersey since state records began in 1895. The preliminary statewide average precipitation total of 11.91 inches was 8.40 inches wetter than normal and would also be the wettest month on record surpassing the August 1955 statewide average of 11.44 inches. October 2005 was also the wettest October on record at Atlantic City International Airport with a precipitation total of 9.04 inches.The October precipitation total in Trenton was 9.92 inches, 7.30 inches wetter than normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a very slow moving cold front and copious moisture from the remnants of Tropical Storm Tammy produced periods of very heavy rain across Somerset County during the morning and evening of the 8th. The evening period of very heavy rain caused many of the smaller creeks and brooks to flood in the county. Flooding later spread into the Raritan and Millstone Basins. Storm totals averaged five to nine inches. In Hillsborough Township, an apartment building was evacuated after its basement was flooded with seven feet of water. In Montgomery Township, firefighters rescued six people from three flooded roadways during the evening of the 8th including a family of four whose vehicle was surrounded by the flooding Bedens Brook. A bridge over the Raritan River between Branchburg and Bridgewater Townships was closed. The North Branch of the Raritan River at North Branch was above its 12.3 flood stage from 1253 a.m. EDT through 904 a.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 14.02 feet at 5 a.m. EDT. Farther downstream, the North Branch of the Raritan River at Raritan was above its 10 foot flood stage from 240 a.m. through 950 a.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 10.9 feet at 615 a.m. EDT. Farther downstream at the village of South Branch, the North Branch of the Raritan River was above its 7 foot flood stage from 1057 p.m. EDT on the 8th through 151 p.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 9.99 feet at 1045 a.m. EDT on the 10th. Along the main stem of the Raritan River at Manville, the river was above its 14 foot flood stage from 811 a.m.EDT through 458 p.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 15.44 feet at 1 p.m. EDT. Farther downstream at Bound Brook, the Raritan River was above its 28 foot flood stage from 9 a.m. EDT through 608 p.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 29.20 feet at 230 p.m. EDT. The Millstone River at Griggstown was above its 10 foot flood stage from 10 p.m. EDT on the 8th through 4 p.m. EDT on the 10th. It crested at 15.13 feet at 530 a.m. EDT on the 9th. Farther downstream at Blackwells Mills, the Millstone River was above its 9 foot flood stage from 457 a.m. EDT on the 9th through 155 a.m. EDT on the 10th. It crested at 11.05 feet at 1033 a.m. EDT on the 10th. Just before its confluence with the Raritan River, at Weston, the Millstone River was above its 12.4 foot flood stage from 1229 p.m. EDT through 4 p.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 12.5 feet at 1 p.m. EDT. The Green Brook at Plainfield (Union County) was above its 8 foot flood stage from 115 a.m. EDT through 749 a.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 9.12 feet at 545 a.m. EDT. Pike Run in Belle Mead was above its 7 foot flood stage from 913 p.m. EDT on the 8th through 341 a.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 9.83 feet at Midnight EDT on the 9th. Peters Brook in Somerville was above its 8.2 foot flood stage from 1025 p.m. EDT on the 8th through 1235 a.m. EDT on the 9th. It crested at 9.2 feet at Midnight EDT on the 9th.  Storm totals included 8.87 inches in Pottersville, 7.80 inches in Branchburg, 7.52 inches in Martinsville, 7.08 inches in Hillsborough, 6.94 inches in Somerville, 6.91 inches in Far Hills, 6.88 inches in Belle Mead and 6.00 inches in North Plainfield. The flooding on the 8th and 9th and the subsequent flooding during the upcoming week damaged over 2,700 single family homes, over 640 apartment units and 220 businesses throughout the state of New Jersey. The cold front moved from near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania at 8 p.m. EDT on the 7th, to the Susquehanna Valley in Pennsylvania at 2 a.m. EDT on the 8th, to the Poconos and Berks County in Pennsylvania and just west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland at 8 a.m. EDT on the 8th. The cold front stalled as waves of low pressure road northeast along it. At 2 p.m. EDT on the 8th, the cold front just edged into northwestern New Jersey and the Philadelphia northwest suburbs and was still west of Chesapeake Bay in Maryland. At 8 p.m. EDT that evening the cold front barely moved into the Philadelphia New Jersey suburbs and the Delmarva Peninsula. The cold front and waves of low pressure cleared the Delaware and New Jersey coasts between Midnight EDT and 2 a.m. EDT on the 9th. The slow movement and stalling coupled with an unstable air mass and tropical moisture associated with Tammy helped enhance the torrential downpours. The flooding would have been even worse if not for the unseasonably dry weather that preceded this event from the middle of August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced high winds that downed trees and wires in Jersey City.Thunderstorms produced torrential rain that caused flash flooding of low lying and poor drainage areas.  Rainfall rates up to 2 inches per hour caused flash flooding of streets that forced road closures.  In Elizabeth, 2.75 inches of rain caused significant street flooding. Spotters in Westfield and Linden also reported significant flash flooding, where water ponded up to at least 3 feet deep.  A spotter at Westfield measured 3.1 inches of rain.

A Skywarn Spotter reported that 1.40 inches of rain fell in 40 minutes in Metuchen.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 1 to 3 inches across the northern part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms that circulated around a circulation aloft caused torrential downpours across eastern sections of Ocean County and caused widespread flash flooding of smaller streams and roadways. Hardest hit locations included Stafford and Berkeley Townships on the mainland and Lavallette, Seaside Heights, Seaside Park and the Ortley Beach section of Dover Township on the barrier islands. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 8 to 10 inches in Berkeley Township and 6 to 8 inches in Stafford Township. Major roadways were flooded including U.S. Route 9, New Jersey State Routes 37 and 72 and Ocean County Route 537. Exit 77 off of the Garden State Parkway was also closed in Berkeley Township because of flooding along the exit roadways. Two roads were closed pending inspection because the flooding undermined them. Over 100 people were rescued from stranded vehicles (some were nearly totally submerged) including a one-month-old boy in Stafford Township. Many homes and basements were also flooded.  Even a hospital was affected.In Berkeley Township, flooding entered the hallways of the Central Regional High School.  In Stafford Township, flood waters reached into the emergency room and and basement of Southern Ocean County Hospital. Homes on Leeward Drive and Neptune Drive were flooded. Residents from six homes on Neptune Drive were evacuated by canoe. Students at the South Regional High School were moved into the gymnasium and auditorium because flood waters seeped into the building. All after school activities and sporting events were cancelled. On the barrier islands, during the height of the heavy rain, it was impossible to get on and off of Long Beach Island. Long Beach and Ocean Boulevards were flooded. In Seaside Heights, Hiering Avenue was flooded and apartments below street level were flooded. Actual storm totals included 8.82 inches in Bayville (Berkeley Township), 6.30 inches in Lacey Township and 5.96 inches in Chatsworth (Burlington County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flooding in Ocean City and the north end of Sea Isle City. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 6 to 8 inches, most of which fell within three hours. In Ocean City, over 100 vehicles were damaged by the flood waters. The worst flooding was reported on the south end of Ocean City and the north end of Sea Isle City. Many yards and lawns were flooded and flooding reached the steps of homes. Actual storm totals included 5.56 inches in Strathmere and 3.52 inches in Seaville.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours produced a Doppler Radar estimated 6 to 8 inches of rain within a three hour period in central Cumberland County. This caused flooding of roadways, fields, streams and basements in Bridgeton City and Fairfield Township. The rain and flooding flattened pepper and eggplant plants on some farms. Storm totals included 4.70 inches and 4.15 inches in Vineland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours dropped between 4 and 5 inches across northwestern Camden County and caused flash flooding in the northwest part of the county particularly in Camden, Pennsauken and Collingswood. Flooding also occurred along the Cooper River. Major roadways including Admiral Wilson Boulevard, U.S.Routes 30 and 130, New Jersey State Routes 38 and 70 were flooded as far southeast as Cherry Hill Township. Vehicles were stuck in flood waters along Admiral Wilson Boulevard and on roadways in Woodlynne Borough. In the city of Camden, about 10 to 12 families were evacuated, some by raft in and around the Westfield Garden Apartments. Basements of apartments were totally flooded. In Collingswood Borough, sixteen homes on Cattell Avenue near the often flooded Collingswood Circle sustained water damage in their basements. Roads and homes west of U.S. Route 130 in Pennsauken Township were hit the hardest by the flooding. The foundation of one home in the township collapsed. The South Branch of the Pennsauken Creek flooded homes on King George Road in Cherry Hill Township. The Cooper River flooded parkland in Collingswood, Haddon Township and Haddonfield. The Cooper River at Haddonfield was above its 2.8 foot flood stage from 514 a.m. EDT through 1222 p.m. EDT on the 28th. It crested at 3.17 feet at 915 a.m. EDT. Actual storm totals included 4.10 inches in Pennsauken and 3.68 inches in Camden.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms that moved across the same region (called training) just after Midnight EDT on the 27th caused flash flooding of streams and poor drainage flooding in Somerset and Hunterdon Counties. The run-off from those thunderstorms and other thunderstorms later that morning caused flooding along some of the slower responding and/or larger streams and rivers in Mercer, Hunterdon, Somerset and Middlesex Counties. Doppler radar storm total estimates averaged between 1 and 4 inches across the four county area with the highest amounts in Hunterdon and Somerset Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms with heavy rain entered Hunterdon County around Midnight EDT on the 27th and continued until around 3 a.m. EDT. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches in a narrow band from Delaware Township northeast through Raritan and East Amwell Townships. This caused roadway and flash flooding of streams within that band and hit Delaware Township the hardest. About 14 roads in the township were flooded and closed including New Jersey State Route 29. Debris left behind by the flood waters had to be cleared from roadways and schools were closed for the day. Storm totals included 3.40 inches in Ringoes, 2.51 inches in Wertsville and 1.97 inches in Flemington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a lee side trough and an approaching cold front helped trigger strong thunderstorms during the late afternoon of the 28th. This led to the flooding of a few streams across north central Sussex County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached three inches in Wantage, Frankford and Vernon Townships.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NA

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry caused flash flooding in parts of Northeast New Jersey.  Rainfall amounts ranged from just under 3.25 inches in Rivervale, Bergen County to just over an inch at Hawthorne, Passaic County, with most locations across Northeast New Jersey receiving between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rainfall. Wind gusts if 30-40 mph produced sporadic instances of minor tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ridge Road flooded due to flash flooding between Linden Street and Mark Twain Way.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from the remnants of Tropical Storm Barry caused flash flooding in parts of Northeast New Jersey.  Rainfall amounts ranged from just under 3.25 inches in Rivervale, Bergen County to just over an inch at Hawthorne, Passaic County, with most locations across Northeast New Jersey receiving between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rainfall. Wind gusts if 30-40 mph produced sporadic instances of minor tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: New Jersey Turnpike (Eastern Spur) Interchange 15E on-ramp closed due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms downed trees in Passaic and Bergen Counties, and Flash Flooding in Essex County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars trapped in water at Belleville Avenue and Ogdon St.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy showers and thunderstorms produced isolated flash flooding in portions of Bergen and Hudson Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant road flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved northeast from the Mid Atlantic States across Northeast New Jersey and Eastern Connecticut on the 27th.  Two bands of heavy rain occurred:  one extended northeast across Hunterdon and Passaic Counties; the other extended from Somerset northeast across Eastern Essex and Eastern Bergen Counties.  Storm total rainfall amounts in these bands ranged from 2 to 4 inches, which resulted in flash flooding across parts of the region.|Storm total rainfall amounts for:|Bergen County - ranged from 2.01 inches at Cliffside Park to 3.26 inches at Teterboro Airport.|Essex County - ranged from 2.36 inches at Newark Airport to 2.40 inches at West Orange.|Hudson County - ranged from 1.46 inches at Jersey City to 2.88 inches at Harrison.|Passaic County - 2.12 inches was measured in West Patterson.|Union County - 2.97 inches was measured in Elizabeth.|A NWS Cooperative Observer reported flash flooding of Route 46 in Lodi, where lanes in both directions were closed, at 4:15 am.|Amateur radio operators reported flash flooding of I-280 in Newark at 5:00 am.|The broadcast media reported flash flooding along portions of:|Route 46 in Wayne, where 2 lanes were closed and Highway 508 in Kearny at 6:00 am.|Route 17 in Rutherford at 9:10 am.|I-280 in Kearny at 9:11 am and in Newark at 9:24 am.|I-78 west bound at Exit 43 (Diamond Hill Road) in Berkeley Heights at 10:14 am.|Route 139 lower level west bound before Tonnelle Avenue in Jersey City at 10:18 am.|Highway 21 south bound at River Drive in Passaic at 10:50 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms that moved across the same region (called training) just after Midnight EDT on the 27th caused flash flooding of streams and poor drainage flooding in Somerset and Hunterdon Counties. The run-off from those thunderstorms and other thunderstorms later that morning caused flooding along some of the slower responding and/or larger streams and rivers in Mercer, Hunterdon, Somerset and Middlesex Counties. Doppler radar storm total estimates averaged between 1 and 4 inches across the four county area with the highest amounts in Hunterdon and Somerset Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms with heavy rain entered Somerset County between Midnight and 1 a.m. EDT on the 27th and continued until between 3 a.m. and 4 a.m. EDT. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches in a band from Hillsborough and Branchburg Townships northeast through Somerville, Manville, Bridgewater, Bound Brook, Warren, Green Brook, North Plainfield and Watchung. This caused flash flooding of smaller streams in the early morning of the 27th and led to minor flooding along some of the larger rivers in the county later that day. In Hillsborough Township, a woman was rescued from the Raritan River after she drove around barricades and became caught in a flooded section of Somerset County Route 625 just before the John Basilone Veterans Memorial Bridge leading into Raritan Borough. During the early morning both U.S. Routes 206 and 202 were closed in Raritan Borough. There were a few voluntary evacuations in Green Brook. Two roads were closed.  U.S. Route 22 was among four roads closed in North Plainfield. One home was evacuated on Princeton Lane. In Bound Brook, the worst flooding was reported on Piedmont road, Windsor and Chestnut Streets and Linden Avenue. On the latter road, up to three feet of water was reported in basements. There were road closures also in Hillsborough and Franklin Townships. Six roads were closed in Hillsborough Township and schools had a two hour delayed opening. Northbound Interstate 287 north of milepost 16 near the South Bound Brook and Franklin Township border was closed to passenger vehicles during the early morning. Tractor-trailers were permitted to go through. |The Pike Run at Belle Mead was above its 7 foot flood stage from 717 a.m. through 815 a.m. EDT on the 27th. It crested at 7.21 feet at 745 a.m. EDT. The Green Brook at Plainfield (Union County) was above its 8 foot flood stage from 414 a.m. EDT through 815 a.m. EDT on the 27th. It crested at 9.75 feet at 6 a.m. EDT. The Stony Brook at North Plainfield was above its 7 foot flood stage from 338 a.m. EDT through 427 a.m. EDT on the 27th. It crested at 7.5 feet at 4 a.m. EDT. Farther downstream, the Stony Brook at Watchung was above its 14.5 foot flood stage from 314 a.m. through 451 a.m. EDT on the 27th. It crested at 15.9 feet at 4 a.m. EDT. The North Branch of the Raritan River at South Branch was above its 7 foot flood stage from 5 a.m. EDT through 716 p.m. EDT on the 27th. It crested at 9.64 feet at 1230 p.m. EDT.|Storm totals included 3.30 inches in Bound Brook, 2.73 inches in Watchung, 2.19 inches in Somerville, 2.03 inches in Basking Ridge and 1.94 inches in Hillsborough.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure riding along a warm front produced thunderstorms with heavy rain causing flooding in New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rahway River at Springfield exceeded its flood stage at 9:15am EDT and fell below flood stage at 1:30pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, spawned thunderstorms that produced heavy rainfall and caused flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous flooded roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, spawned thunderstorms that produced heavy rainfall and caused flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding closed portions of Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, spawned thunderstorms that produced heavy rainfall and caused flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flooding of Stegman Parkway near Westside Avenue, multiple cars abandoned.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, spawned thunderstorms that produced heavy rainfall and caused flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding was reported on Jefferson Street about 1 mile north of Hoboken at 6:22 am.  One water rescue occurred in Hoboken at 6:30 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure was located in southeastern Canada during the early morning hours of August 8th. A cold front associated with this area of low pressure was moving across the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley regions during the morning. Well out ahead of this cold front was a surface trough which moved through the Mid Atlantic region during the very early morning hours on August 8th. A very warm and humid air mass was in place, and with some upper-level energy, a round of showers and thunderstorms moved through parts of northern New Jersey. Some of the thunderstorms produced torrential downpours and caused poor drainage and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms which also produced torrential downpours caused flash flooding in Morristown in and near the Whippany Creek. Seven vehicles (two completely submerged) and basements sustained flood damage. Basements on Cobb Place were flooded. Three roadways within the town were closed. The heavy rain also helped a tree on Olyphant Drive topple onto two vehicles.||The Whippany Creek at Moorestown was above its 6 foot flood stage from 513 a.m. EDT through 603 a.m. EDT on the 8th. It crested at 6.35 feet at 530 a.m. EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure was located in southeastern Canada during the early morning hours of August 8th. A cold front associated with this area of low pressure was moving across the Great Lakes and Ohio Valley regions during the morning. Well out ahead of this cold front was a surface trough which moved through the Mid Atlantic region during the very early morning hours on August 8th. A very warm and humid air mass was in place, and with some upper-level energy, a round of showers and thunderstorms moved through parts of northern New Jersey. Some of the thunderstorms produced torrential downpours and caused poor drainage and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours produced flash flooding in Washington Township and Washington Borough. A road (County Route 640) was washed out near Cemetery Hill Road in Washington Township. In Washington Borough up to six feet of water accumulated in basments. Two feet of water amassed on parts of New Jersey State Routes 57 and 31. Businesses had up to two feet of water. A small creek flood helped collapse a swimming pool, knocked over a shed and toppled one man to the ground. Craters formed near Memorial Elementary School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure riding along a warm front produced thunderstorms with heavy rain causing flooding in New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: New Street and Oak Street closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front, spawned thunderstorms that produced heavy rainfall and caused flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread significant flash flooding resulted in many road closures.|Just south of Ridgewood, the Franklin Avenue underpass at Wolsey Square was closed at 6:05 am.  At 6:06 am, the Maple Avenue underpass was closed near Glen Rock.  Just south of Westwood, the 2 right lanes along Route 17 north were closed at 6:15 am.  At Bergenfield, Route 208 south at Virginia Avenue was closed at 6:20 am.  Flash flooding continued through 7:30 am at many locations throughout Bergen County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy showers and thunderstorms produced isolated flash flooding in portions of Bergen and Hudson Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant road flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomolous slow moving upper level low pressure system in combination with a weak surface cold front and local seabreezes triggered thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall which led to flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Maywood Ave. and Essex St. in Maywood was impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomolous slow moving upper level low pressure system in combination with a weak surface cold front and local seabreezes triggered thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall which led to flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bergen County Office of Emergency Management reported multiple road closures in Cresskill and Tenafly due to flooding.  A sinkhole was also reported in Bergenfield due to the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from the Ohio Valley to Northern New England from February 1 to February 2, 2008. A strong arctic high pressure system preceded this low with a prolonged period of subfreezing ground temperatures which allowed for increased runoff causing flash flooding across parts of the local area. Rainfall totals across NE New Jersey ranged from 1 to 2 inches.  There were a few isolated reports over 2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A motorist was rescued from his car in Hawthorne at the intersection of North 8th St. and Goffle Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from the heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as basement and poor drainage flooding across much of central and northwest New Jersey during the afternoon of the 8th. The region was primed for flooding by another heavy rain event that occurred on the 5th. The runoff from the heavy rain caused flooding to continue through the 10th in the Raritan Basin and through the 13th in the Passaic Basin. Rain began falling during the afternoon on the 7th and did not end until the early evening on the 8th. It fell at its heaviest between 10 a.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST on the 8th. Storm totals ranged from one to four inches with the highest amounts in Morris County.||Please note, some of the flooding persisted through the crossover between eastern standard and eastern daylight time on the night of March 8th.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. At 1 p.m. EST on the 8th, there were a pair of 992 millibar lows, one near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and the other in northern Virginia. At 4 p.m. EST on the 8th, they combined into one over southeast Pennsylvania and deepened to 987 millibars. At 7 p.m. EST the low had deepened to 985 millibars and was near New York City. Its associated cold front had cleared Delaware and New Jersey and ended the rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The runoff from the heavy rain as well as the slowing of the runoff caused by the incoming high tide caused flooding across northwestern Camden County. Roadway flooding included the Admiral Wilson Boulevard and U.S. Route 130. Minor tidal flooding occurred along the Delaware River and tidal sections of its tributaries between 2 p.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.44 feet above mean lower low water and minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water. Storm totals included 1.60 inches in Pennsauken and 1.53 inches in Somerdale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from the heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as basement and poor drainage flooding across much of central and northwest New Jersey during the afternoon of the 8th. The region was primed for flooding by another heavy rain event that occurred on the 5th. The runoff from the heavy rain caused flooding to continue through the 10th in the Raritan Basin and through the 13th in the Passaic Basin. Rain began falling during the afternoon on the 7th and did not end until the early evening on the 8th. It fell at its heaviest between 10 a.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST on the 8th. Storm totals ranged from one to four inches with the highest amounts in Morris County.||Please note, some of the flooding persisted through the crossover between eastern standard and eastern daylight time on the night of March 8th.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. At 1 p.m. EST on the 8th, there were a pair of 992 millibar lows, one near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and the other in northern Virginia. At 4 p.m. EST on the 8th, they combined into one over southeast Pennsylvania and deepened to 987 millibars. At 7 p.m. EST the low had deepened to 985 millibars and was near New York City. Its associated cold front had cleared Delaware and New Jersey and ended the rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding as well as flooding along most of the gaged creeks and main stem rivers in Somerset County. The first gaged river to flood was the North Branch of the Raritan River at the village of South Branch. Please refer to the separate flood section on Somerset County for specific details about individual streams and rivers. Event precipitation totals included 2.30 inches in Bound Brook, 2.22 inches in Somerville and 1.94 inches in Hillsborough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from the heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as basement and poor drainage flooding across much of central and northwest New Jersey during the afternoon of the 8th. The region was primed for flooding by another heavy rain event that occurred on the 5th. The runoff from the heavy rain caused flooding to continue through the 10th in the Raritan Basin and through the 13th in the Passaic Basin. Rain began falling during the afternoon on the 7th and did not end until the early evening on the 8th. It fell at its heaviest between 10 a.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST on the 8th. Storm totals ranged from one to four inches with the highest amounts in Morris County.||Please note, some of the flooding persisted through the crossover between eastern standard and eastern daylight time on the night of March 8th.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. At 1 p.m. EST on the 8th, there were a pair of 992 millibar lows, one near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and the other in northern Virginia. At 4 p.m. EST on the 8th, they combined into one over southeast Pennsylvania and deepened to 987 millibars. At 7 p.m. EST the low had deepened to 985 millibars and was near New York City. Its associated cold front had cleared Delaware and New Jersey and ended the rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding in Morris County. The runoff also caused flooding along some of the larger rivers in the county including the Rockaway and Passaic which lasted for days. In Jefferson Township, flooding was reported along New Jersey State Route 15. An overflowing retention basin flooded a house in the township. In Mount Olive Township, three roads were closed including River Road. In Chester, Tanner Brook Road was closed. Four roads were closed in Lincoln Park and two roads were closed in Mendham Township. Basements were flooded in Morristown. Please refer to the separate storm data entry as flooding for specifics about flooded streams and rivers within the county. Event precipitation totals included 3.91 inches in Morris Township, 3.19 inches in Ironia, 2.64 inches in West Wharton and 2.30 inches in Boonton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from the heavy rain caused flooding of streams and roadways in southern Warren County. A road was closed in Pohatcong Township because of the flooding. Event precipitation totals included 2.29 inches in Greenwich Township and 1.85 inches at the Belvidere Bridge.

Storm totals ranged from one to four inches with the highest amounts in Morris County.||Please note, some of the flooding persisted through the crossover between eastern standard and eastern daylight time on the night of March 8th.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heavy rain caused basement, roadway and stream flooding across the northern part of Mercer County. In Princeton both River Road and Quakerbridge Road were closed. Two roadways were closed in Hopewell Township including New Jersey State Route 29. Nearly half of the flooded basements in Mercer County occurred in Hopewell Township. Event precipitation totals included 2.32 inches in Washington Crossing, 2.30 inches in Trenton and 2.14 inches in Pennington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex low pressure system over the Gulf Coast Friday morning March 7th, interacted with a frontal boundary approaching from the Ohio Valley as it moved northeast. The frontal boundary became nearly stationary across the coastal plain Friday night and a wave of low pressure developed along it. This low passed over the region during the overnight period of March 7th to March 8th followed by the main area of low pressure on Saturday, March 8th, with rainfall totals from both systems between 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A woman and an infant were rescued from their vehicle at the intersection of Route 1 and 9 and McClellan St in Elizabeth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The runoff from the heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as basement and poor drainage flooding across much of central and northwest New Jersey during the afternoon of the 8th. The region was primed for flooding by another heavy rain event that occurred on the 5th. The runoff from the heavy rain caused flooding to continue through the 10th in the Raritan Basin and through the 13th in the Passaic Basin. Rain began falling during the afternoon on the 7th and did not end until the early evening on the 8th. It fell at its heaviest between 10 a.m. EST and 3 p.m. EST on the 8th. Storm totals ranged from one to four inches with the highest amounts in Morris County.||Please note, some of the flooding persisted through the crossover between eastern standard and eastern daylight time on the night of March 8th.||The heavy rain was caused by a low pressure system that developed in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico on the 7th. It deepened to a 997 millibar low by the time it moved slowly northeast into West Virginia at 7 a.m. EST on the 8th. At 1 p.m. EST on the 8th, there were a pair of 992 millibar lows, one near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and the other in northern Virginia. At 4 p.m. EST on the 8th, they combined into one over southeast Pennsylvania and deepened to 987 millibars. At 7 p.m. EST the low had deepened to 985 millibars and was near New York City. Its associated cold front had cleared Delaware and New Jersey and ended the rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heavy rain caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams mainly in the southern part of Hunterdon County. The heavy rain led to flooding along the South Branch of the Raritan River later that day. Flooding was reported on County Routes 519 and 602 as well as within Lambertville, Raritan Township and East Amwell Township. New Jersey State Route 29 was closed in Delaware Township. Flooding was reported on Holcombe Island. Flooding was also reported around the small bridges in and around Califon. Event precipitation totals included 2.91 inches in Flemington, 2.38 inches in Stockton and 2.36 inches in Califon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger scattered showers and thunderstorms across New Jersey during the evening of the 14th. The thunderstorms moved slowly and caused flash flooding in Monmouth County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused roadway flooding and flooding of smaller streams and creeks in the northeastern part of Monmouth County. A Skywarn spotter measured 3 inches of rain within 45 minutes in Middletown Township. Roadway flooding was reported in Middletown and Highlands.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which caused Flash Flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five people were rescued from their vehicle which became stranded in rising water in a shopping center parking lot on West Pleasant View Ave. in Hackensack.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rain which caused Flash Flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Stillwell Avenue was closed from 10th street to where it ends at Anderson Ave. in Fort Lee. Three feet of water was on the road at the underpass.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front helped trigger some back building thunderstorms in Middlesex County that caused flash flooding during the late afternoon and early evening on the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Back building thunderstorms produced flash flooding across northern Middlesex County in Edison, North Brunswick, Milltown, East Brunswick and New Brunswick. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches across the area. ||In New Brunswick, New Jersey State Route 18 was closed due to flooding. Emergency repairs had to be done to one of the lanes after the flooding subsided and the road was backed up for over two and a half miles. The basement of the Middlesex County Family Courthouse was flooded and the offices were relocated for a couple of days. The office reopened on July 3rd. A few other roads were flooded in the city including New Street. Three roadways were flooded and closed in North Brunswick Township. Main Street was flooded in Milltown and flooding was also reported in Edsion and East Brunswick Townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in Sussex County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pair of thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flooding of smaller streams and poor drainage areas in and around Hainesville in Montague and Sandyston Townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dissipating but stalled frontal boundary helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy rain during the late afternoon of the 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused roadway flooding and flooding of smaller creeks in and around Palmyra. Several roads in Palmyra were flooded and some minor flooding also occurred at the entrance of the Palmyra Tacony Bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front draped across the local area produced thunderstorms with torrential downpours leading to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 4 was closed in both directions due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential rain caused flash flooding in Somerset and Monmouth Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential rains caused flash flooding and water rescues across central Monmouth County. Widespread flooding was reported in Freehold. Flooding along Douglas Road reached up to four feet and inundated a few homes in the area. The Monmouth County fair was closed early. Two motorists were rescued from flooded Taylors Mills Road in Manalapan Township. A motorist was also rescued from flooded Pine Street in Tinton Falls. Asbury Avenue was also flooded in Tinton Falls. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were between four and five inches. A Skywarn Spotter in Colts Neck measured 3.82 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of the heavy rain that fell with Tropical Storm Hanna on the 6th and heavy rain that fell along and around the cold frontal passage on the 9th, led to flash flooding of roadways and small streams in the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to minor flash flooding of streams and roadways in and around Netcong Borough. In the central part of the county, several roads were flooded in Dover. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between two and two and a half inches around the borough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with Tropical Storm Hanna caused widespread heavy rain and poor drainage flooding, especially in the northern part of New Jersey. The runoff also caused some isolated flooding along some of the smaller streams and creeks in the area. Rain moved into the region around noon EDT, fell heavy at times during the late afternoon and early evening and ended during the late evening. Storm totals ranged from around 2 to around 5 inches with the highest amounts in northern New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heavy rain that fell during the early evening of the 6th led to flash flooding in and around Palmyra. The Tacony-Palmyra Bridge Toll Plaza was flooded and all eastbound traffic into New Jersey was halted for about 45 minutes until the water receded. Two other roadways in Palmyra were also closed. Doppler Radar adjusted storm total amounts exceeded three inches in the borough.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong for August upper air disturbance helped trigger numerous strong to severe thunderstorms across New Jersey. In addition these storms moved over the same areas of Salem and Gloucester Counties and produced flash flooding of streams and fields.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flooding of small creeks and roadways in Pitman Borough. The worst reported flooding was near and along the railroad line where vehicles became stuck and water rescues were performed. No serious injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomolous slow moving upper level low pressure system in combination with a weak surface cold front and local seabreezes triggered thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall which led to flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Molnar Dr. and Midland Ave. in Elmwood Park was impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomolous low pressure system over southeast New York produced numerous thunderstorms with torrential rainfall which led to flash flooding in northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North Avenue in Elizabeth was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomolous low pressure system over southeast New York produced numerous thunderstorms with torrential rainfall which led to flash flooding in northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Elmora Ave. at Fay Ave. in Elizabeth was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomolous low pressure system over southeast New York produced numerous thunderstorms with torrential rainfall which led to flash flooding in northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maple Street in Fort Lee was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomolous low pressure system over southeast New York produced numerous thunderstorms with torrential rainfall which led to flash flooding in northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 17 southbound was closed at Paterson Ave. in East Rutherford and near Highland Cross in Rutherford due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomolous low pressure system over southeast New York produced numerous thunderstorms with torrential rainfall which led to flash flooding in northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three feet of water inundated Frelinghuysen Ave. in Newark.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved across the area producing thunderstorms with torrential downpours which caused isolated flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: New Bridge Rd., the south end of River Rd., the south end of Boulevard and Reichelt Roads; all in New Milford, were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure moving along a stationary front draped across the local area produced thunderstorms with torrential downpours leading to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 17 northbound was impassable for 0.8 mile at the exit for Linwood Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong for August upper air disturbance helped trigger numerous strong to severe thunderstorms across New Jersey. In addition these storms moved over the same areas of Salem and Gloucester Counties and produced flash flooding of streams and fields.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moving over the same areas of Woolwich Township caused flooding of fields and small streams. One farm had 35 acres of sweet potato and butternut squash under water. Adjusted for hail Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches in the township. In neighboring Harrison Township, a storm total of 3.27 inches was measured in Mullica Hill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong for August upper air disturbance helped trigger numerous strong to severe thunderstorms across New Jersey. In addition these storms moved over the same areas of Salem and Gloucester Counties and produced flash flooding of streams and fields.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moving across the same areas caused flash flooding in Mannington, Carney's Point and Pennsville Townships. In Mannington Township, flooding washed away a small bridge over a tributary creek to the Salem River. U.S. Route 40 was flooded along the Pennsville and Carney's Point Township line. In Carney Point Township, the YMCA was partially closed after flood waters reached the fitness center, locker rooms and pool. Dunn's Park was also flooded. In Pennsville Township, flooding reached into a few homes. Adjusted for hail contamination, Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 4 inches in the area. A rainfall total of 5 inches was estimated in Mannington Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential rain caused flash flooding in Somerset and Monmouth Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams were reported in and around Bound Brook. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 3 inches in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of low pressure rode along a slow moving cold front approaching the area on July 23. A tropical airmass was already in place across the local area from Tropical Storm Cristobal which passed by to our east the previous day. The combination of these systems interacting with this airmass led to torrential rainfall and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many streets were flooded in Fort Lee.  Some of these streets were impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of low pressure rode along a slow moving cold front approaching the area on July 23. A tropical airmass was already in place across the local area from Tropical Storm Cristobal which passed by to our east the previous day. The combination of these systems interacting with this airmass led to torrential rainfall and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Short Hills Ave. in Millburn was closed due to flooding.  Water also covered the Railroad tracks suspending service.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of the heavy rain that fell with Tropical Storm Hanna on the 6th and heavy rain that fell along and around the cold frontal passage on the 9th, led to flash flooding of roadways and small streams in the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flooding of small river and roadway flooding in and around Somerdale Borough. Somerdale Road was closed near the White Horse Pike (U.S. Route 30). This is located close to the Cooper River. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were around 1.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of the heavy rain that fell with Tropical Storm Hanna on the 6th and heavy rain that fell along and around the cold frontal passage on the 9th, led to flash flooding of roadways and small streams in the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rain led to roadway flooding as well as flooding of smaller streams across central Somerset County from Branchburg Township east through Bound Brook Borough. Several roads were closed. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of the heavy rain that fell with Tropical Storm Hanna on the 6th and heavy rain that fell along and around the cold frontal passage on the 9th, led to flash flooding of roadways and small streams in the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rain caused flooding of smaller streams in northern Middlesex County. It also led to lane closures along the Garden State Parkway. Doppler Radar Storm Total estimates reached around 1.5 inches, most of which fell within an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna impacted Northeast New Jersey, making landfall near the Nassau/Suffolk County border around 10:35 pm on the 6th. Storm total rainfall ranged from 2.52 inches at Ridgewood to 5.50 inches at River Edge. Periods of torrential rainfall from heavy showers and thunderstorms caused flash flooding of many urban areas, small streams, and rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inches of moving water was reported on Linwood Ave. in Ridgewood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna impacted Northeast New Jersey, making landfall near the Nassau/Suffolk County border around 10:35 pm on the 6th. Storm total rainfall ranged from 2.52 inches at Ridgewood to 5.50 inches at River Edge. Periods of torrential rainfall from heavy showers and thunderstorms caused flash flooding of many urban areas, small streams, and rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Frank E. Rodgers Blvd. near Middlesex St. and Cape May St. in Harrison was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna impacted Northeast New Jersey, making landfall near the Nassau/Suffolk County border around 10:35 pm on the 6th. Storm total rainfall ranged from 2.52 inches at Ridgewood to 5.50 inches at River Edge. Periods of torrential rainfall from heavy showers and thunderstorms caused flash flooding of many urban areas, small streams, and rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three feet of water inundated Route 440 at Danforth Ave. in Jersey City and was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna impacted Northeast New Jersey, making landfall near the Nassau/Suffolk County border around 10:35 pm on the 6th. Storm total rainfall ranged from 2.52 inches at Ridgewood to 5.50 inches at River Edge. Periods of torrential rainfall from heavy showers and thunderstorms caused flash flooding of many urban areas, small streams, and rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused major flooding of a newly constructed tanning salon in Ramsey.  There was basement flooding and the building inspector and rescue squad were called in due to concerns of a structural collapse from leaks in the foundation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna impacted Northeast New Jersey, making landfall near the Nassau/Suffolk County border around 10:35 pm on the 6th. Storm total rainfall ranged from 2.52 inches at Ridgewood to 5.50 inches at River Edge. Periods of torrential rainfall from heavy showers and thunderstorms caused flash flooding of many urban areas, small streams, and rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Meeker Ave. at Elizabeth Ave. in Newark was closed with cars floating due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna impacted Northeast New Jersey, making landfall near the Nassau/Suffolk County border around 10:35 pm on the 6th. Storm total rainfall ranged from 2.52 inches at Ridgewood to 5.50 inches at River Edge. Periods of torrential rainfall from heavy showers and thunderstorms caused flash flooding of many urban areas, small streams, and rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Valley Road in Wayne was inundated with water and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna impacted Northeast New Jersey, making landfall near the Nassau/Suffolk County border around 10:35 pm on the 6th. Storm total rainfall ranged from 2.52 inches at Ridgewood to 5.50 inches at River Edge. Periods of torrential rainfall from heavy showers and thunderstorms caused flash flooding of many urban areas, small streams, and rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed in Jersey City due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Hanna impacted Northeast New Jersey, making landfall near the Nassau/Suffolk County border around 10:35 pm on the 6th. Storm total rainfall ranged from 2.52 inches at Ridgewood to 5.50 inches at River Edge. Periods of torrential rainfall from heavy showers and thunderstorms caused flash flooding of many urban areas, small streams, and rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Newark Turnpike was closed from the New Jersey Tpke. to Route 7 in Kearny due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front swept through the tri-state area, resulting in numerous thunderstorms that produced isolated flash flooding in Bergen County.
