EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential downpours led to flash flooding along the Culver Creek in Branchville. A State of Emergency was declared after the creek tore away the Mill Street Bridge in the borough. Ten homes had over eight feet of water in them, the most severely damaged were at the end of Mill Street. Residents from about 50 homes evacuated, with residents from all but one home being able to return at Noon EDT that day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding across northwest New Jersey during the morning of the 28th. Event precipitation totals in the heavier band that extended from northern Hunterdon County northeastward through the border of Sussex and Morris Counties averaged 3 to 5 inches. The runoff from the heavy rain then caused some stream and smaller river flooding in northwest New Jersey that lasted into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along many small streams in north central Hunterdon County. Stream flooding was reported in Lebanon, Glen Gardner, Clinton and Tewksbury.  There were a couple of camper rescues and vehicles were flooded. The runoff from the heavy rain also caused flooding along the South Branch of the Raritan River. Event precipitation totals included 3.99 inches in High Bridge, 3.94 inches in Clinton, 3.93 inches in Lebanon, 3.88 inches in Califon, 3.23 inches in Holland and 3.13 inches in Franklin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding across northwest New Jersey during the morning of the 28th. Event precipitation totals in the heavier band that extended from northern Hunterdon County northeastward through the border of Sussex and Morris Counties averaged 3 to 5 inches. The runoff from the heavy rain then caused some stream and smaller river flooding in northwest New Jersey that lasted into the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding along smaller streams in southwestern Morris County in Washington and Mount Olive Townships. About a half dozen people had to be rescued from vehicles along River Road (South Branch of the Raritan River) in Mount Olive Township. Event precipitation totals included 4.99 inches in Mount Olive Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall, which caused isolated flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Fifth St. and Victor St. in Saddle Brook was impassible due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of low pressure riding along a nearly stationary frontal boundary across the local area caused several rounds of thunderstorms, which resulted in flash flooding throughout Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Skylands Rd. in Ringwood was closed due to several inches of moving water on the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of low pressure riding along a nearly stationary frontal boundary across the local area caused several rounds of thunderstorms, which resulted in flash flooding throughout Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Running water broke and moved a cinderblock wall on Rockburn Pass Rd. in West Milford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed along a lee side trough and affected central New Jersey during the second half of the afternoon into the early evening of the 6th. Multiple thunderstorms affected northwestern Burlington County where flash flooding occurred. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 3 to 4 inches in parts of Florence, Mansfield and Bordentown Townships.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the U.S. Route 206 corridor in Bordentown Township. A couple of water rescues occurred and no injuries were reported.  Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 3 to 4 inches in parts of Bordentown Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed along a lee side trough and affected central New Jersey during the second half of the afternoon into the early evening of the 6th. Multiple thunderstorms affected northwestern Burlington County where flash flooding occurred. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 3 to 4 inches in parts of Florence, Mansfield and Bordentown Townships.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused small stream and roadway flash flooding in Florence Township. Adjusted Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 3 to 4 inches in parts of Florence Township. A Cocorahs observer in neighboring Chesterfield Township measured 2.49 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger numerous thunderstorms during the second half of the afternoon into the early evening of the 8th in Camden and Gloucester Counties. Similar conditions occurred across eastern Morris County. Storm totals reached between 3 and 4 inches and caused considerable highway and poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding of smaller streams and then later flooding along the Cooper River. Because this coincided with a Friday afternoon, they heavy rain and flooding greatly compounded the commute home and toward shore points in the local Philadelphia Metropolitan Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage and small stream flooding in central Gloucester County in and around Glassboro. A Skywarn spotter measured an event total of 4.00 inches in Glaassboro.  Other Gloucester County precipitation event totals included 3.07 inches in Mantua.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front helped trigger thunderstorms over southwestern New Jersey during the late afternoon and early evening of the 25th. Repeat or training thunderstorms produced flash flooding in western Cumberland County where rainfall amounts reached between 3 and 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams and fields in the Cohansey Creek basin in western Cumberland County. The heaviest rain fell in Greenwich, Hopewell and Stow Creek Townships. Actual storm totals included 3.14 inches in Greenwich Township and 2.29 inches in Bridgeton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger numerous thunderstorms during the second half of the afternoon into the early evening of the 8th in Camden and Gloucester Counties. Similar conditions occurred across eastern Morris County. Storm totals reached between 3 and 4 inches and caused considerable highway and poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding of smaller streams and then later flooding along the Cooper River. Because this coincided with a Friday afternoon, they heavy rain and flooding greatly compounded the commute home and toward shore points in the local Philadelphia Metropolitan Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding forced the closure of the northbound lanes of Interstate 295 in Bellmawr.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of low pressure riding along a nearly stationary frontal boundary across the local area caused several rounds of thunderstorms, which resulted in flash flooding throughout Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local authorities in Saddle River performed water rescues at the intersection of W. Saddle River Rd. and Allendale Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger numerous thunderstorms during the second half of the afternoon into the early evening of the 8th in Camden and Gloucester Counties. Similar conditions occurred across eastern Morris County. Storm totals reached between 3 and 4 inches and caused considerable highway and poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding of smaller streams and then later flooding along the Cooper River. Because this coincided with a Friday afternoon, they heavy rain and flooding greatly compounded the commute home and toward shore points in the local Philadelphia Metropolitan Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused considerable urban and poor drainage flooding in western Camden County as well as flash flooding of smaller creeks. It wreaked havoc to the start of the weekend commute as it coincided with a Friday afternoon on the 8th. In Camden, Interstate 676 was closed in both directions. Flash flooding was also reported along Federal Street and the Admiral Wilson Boulevard. Flash flooding was also reported on the Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Pennsauken Township as well as State Route 38. In Gloucester City, U.S. Route 130 was closed at Interstate 76. In Bellmawr Borough, Southbound New Jersey State Route 42 (North-South Freeway) was closed due to flooding just south of Interstate 295. Eastbound 295 itself was closed due to flooding at Creek Road. ||In Pennsauken, a Skywarn spotter measure 1.75 inches of rain within 20 minutes. Event precipitation totals within Camden County included 3.82 inches in Berlin, 2.93 inches in Winslow and 1.97 inches in Merchantville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front helped trigger numerous thunderstorms during the second half of the afternoon into the early evening of the 8th in Camden and Gloucester Counties. Similar conditions occurred across eastern Morris County. Storm totals reached between 3 and 4 inches and caused considerable highway and poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding of smaller streams and then later flooding along the Cooper River. Because this coincided with a Friday afternoon, they heavy rain and flooding greatly compounded the commute home and toward shore points in the local Philadelphia Metropolitan Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding near Morristown forced the closure of Interstate 287. Event precipitation totals included 1.59 inches in Mount Olive Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing mid level disturbance triggered scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Bergen and Hudson Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stranded in flood waters at the intersection of Elm Ave. and Voohis Ave. in River Edge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing mid level disturbance triggered scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Bergen and Hudson Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Midland Ave. at Laurel Ave. and Magnolia Ave. in River Edge was impassible due to flooding.  Kinderkamack Rd. in Oradell was closed due to flooding.  River Edge Ave. in New Milford was impassible due to flooding.  One vehicle was stranded in flood waters on Fred St. in Old Tappan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing mid level disturbance triggered scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Bergen and Hudson Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fish House Rd. in Kearny was impassable and closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to seven inches of rain across a wide swath of New Jersey (less along most of the coast) from overnight on the 13th into the day on the 14th. But in southern Gloucester, Eastern Salem and Western Cumberland County, rainfall amounts reached seven to eleven inches. Scattered thunderstorms occurred into the 15th and morning of the 16th. This slowed the recession of rivers and streams in the state. The combined event caused severe flash flooding with dam breaks in southwestern New Jersey and flash flooding and flooding across central and northern New Jersey.  Damage estimates reached around 25 million dollars, most of which occurred in Salem and Cumberland Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with repeated torrential downpours caused flash flooding with damaging effects across eastern Salem County, especially in Pittsgrove Township. A county state of emergency was declared. At least one water rescue was reported. Flooding was reported in Alloway, Pittsgrove, Elmer and Upper Pittsgrove Townships. Fourteen roadways, nine bridges and many culverts were damaged, most in Pittsgrove Township. Some families were evacuated in Pittsgrove Township around Palatine and Centerton Lakes. Two bridges washed away in the township on Greenville and Burlington Roads. It was expected to take six to twelve months for both bridges to be replaced. Two other township roadways remained closed into the 19th. In spite of being drained prior to the rain, Centeron Lake filled and flooded. A few homes were half submerged by flood waters along Palatine Lake. In Elmer, Elmer Lake also flooded. Event precipitation totals included 9.64 inches in Elmer and 5.89 inches in Woodstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to seven inches of rain across a wide swath of New Jersey (less along most of the coast) from overnight on the 13th into the day on the 14th. But in southern Gloucester, Eastern Salem and Western Cumberland County, rainfall amounts reached seven to eleven inches. Scattered thunderstorms occurred into the 15th and morning of the 16th. This slowed the recession of rivers and streams in the state. The combined event caused severe flash flooding with dam breaks in southwestern New Jersey and flash flooding and flooding across central and northern New Jersey.  Damage estimates reached around 25 million dollars, most of which occurred in Salem and Cumberland Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused roadway, poor drainage and field flooding in the southern half of Camden County. Several roadways were flooded and closed, the most notable the White Horse Pike (U.S. Route 30).  Event precipitation totals included 8.04 inches in Winslow Township and 5.41 inches in Berlin Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to seven inches of rain across a wide swath of New Jersey (less along most of the coast) from overnight on the 13th into the day on the 14th. But in southern Gloucester, Eastern Salem and Western Cumberland County, rainfall amounts reached seven to eleven inches. Scattered thunderstorms occurred into the 15th and morning of the 16th. This slowed the recession of rivers and streams in the state. The combined event caused severe flash flooding with dam breaks in southwestern New Jersey and flash flooding and flooding across central and northern New Jersey.  Damage estimates reached around 25 million dollars, most of which occurred in Salem and Cumberland Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams and roadways in southern Warren County, mainly in Lopatcong, Greenwich and Pohatcong Townships, Alpha Borough and Phillipsburg. Event precipitation totals included 5.30 inches in Washington Township, 4.74 inches in Greenwich Township and 4.08 inches in Phillipsburg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to seven inches of rain across a wide swath of New Jersey (less along most of the coast) from overnight on the 13th into the day on the 14th. But in southern Gloucester, Eastern Salem and Western Cumberland County, rainfall amounts reached seven to eleven inches. Scattered thunderstorms occurred into the 15th and morning of the 16th. This slowed the recession of rivers and streams in the state. The combined event caused severe flash flooding with dam breaks in southwestern New Jersey and flash flooding and flooding across central and northern New Jersey.  Damage estimates reached around 25 million dollars, most of which occurred in Salem and Cumberland Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams and roadways in northwestern Hunterdon County, mainly in Alexandria, Bethlehem, Holland and Union Townships. Event precipitation totals included 5.23 inches in Bethlehem Township, 5.18 inches in Califon, 4.59 inches in High Bridge and 4.36 inches in Clinton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy rain that caused flooding in Somerset and Morris Counties during the afternoon and evening of the 9th. Event precipitation totals reached two to three inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding and road closures in eastern Somerset County. Road closures were reported in Bound Brook, Bridgewater, Manville and Montgomery. Several vehicular rescues were performed. All roads were reopened by 5 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 2.33 inches in Franklin Township, 2.07 inches in Hillsborough Township and 2.02 inches in Bridgewater Township and Somerville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to seven inches of rain across a wide swath of New Jersey (less along most of the coast) from overnight on the 13th into the day on the 14th. But in southern Gloucester, Eastern Salem and Western Cumberland County, rainfall amounts reached seven to eleven inches. Scattered thunderstorms occurred into the 15th and morning of the 16th. This slowed the recession of rivers and streams in the state. The combined event caused severe flash flooding with dam breaks in southwestern New Jersey and flash flooding and flooding across central and northern New Jersey.  Damage estimates reached around 25 million dollars, most of which occurred in Salem and Cumberland Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of smaller streams and roadways in southern Somerset County. The runoff from the heavy rain caused flooding along the Millstone River later that day. The Pike Run at Belle Mead was above its 7 flood stage from 653 a.m. EDT through 1046 a.m. EDT on the 14th. It crested at 7.25 feet at 930 a.m. EDT.  Event precipitation totals included 5.86 inches in Montgomery Township, 4.61 inches in Hillsborough Township and 4.13 inches in Franklin Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to seven inches of rain across a wide swath of New Jersey (less along most of the coast) from overnight on the 13th into the day on the 14th. But in southern Gloucester, Eastern Salem and Western Cumberland County, rainfall amounts reached seven to eleven inches. Scattered thunderstorms occurred into the 15th and morning of the 16th. This slowed the recession of rivers and streams in the state. The combined event caused severe flash flooding with dam breaks in southwestern New Jersey and flash flooding and flooding across central and northern New Jersey.  Damage estimates reached around 25 million dollars, most of which occurred in Salem and Cumberland Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of roadways and streams in northeastern Morris County during the morning of the 14th. The runoff flooding continued into the morning of the 16th. The East Ditch at Beaver Brook Road was above its 2.5 foot flood stage from 1005 a.m. EDT on the 14th through 817 a.m. EDT on the 16th. It crested at 3.13 feet at 1050  p.m. EDT on the 14th. Event precipitation totals included 4.45 inches in Long Hill Township, 4.08 inches in Denville, 3.79 inches in Morris Township, 3.75 inches in Chatham and 3.47 inches in Parsippany.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching upper level disturbance and a stationary front in the vicinity produced thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall that caused flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Upper Saddle River, Lake St. between East and West Saddle River Rd. and Lower Cross St. also between East and West Saddle River Rd. were closed due to flooding. A motor vehicle was stuck and stranded in three ft. of water on Rt. 202 in Mahwah.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching upper level disturbance and a stationary front in the vicinity produced thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall that caused flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Saddle River, East Allendale Rd. between East and West Saddle River Rd. was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding a cold front dropped three to seven inches of rain across a wide swath of New Jersey (less along most of the coast) from overnight on the 13th into the day on the 14th. But in southern Gloucester, Eastern Salem and Western Cumberland County, rainfall amounts reached seven to eleven inches. Scattered thunderstorms occurred into the 15th and morning of the 16th. This slowed the recession of rivers and streams in the state. The combined event caused severe flash flooding with dam breaks in southwestern New Jersey and flash flooding and flooding across central and northern New Jersey.  Damage estimates reached around 25 million dollars, most of which occurred in Salem and Cumberland Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused street and small stream flash flooding along the northern tier of Atlantic County and affected Hammonton Township the hardest. Four roadways: Fairview Avenue, Orchard Street, Second Street and Railroad Avenue were closed. heavy rain also affected Folsom, Buena and Buena Vista Township. Event precipitation totals included 7.51 inches in Hammonton and 2.15 inches in Buena Vista Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Five days of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain culminated with flash flooding of smaller streams in northeastern Morris County during the late afternoon and early evening of the 18th and then larger stream and river flooding in eastern Morris County that lasted into the 22nd. Minor flooding occurred along the Rockaway and Passaic Rivers and moderate flooding occurred along the lower stretches of the Pompton River. Five day event precipitation totals averaged 3.5 to 6.0 inches. The heaviest rain fell during the afternoon and early evening on the 18th with precipitation totals of around two inches.||The periods of heavy rain were caused by a persistent and blocky weather pattern which forced a low pressure system over the southeastern United States to only slowly move to the northeast. The surface and its upper level low pressure system did not reach New York State until the morning of the 20th. The persistent southeast flow coupled with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year also produced around five days of widespread minor tidal flooding during the evening and overnight high tide cycles from the 15th through the 19th. The highest tides occurred during the evening and overnight high tide cycle on the 17th. The highest tides included 7.66 feet above mean lower low water at Sandy Hook (Monmouth County), 6.52 feet above mean lower low water in Atlantic City (Atlantic County), 7.67 feet above mean lower low water in Cape May (Cape May County), 7.86 feet above mean lower low water at Reedy Island, Delaware and 8.73 feet above mean lower low water in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain during the late afternoon on the 18th led to flash flooding of smaller streams in northeastern Morris County. Larger stream and river flooding followed. This was the fifth consecutive day of heavier rain within the county. Storm total amounts on the 18th within the axis of heavier rain averaged 1.5 to 2.0 inches. The axis of heavier rain extended from East Hanover and Montville Townships northwest through Parsippany, Kinnelon, Boonton and Rockaway Townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of low pressure riding along a nearly stationary frontal boundary across the local area caused several rounds of thunderstorms, which resulted in flash flooding throughout Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 3, just east of the Garden State Pkwy. in Clifton, was closed in both directions due to severe flooding.  Several motorists were stranded in waist-high water and rescued by local authorities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of thunderstorms igniting along the sea breeze front and other thunderstorms that developed preceding an approaching cold front caused pockets of very heavy rain across New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of the 22nd. Hardest hit was southern Ocean County where multiple thunderstorms moved over the same area. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and small creeks in Upper Deerfield Township. A Skywarn spotter reported several roadways were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of thunderstorms igniting along the sea breeze front and other thunderstorms that developed preceding an approaching cold front caused pockets of very heavy rain across New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of the 22nd. Hardest hit was southern Ocean County where multiple thunderstorms moved over the same area. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple thunderstorms produced torrential downpours and flash flooding in eastern parts of Stafford, Barnegat and Ocean Townships. Five inches of rain was reported within ninety minutes. Motorists were stranded within their vehicles with water rising to nearly window level in Manahawkin in Stafford Township. Multiple roadways were closed including New Jersey State Route 72 in Stafford Township.Ten vehicles were so badly flooded that they had to be towed away from the Ocean Acres section of Stafford Township. New Jersey State Route 72, Forecastle and Outboard Avenues remained closed into the evening of the 22nd.  This inhibited weekend getaway traffic to Long Beach Island as this occurred on a Friday.  No serious injuries were reported. Two CoCoRahs reports from Stafford Township had event totals of 7.60 inches and 5.77 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak short wave rotating around a cutoff low pressure system over the Canadian Maritimes caused showers and thunderstorms to develop across the area.  A few of these storms resulted in heavy rainfall, which produced isolated flash flooding in Hudson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Bayonne, 22nd St. between Ave. E and Prospect Ave. was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In addition to the severe weather, thunderstorms dropped heavy rain in northwest New Jersey and caused some poor drainage and isolated flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 3 inches in parts of Morris, Sussex and Warren Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in and around the intersection of U.S. Routes 206 and 46 in Flanders in Mount Olive Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in Long Branch.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding submerged eight vehicles to their windows at city hall police headquarters in Long Branch. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 2.0 to 2.5 inches, most of which fell within 45 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak areas of low pressure moved along a nearly stationary frontal boundary just south of Long Island.  This in combination with an upper level trough also tracking through the area resulted in scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Passaic and Bergen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 17 was closed in both directions in Hasbrook Heights due to flooding. Motorists were stranded in their vehicle on Rt. 17 in Rutherford and were rescued by the local fire department.  In Rochelle Park, the intersection of Ackerman Ave. and Saddle River Rd. was closed due to flooding and all lanes were blocked on Rt. 46 between Bergen Blvd. and Main St. in Ft. Lee also due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with very heavy rain moved across southeast New Jersey during the first half of the day on the 20th. It produced poor drainage flooding as well as flash flooding in Mystic Island in Ocean County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 6 inches in parts of Cape May, Southeast Burlington and Southern Ocean Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of heavy rain from a series of thunderstorms and the approaching spring high tide associated with the new moon caused flash flooding of roadways in the Mystic Islands section of Little Egg Harbor Township. Several vehicles became stuck in flood waters and rescues were performed. Actual rainfall amounts included 5.50 inches in New Gretna (Burlington County) and 5.30 inches in Mystic Islands.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Successive waves of thunderstorms with very heavy rain overnight on the 3rd into the 4th produced flash flooding in southwestern Ocean County and southeastern Burlington County. The runoff from the torrential rains caused flooding along the Oswego and Wading Rivers that lasted into the 6th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 10 inches in southeastern Burlington County, more than half of which fell with the first wave of torrential downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flooding in sections of Bass River and Woodland Township. Event precipitation totals included 5.19 inches in Chatsworth (Woodland Township).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system and upper level disturbance moved through the Northeast during the morning and afternoon hours, producing multiple rounds of thunderstorms with torrential rain and flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Westwood, torrential rain flooded the basement of a medical center on Old Hook Rd.   Ractrack Road was also closed due to flooding in HoHoKus.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a weak cold front and upper air disturbance triggered a cluster of thunderstorms that tracked through central New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of the 9th. Torrential downpours affected portions of Mercer and Middlesex counties, producing areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flash flooding that resulted in several water rescues and stranded vehicles in Woodbridge. Three vehicles were trapped on Woodbridge Center Drive. Several other vehicles were caught in flood waters on U.S. Route 9 under the New Jersey State Route 440 Bridge and also on Leesville Avenue. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were around 3 inches in the Woodbridge area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a weak cold front and upper air disturbance triggered a cluster of thunderstorms that tracked through central New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of the 9th. Torrential downpours affected portions of Mercer and Middlesex counties, producing areas of flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flash flooding on roadways in Hopewell Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were around 3 inches throughout most of the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of slow moving thunderstorms associated with a nearly stationary low pressure system in Eastern Virginia caused flash flooding in Cape May County during the evening and overnight on the 25th into the 26th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused additional flash flooding in lower Cape May County, in particular North Wildwood and Wildwood Crest where streets were flooded. Some businesses in Wildwood were flooded. Event precipitation totals included 4.46 inches in Wildwood Crest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of slow moving thunderstorms associated with a nearly stationary low pressure system in Eastern Virginia caused flash flooding in Cape May County during the evening and overnight on the 25th into the 26th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused additional flash flooding in Avalon and Stone Harbor. In Avalon, one vehicle was totally submerged in flood waters. No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of slow moving thunderstorms associated with a nearly stationary low pressure system in Eastern Virginia caused flash flooding in Cape May County during the evening and overnight on the 25th into the 26th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in western parts of Lower Township, North Cape May, Cape May and West Cape May. Vehicles were stuck in flood waters in Cape May. Event precipitation totals included 5.05 inches in Cape May.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers and thunderstorms preceding an approaching low pressure from the Ohio Valley, produced some very heavy rain as it moved through central New Jersey during the afternoon of the 14th.  Flash flooding occurred in Atlantic County with one storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms which back built over Galloway Township caused flash flooding during the late afternoon of the 14th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 3 to 5 inches in the township. The Garden State Parkway was flooded in the township as were numerous other smaller roadways including Kensington Drive. Vehicles were partially submerged and flood waters reached up to the entrances of homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a weak cold front and a mid level disturbance, along with an increasingly hot and humid air mass, triggered strong to severe thunderstorms, which produced heavy rain and flooding in New Jersey. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding from torrential downpours flooded Stanton-Grange Road in Lebanon and Stanton-Station Road in Readington Township.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates were 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a weak cold front and a mid level disturbance, along with an increasingly hot and humid air mass, triggered strong to severe thunderstorms, which produced heavy rain and flooding in New Jersey. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours produced 2 to 5 inches of rain, which caused poor drainage and street flooding to occur along Cain Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a weak cold front and a mid level disturbance, along with an increasingly hot and humid air mass, triggered strong to severe thunderstorms, which produced heavy rain and flooding in New Jersey. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3 and 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding reported along Main Street and Yorktown Road in Millstone due to heavy rains of 2 to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding an approaching cold front that coincided nearly exactly with the afternoon high tide produced flash flooding along coastal sections of Atlantic and Cape May Counties. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2.0 and 2.5 inches right along the immediate shore from Ocean City (Cape May County) northeast into Atlantic City (Atlantic County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in Ocean City, Sea Isle City and Middle and Lower Townships. Widespread roadway flooding was reported, especially in Ocean City. The heavy rain coincided with the afternoon high tide. Event precipitation totals included 1.78 inches in Dennis Township and 1.70 inches in Middle Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms preceding an approaching cold front that coincided nearly exactly with the afternoon high tide produced flash flooding along coastal sections of Atlantic and Cape May Counties. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2.0 and 2.5 inches right along the immediate shore from Ocean City (Cape May County) northeast into Atlantic City (Atlantic County).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding on Absecon Island in both Atlantic City and Margate City. Numerous streets were flooded in Atlantic City and vehicles were getting stuck in the high water. In Margate, flooding spread into some buidlings.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2.0 to 2.5 inches on the island. The Marina within Atlantic City measured 1.60 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms that preceded a cold front during the afternoon of the 5th produced locally heavy rain as well as flash flooding in Ocean County.  Daily precipitation totals were generally an inch or less, but reached between 2 and 3 inches in parts of Ocean County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding along McKinley Avenue in Stafford Township. A couple of basements were also flooded on Perry Lane. Event precipitation totals included 3.49 inches in Berkeley Township and 3.01 inches in Stafford Township, all of which fell within two hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Successive waves of thunderstorms with very heavy rain overnight on the 3rd into the 4th produced flash flooding in southwestern Ocean County and southeastern Burlington County. The runoff from the torrential rains caused flooding along the Oswego and Wading Rivers that lasted into the 6th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 10 inches in southeastern Burlington County, more than half of which fell with the first wave of torrential downpours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flooding in sections of Stafford, Barnegat and Little Egg Township. The torrential downpours led to the closing of New Jersey State Route 72 in western Barnegat Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours associated with the remnants of Hurricane Isaac overnight on the 4rd caused flash flooding in Sussex County.   Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 6 inches in the western part of the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of streams and poor drainage flooding in Montague, Sandyston, Walpack and Wantage Townships in western Sussex County. In Sandyston, several driveways were washed away. County Route 560 was closed for debris clean-up. Firefighters pumped water from basements on Bevans Road and County Route 560.  Flooded roadways were reported in Montague. New Jersey State Route 23 was flooded and closed in Wantage. Event precipitation totals included 3.47 inches in Montague and 3.44 inches in Wantage. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 6 inches in parts of Sandyston and Walpack Townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak areas of low pressure moved along a nearly stationary frontal boundary just south of Long Island.  This in combination with an upper level trough also tracking through the area resulted in scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Passaic and Bergen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Spring Ave. and S. Irving St. in Ridgewood was impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak areas of low pressure moved along a nearly stationary frontal boundary just south of Long Island.  This in combination with an upper level trough also tracking through the area resulted in scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Passaic and Bergen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 3 westbound between Bloomfield Ave. and the Garden State Pkwy. in Clifton was impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front that was moving through the state into New England helped trigger a series of thunderstorms that moved through Sussex County during the first part of the afternoon of the 23rd. Torrential downpours affected the western part of the county the most and produced some flash flooding. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached close to 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of streams and poor drainage flooding on roadways in Sandyston Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 2.5 inches throughout most of the township and peaked closed to 5 inches. A mesonet site in Walpack Township measured 3.54 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak areas of low pressure moved along a nearly stationary frontal boundary just south of Long Island.  This in combination with an upper level trough also tracking through the area resulted in scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Passaic and Bergen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Berdan Ave. at Hamburg Turnpike in Wayne was impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak areas of low pressure moved along a nearly stationary frontal boundary just south of Long Island.  This in combination with an upper level trough also tracking through the area resulted in scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Passaic and Bergen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Race Track Rd. was closed at Rt. 17 South in HoHoKus due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak areas of low pressure moved along a nearly stationary frontal boundary just south of Long Island.  This in combination with an upper level trough also tracking through the area resulted in scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Passaic and Bergen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Market St. in Saddle Brook was impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak areas of low pressure moved along a nearly stationary frontal boundary just south of Long Island.  This in combination with an upper level trough also tracking through the area resulted in scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Passaic and Bergen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A person was trapped inside their vehicle due to flood waters near the intersection of Maple Ave. and Glen Ave. in Glen Rock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak areas of low pressure moved along a nearly stationary frontal boundary just south of Long Island.  This in combination with an upper level trough also tracking through the area resulted in scattered thunderstorms which produced heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Passaic and Bergen counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Motorists were stranded in their vehicles and were rescued by boat at the intersection of Rt. 17 North and Rt. 4 in Paramus.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in western parts of Salem and Gloucester Counties during the early evening on the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as poor drainage flooding in Salem County affecting Carneys Point and Oldman Township to the west of the New Jersey Turnpike. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around two inches, most of which fell within one hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in western parts of Salem and Gloucester Counties during the early evening on the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks as well as poor drainage flooding in Gloucester County affecting the municipalities along the Delaware River.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around two inches, most of which fell within one hour. Event precipitation totals included 1.83 inches in East Greenwich Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough ahead of a cold front triggered numerous showers and thunderstorms. These storms produced heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding across portions of Bergen County, New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chestnut St. in Allendale was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough ahead of a cold front triggered numerous showers and thunderstorms. These storms produced heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding across portions of Bergen County, New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: East Crescent Ave. was closed due to flooding with one vehicle stranded in flood waters in Allendale.  In Wyckoff, 3 vehicles became stranded in 3 feet of water on Russell Ave. near Rt. 208.  The motorists of two of these vehicles were trapped inside and had to be rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms congealed into a squall line ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon. Isolated severe thunderstorms were embedded within the line, mainly over the Northeast NJ Metro area. Heavy rain associated with this line produced flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Rutherford, Hackensack St. was closed near the Rt. 17 off ramp due to flooding.  Several motorists were stranded due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal trough ahead of a cold front triggered numerous showers and thunderstorms. These storms produced heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding across portions of Bergen County, New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pascack Brook at Westwood exceeded its flood stage of 5.0 feet at 8:45 pm EST. The river crested at 5.34 ft at 10:30 pm and fell back within its banks at 12:30 am on May 24.  This resulted in around one foot of flowing water on Washington Ave. in Hillsdale and Broadway north of Lake St. in Westwood.  Three businesses suffered water damage on Broadway as a result.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An occluded front associated with a cutoff low pressure system slowly advanced towards the area from the south.  Thunderstorms training over the same area produced heavy rain that coincided with high tide, which resulted in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stuck in flood waters on W. Pleasant Ave. in Hackensack.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An occluded front associated with a cutoff low pressure system slowly advanced towards the area from the south.  Thunderstorms training over the same area produced heavy rain that coincided with high tide, which resulted in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Hoboken, flood waters blocked the intersection of 3rd and Clinton St.  In Jersey City, multiple cars were stranded in high water at the intersection of 18th St. and Grove Street.  The local fire department performed water rescues.  Multiple cars were also stuck in high waters on Routes 1 and 9 between Manhattan Ave. and Secaucas Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A stretch of Rt. 3 near the Garden State Pkwy. in Clifton was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of showers and thunderstorms withe heavy rain caused flash flooding in the northwest part of the state during the morning of the 1st. While additional showers and thunderstorms occurred during the afternoon, they were not as heavy. Doppler Radar storm total estimates ranged from 1.5 to 4.5 inches in Somerset, Hunterdon, Warren, Morris and Sussex Counties. The heaviest rain fell in Warren County along the Delaware River. The nearly stationary frontal boundary that has been responsible for heavy rain started to retrograde westward as a Bermuda High pressure system moved west from the Atlantic Ocean.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in Parsippany-Troy Hills Township. Eastbound Interstate 80 was flooded as was Interstate 287 in both directions. The ramp from Interstate 80 to Interstate 287 was also flooded. Ramps onto U.S. Route 46 and Interstate 80 were also flooded and closed. Several streets within the township were covered with rapidly flowing water. East of Morristown, the Columbia Turnpike exit east of New Jersey State Route 24 was flooded and closed. Event precipitation totals included 2.23 inches in Parsippany and 2.19 inches in Morristown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moving water approximately one to two feet deep inundated many residence properties in Dumont.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The exit ramp for Clifton Ave. on I-280 in Newark was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Wayne, the service road on Route 23 near I-80 was closed due to flooding.  In addition, there was 3 feet of standing water at the intersection of French Hill Rd. and Valley Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Peckman River at Verona exceeded its flood stage of  3.5 feet at approximately 8:55 EST, crested at 4.02 feet at 9:00 EST and fell back within its banks at 9:15 EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Molly Ann Brook at North Haledon exceeded its flood stage of 6 feet at approximately 9:10 EST, crested at 6.88 feet at 9:15 EST and fell back within its banks at 9:45 EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676. Westbound delays on the Atlantic City Expressway reached two hours.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused flash flooding of smaller creeks and roadways in western Cumberland County.  Particularly hard hit by flooding was New Jersey State Route 77 in Upper Deerfield Township and Bridgeton City. Event precipitation totals included 2.79 inches in Upper Deerfield Township, 2.57 inches in Greenwich Township and 2.07 inches at Seabrook Farms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676. Westbound delays on the Atlantic City Expressway reached two hours.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second wave of thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage, creek and field flash flooding in eastern Salem County. Event precipitation totals included 3.84 inches in Pittsgrove Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a stalled frontal boundary, extending from the Pennsylvania/Maryland border eastward across southern New Jersey, and a series of upper level disturbances resulted in numerous slow-moving thunderstorms from the afternoon of the 22nd through the early morning of the 23rd. These thunderstorms produced torrential rain and some wind damage.||Storm total rainfall measurements ranged mainly between 2 and 7 inches across central to northern New Jersey.  Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and roadway flooding, with some creeks and streams also overflowing their banks. In Jackson (Ocean County), rainfall totals of 5 inches were reported in an hour.||In addition, the combination of the heavy rain and higher than normal astronomical tides associated with the full moon, caused minor tidal flooding along the tidal Delaware River and upper Delaware Bay during the overnight high tide cycles on the 22nd and lingered into the early morning high tide cycle on the 23rd. In Philadelphia, the highest tide reached 8.76 feet above mean lower low water early on the 23rd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.  At Reedy Island (New Castle County), the highest tide reached 7.52 feet above mean lower low water late on the 22nd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell through the night of the 22nd and caused urban and poor drainage flash flooding to occur during the early morning of the 23rd. Water estimated to be a foot deep was reported on Hessian Avenue in West Deptford Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Glen Rock, the intersection of Prospect St. and Locust Ave. was flooded with motor vehicle water rescues required.  Ackerman Ave. was also flooded between Prospect St. and Harristown Rd. with a car stranded in high water.  In Fair Lawn, the intersection of Rt. 208 and Morlot Ave. was closed due to flooding.  Additionally, Broadway was closed at the NJ Transit underpass near the Broadway train station due to flooding. A few cars and a bus were submerged in approximately 6 feet of water requiring water rescues of 6 people by the local fire department.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars were stranded with water rescues performed by local authorities due to flooding at the intersection of Maple and Dayton streets and on Franklin Ave. at the railroad underpass in Ridgewood.  Additionally, Rt. 17 just north of Century Rd. in Paramus was flooded with cars unable to cross the intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: McLean Blvd. between Broadway and I-80 in Paterson was closed due to flooding.  In addition, Rt. 3 at Valley Rd. in Clifton was also closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676. Westbound delays on the Atlantic City Expressway reached two hours.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in western Camden County that damaged vehicles and jammed traffic on major roadways for hours. People were trapped in vehicles for hours. Numerous vehicles were submerged to their tops with multiple rescues on the 42 Freeway, Interstate 76 and in Brooklawn, Camden and Gloucester City. In spite of all of the rescues, no serious injuries were reported. In Gloucester City, U.S. Route 130 was completely submerged. In Collingswood, U.S. Route 30 was closed. On the other side of the Cooper River, waves of water occurred on the Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Pennsauken and Camden. In Barrington, three feet of water accumulated on Clement Bridge Road (New Jersey State Route 41) and raw sewage backed up into apartment buildings. In Camden, the Ferry Avenue PATCO parking lot was flooded. Event precipitation totals included 5.37 inches in Audubon, 5.17 inches in Mount Ephraim, 5.05 inches in Haddonfield, 5.00 inches in Merchantville, 3.63 inches in Collingswood, 3.55 inches in Somerdale, 3.20 inches in Cherry Hill, 2.60 inches in Pennsauken and 2.50 inches in Voorhees Township.

These thunderstorms produced torrential rain and some wind damage.||Storm total rainfall measurements ranged mainly between 2 and 7 inches across central to northern New Jersey.  Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and roadway flooding, with some creeks and streams also overflowing their banks. In Jackson (Ocean County), rainfall totals of 5 inches were reported in an hour.||In addition, the combination of the heavy rain and higher than normal astronomical tides associated with the full moon, caused minor tidal flooding along the tidal Delaware River and upper Delaware Bay during the overnight high tide cycles on the 22nd and lingered into the early morning high tide cycle on the 23rd. In Philadelphia, the highest tide reached 8.76 feet above mean lower low water early on the 23rd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.  At Reedy Island (New Castle County), the highest tide reached 7.52 feet above mean lower low water late on the 22nd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding in Jackson Township in Ocean County. Several roads were reported to be flooded in Jackson. Event precipitation totals included 6.07 inches in Jackson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low encompassing the Mississippi Valley resulted in a moisture feed up the east coast from the Gulf of Mexico. A stationary boundary just to the west of New York City was the focus for training showers and thunderstorms that resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hollywood Ave. in Ho-Ho-Kus was closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The road at the intersection of French Hill Rd. and Parish Dr. buckled due to flooding and had to be closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Inman Ave. and New Brunswick Ave. in Rahway was closed due to flooding.

Event precipitation totals included 3.33 inches in Chester, 3.32 inches in Randolph Township, 2.43 inches in Netcong and Parsippany-Troy Hills and 2.25 inches in Long Hill Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second wave of thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused field, small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in southeastern Gloucester County. Event precipitation totals included 3.86 inches in Malaga in Franklin Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a stalled frontal boundary, extending from the Pennsylvania/Maryland border eastward across southern New Jersey, and a series of upper level disturbances resulted in numerous slow-moving thunderstorms from the afternoon of the 22nd through the early morning of the 23rd. These thunderstorms produced torrential rain and some wind damage.||Storm total rainfall measurements ranged mainly between 2 and 7 inches across central to northern New Jersey.  Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and roadway flooding, with some creeks and streams also overflowing their banks. In Jackson (Ocean County), rainfall totals of 5 inches were reported in an hour.||In addition, the combination of the heavy rain and higher than normal astronomical tides associated with the full moon, caused minor tidal flooding along the tidal Delaware River and upper Delaware Bay during the overnight high tide cycles on the 22nd and lingered into the early morning high tide cycle on the 23rd. In Philadelphia, the highest tide reached 8.76 feet above mean lower low water early on the 23rd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.  At Reedy Island (New Castle County), the highest tide reached 7.52 feet above mean lower low water late on the 22nd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell through the night of the 22nd and caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding to occur during the early morning of the 23rd. Several roads reported flooding through the Mount Holly/Westampton/Mount Laurel area. In Mount Holly, two homes were damaged by flooding on Cherry Street as the Buttonwood Run flooded. Part of the foundation of one home was washed away and was uninhabitable.  The other home was severely damaged, but was unoccupied.  The intersection of Rancocas Road and the Mount Holly By-Pass (County Route 541) was flooded and closed. The basement of the First Presbyterian Church also flooded. In Mount Laurel, flash flooding along Parkers Creek shut down Hartford and Union Mill Rods. Event precipitation totals included 6.71 inches in Eastampton, 6.25 inches at the Mount Holly WFO, 4.00 inches in Florence, 3.43 inches in Hainesport and 3.36 inches in Mount Laurel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676.
