Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding mainly in the northwest part of Somerset County. Event precipitation totals included 3.15 inches in Pottersville, 3.04 inches in Bedminster Township, 2.99 inches in Basking Ridge, 2.96 inches in Bernards Township, 2.83 inches in Branchburg Township, 2.71 inches in Bridgewater Township, 2.53 inches in Far Hills and 1.84 inches in Hillsborough Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bands of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain associated with a low pressure system along the frontal boundary caused some poor drainage flooding in Mercer, Salem and Cumberland Counties and flash flooding in Cape May County. The heaviest rain fell during the afternoon in southern New Jersey and during the late afternoon and early evening in central New Jersey. Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 2.5 inches in Mercer, Salem and Cumberland Counties as well as the northern half of Cape May County and 2.5 to 5.5 inches in the southern half of Cape May County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flash flooding in the southern third of Cape May County. Event precipitation totals included 5.60 inches in Green Creek, 5.51 inches in Erma, 3.83 inches in Cape May,  3.71 inches in Cape May Harbor and 3.12 inches in Wildwood Crest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Andrea moving up the Eastern Seaboard, from the Southeast States to the Mid Atlantic and Northeast Coasts, led to waves of heavy rain and thunderstorms from the early morning hours through the late evening on the 7th. The initial burst of heavy precipitation arrived during the early morning on the 7th as moisture surged into the Mid Atlantic Region ahead of Tropical Storm Andrea, with the center of its low pressure located near the coast of Georgia. Through the course of the day, the cyclone became post-tropical as it accelerated northeastward along the East Coast of the United States, delivering another round of heavy rain with some strong thunderstorms to the Mid Atlantic States during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th. ||Doppler radar storm total estimates ranged from around 2 to 5 inches of rain for the event across New Jersey.  Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and flash flooding, which caused some smaller rivers across southern New Jersey to overflow their banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused minor flooding along roadways and small creeks in central Salem County. Of note, roadway flooding occurred along NJ Route 45 north of County Route 660 (Point Airy Road) near milemarker 12 in Pilesgrove Township. All lanes were closed, and traffic was detoured around this stretch of NJ Route 45 due to flooding. Doppler radar storm total estimates ranged between 3 to 4 inches of rainfall through central Salem County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain that fell on the 10th caused additional flooding across the central third of New Jersey. Event precipitation totals averaged between 1.0 and 2.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to flash flooding along some roadways and smaller rivers in Camden County. The Cooper River at Haddonfield was above its 2.8 foot flood stage from 1252 p.m. EDT through 451 p.m. EDT on the 10th, and it crested at 2.99 feet at 215 p.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 1.91 inches in Mount Ephraim, 1.88 inches in Collingswood, 1.69 inches in Merchantville, and 1.42 inches in Somerdale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676. Westbound delays on the Atlantic City Expressway reached two hours.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in western Salem County and affected Carneys Point and Pennsville Township the hardest. In Pennsville, two women were rescued from their vehicles on North Broadway. In Carneys Point, Ives Avenue, Hickory Avenue and U.S. Route 130 were all flooded and closed. A Cumberland Farms store within the township suffered flood damage. Field flash flooding damaged tomato crops in the county. Event precipitation totals included 5.93 inches in Pennsville Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676. Westbound delays on the Atlantic City Expressway reached two hours.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in western Burlington County. The Southwest Branch of the Rancocas Creek flooded sections of the Golden Pheasant Golf Course in Lumberton. In Southampton. several apartment buildings flooded at the Sherwood Village Complex. Event precipitation totals included 2.91 inches in Mount Laurel, 2.76 inches in Mount Holly, 2.37 inches in Cinnaminson, 2.32 inches in Westampton, 2.08 inches in Palmyra and 2.05 inches in Moorestown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Andrea moving up the Eastern Seaboard, from the Southeast States to the Mid Atlantic and Northeast Coasts, led to waves of heavy rain and thunderstorms from the early morning hours through the late evening on the 7th. The initial burst of heavy precipitation arrived during the early morning on the 7th as moisture surged into the Mid Atlantic Region ahead of Tropical Storm Andrea, with the center of its low pressure located near the coast of Georgia. Through the course of the day, the cyclone became post-tropical as it accelerated northeastward along the East Coast of the United States, delivering another round of heavy rain with some strong thunderstorms to the Mid Atlantic States during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th. ||Doppler radar storm total estimates ranged from around 2 to 5 inches of rain for the event across New Jersey.  Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and flash flooding, which caused some smaller rivers across southern New Jersey to overflow their banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to flash flooding of smaller rivers and streams and along some roadways in northwestern Camden County. The Cooper River at Haddonfield was above its 2.8 foot flood stage from 807 p.m. EDT on the 7th through 507 a.m. EDT on the 8th. It crested at 3.12 feet at 1100 p.m. EDT on the 7th. Event precipitation totals included 4.02 inches in Collingswood, 3.96 inches in Morris, 3.78 inches in Somerdale, 3.34 inches in Lindenwold, and 3.09 inches in Merchantville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Andrea moving up the Eastern Seaboard, from the Southeast States to the Mid Atlantic and Northeast Coasts, led to waves of heavy rain and thunderstorms from the early morning hours through the late evening on the 7th. The initial burst of heavy precipitation arrived during the early morning on the 7th as moisture surged into the Mid Atlantic Region ahead of Tropical Storm Andrea, with the center of its low pressure located near the coast of Georgia. Through the course of the day, the cyclone became post-tropical as it accelerated northeastward along the East Coast of the United States, delivering another round of heavy rain with some strong thunderstorms to the Mid Atlantic States during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th. ||Doppler radar storm total estimates ranged from around 2 to 5 inches of rain for the event across New Jersey.  Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and flash flooding, which caused some smaller rivers across southern New Jersey to overflow their banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to flash flooding of smaller rivers and streams and along some roadways in northwestern Cumberland County. The Cohansey River at Seeley was above its 6 foot flood stage from 1224 a.m. EDT through 145 p.m. EDT on the 8th, and it crested at 6.55 feet at 500 a.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 4.25 inches in Lawrence Township, 4.10 inches in Bridgeton, 4.05 inches in Seabrook Farms, and 3.95 inches in Upper Deerfield Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of showers and thunderstorms withe heavy rain caused flash flooding in the northwest part of the state during the morning of the 1st. While additional showers and thunderstorms occurred during the afternoon, they were not as heavy. Doppler Radar storm total estimates ranged from 1.5 to 4.5 inches in Somerset, Hunterdon, Warren, Morris and Sussex Counties. The heaviest rain fell in Warren County along the Delaware River. The nearly stationary frontal boundary that has been responsible for heavy rain started to retrograde westward as a Bermuda High pressure system moved west from the Atlantic Ocean.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding as well as field flooding in the northwest part of Somerset County centered in and around Bridgewater, Branchburg, Bedminster and Bernards Townships. The North Branch area was flooded in Branchburg Township. Burnt Mills Road was flooded and closed as was New Jersey State Route 28 (Easton Turnpike) at the North Branch Bridge. In Bridgewater Township, flooding along U.S. Route 22 blocked the eastbound entrance to Interstate 287. A few flooded roadways had rapidly moving water passing over them in Bernards Township. This included left lane flooding on Interstate 287 that necessitated a closure.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around three inches in the township and street flooding was reported. Event precipitation totals included 2.34 inches in Bernards Township and 2.29 inches in Basking Ridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676. Westbound delays on the Atlantic City Expressway reached two hours.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding mainly in the northeast part of Hunterdon County. Event precipitation totals included 3.18 inches in Readington Township, 2.51 inches in Lebanon, 2.10 inches in Flemington and 2.09 inches in Frenchtown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of showers and thunderstorms withe heavy rain caused flash flooding in the northwest part of the state during the morning of the 1st. While additional showers and thunderstorms occurred during the afternoon, they were not as heavy. Doppler Radar storm total estimates ranged from 1.5 to 4.5 inches in Somerset, Hunterdon, Warren, Morris and Sussex Counties. The heaviest rain fell in Warren County along the Delaware River. The nearly stationary frontal boundary that has been responsible for heavy rain started to retrograde westward as a Bermuda High pressure system moved west from the Atlantic Ocean.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in northwest Warren County in Knowlton, Pahaquarry, and Hardwick Townships and affected the Worthington State Forest area the hardest.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates nearly reached 5 inches in the northwest part of the county. Event precipitation totals included 2.90 inches in Hope and 1.94 inches in Pequest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676. Westbound delays on the Atlantic City Expressway reached two hours.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding along the western tier of Gloucester County. In Paulsboro, numerous roads were flooded and closed. Some homes were flooded near the Mantua Creek. In Greenwich Township, one motorist had to be rescued from flood waters. A sewer main breakage exacerbated the ongoing flooding. Field flash flooding damaged tomato crops in the county. Event precipitation totals included 4.55 inches in East Greenwich Township, 4.25 inches in Mickleton, 4.15 inches in Westville, 3.78 inches in West Deptford, 3.77 inches in Mullica Hill, 2.75 inches in Woolwich Township, 2.30 inches in Wenonah and 1.91 inches in South Harrison Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front coupled with a deep southerly flow of very moist air caused slow moving and in some instances back building thunderstorms to occur during the afternoon and evening of the 28th. This caused an all-time record breaking rainfall in nearby Philadelphia as well as flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey and parts of the Passaic and Raritan Basins in northern New Jersey.  The flash flooding in the Philadelphia suburbs (Camden County in particular) led to people being stuck on roadways for hours on the 42 Freeway as well as Interstates 295, 76 and 676. Westbound delays on the Atlantic City Expressway reached two hours.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates and or actual measurements reached around 4 inches in parts of northern New Jersey and 4 to 8 inches in parts of southwest New Jersey with the heaviest rain right along the Delaware River. The daily rainfall measurement of 8.02 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport was not only the all-time calendar day record but was estimated to be a one in thousand year event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A second wave of thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in southeastern Camden County. Event precipitation totals included 3.22 inches in Winslow Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of showers and thunderstorms withe heavy rain caused flash flooding in the northwest part of the state during the morning of the 1st. While additional showers and thunderstorms occurred during the afternoon, they were not as heavy. Doppler Radar storm total estimates ranged from 1.5 to 4.5 inches in Somerset, Hunterdon, Warren, Morris and Sussex Counties. The heaviest rain fell in Warren County along the Delaware River. The nearly stationary frontal boundary that has been responsible for heavy rain started to retrograde westward as a Bermuda High pressure system moved west from the Atlantic Ocean.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in central Hunterdon County from Kingwood and Alexandria Townships northeastward through Readington and Tewksbury Townships. U.S. Route 22 in Readington Township was flooded in both directions as was Interstate 78 in Clinton Township. In Readington Township, the approach to the Rockefellow Mills Bridge over the South Branch of the Raritan River was flooded. Flooding was reported along the South Branch of the Rockaway Creek in Whitehouse Station, the Neshanic River at Reaville (crested at 6.94 feet), the South Branch of the Raritan River near Stanton and the Mulhockaway Creek in Clinton. The Beaver Brook flooded into the parking lot of the municipal building in Clinton.  Widespread street flooding was reported in Kingwood Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 3 inches in this band and actual storm totals included 2.50 inches in Readington Township, 2.41 inches in Franklin Township, 2.40 inches in Lebanon Township, 2.34 inches in Frenchtown, 2.08 inches in Stockton, 1.95 inches in Pittstown and 1.71 inches in Kingwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a slowly moving cold front with a wave of low pressure along it and wet antecedent conditions helped develop a large area of light to moderate rain with embedded thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain in New Jersey primarily during the afternoon of the 18th. This led to urban and poor drainage flooding and also flash flooding near and along some of the smaller creeks and rivers in the state. Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 3 inches in the southern half of the state and in sections of Morris County in the northern part of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in Parsippany-Troy Hills Township. U.S. Route 46 was closed in both directions between Baldwin and South Beverwyck Roads. Homes and businesses in the area suffered damage to their plumbing systems caused by the flooding rains. Event precipitation totals included 1.87 inches within the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving thunderstorm developed over the town of Pompton Lakes producing very heavy rainfall and resulted in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dawes Highway was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms accompanying a warm front caused very heavy rain during the late afternoon and early evening on the 27th. This caused flooding in central New Jersey that lasted overnight. Doppler Radar storm total estimates as well as Skywarn Spotter and mesonet reports reached 2 to 3 inches in the hardest hit parts of Mercer and Somerset Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding and flash flooding of smaller creeks in the northwest half of Mercer County from Ewing Township northeast through Hopewell and Princeton Townships. In Pennington Borough, West Delaware Avenue and New Jersey State Route 31 were flooded. Yards and driveways were also flooded in Pennington and also in Lawrence Township.  Event precipitation totals included 3.31 inches in Lawrence Township, 3.22 inches in Pennington Borough, 2.97 inches in Ewing Township, 2.50 inches in Trenton and 2.36 inches at the Mercer County Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms accompanying a warm front caused very heavy rain during the late afternoon and early evening on the 27th. This caused flooding in central New Jersey that lasted overnight. Doppler Radar storm total estimates as well as Skywarn Spotter and mesonet reports reached 2 to 3 inches in the hardest hit parts of Mercer and Somerset Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flooding and flash flooding of smaller creeks in the western half of Somerset County during the evening of the 27th and affected Branchburg, Hillsborough and Montgomery Townships the most.  In Branchburg Township,  the Chambers Brook flooded.  In Bedmister Township, the Middle Brook also flooded. Event precipitation totals included 3.20 inches in Neshanic, 2.71 inches in Bridgewater Township, 2.45 inches in Hillsborough Township,  2.44 inches in Somerville and 2.12 inches in Montgomery Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a slowly moving cold front with a wave of low pressure along it and wet antecedent conditions helped develop a large area of light to moderate rain with embedded thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain in New Jersey primarily during the afternoon of the 18th. This led to urban and poor drainage flooding and also flash flooding near and along some of the smaller creeks and rivers in the state. Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 3 inches in the southern half of the state and in sections of Morris County in the northern part of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in the Little Timber Creek drainage basin in and around Bellmawr. The flooding also affected Interstate 295 at exit 26. Doppler Radar storm total estimates were around 2.5 inches in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a slowly moving cold front with a wave of low pressure along it and wet antecedent conditions helped develop a large area of light to moderate rain with embedded thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain in New Jersey primarily during the afternoon of the 18th. This led to urban and poor drainage flooding and also flash flooding near and along some of the smaller creeks and rivers in the state. Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 3 inches in the southern half of the state and in sections of Morris County in the northern part of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding in central Gloucester County.  Event precipitation totals included 2.78 inches in Elk Township, 2.76 inches in Clayton, 2.61 inches in Pitman, 2.54 inches in Glassboro and 2.14 inches in Monroe Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a slowly moving cold front with a wave of low pressure along it and wet antecedent conditions helped develop a large area of light to moderate rain with embedded thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain in New Jersey primarily during the afternoon of the 18th. This led to urban and poor drainage flooding and also flash flooding near and along some of the smaller creeks and rivers in the state. Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 3 inches in the southern half of the state and in sections of Morris County in the northern part of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding in Atlantic City. Several roadways were flooded. Event precipitation totals included 2.16 inches within the city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey during the afternoon of the 30th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two to three inches from Evesham Township through sections of Camden, Gloucester and Salem Counties.  Extremely wet antecedent conditions made it easier for flash flooding to occur. On  a statewide average, June 2013 was the wettest June on record dating back to 1895. The statewide average total of 9.55 inches was 5.55 inches wetter than average. On a county weighted average,  June rainfall totals ranged from 7.7 inches in Cape May County to 11.9 inches in Camden and Gloucester Counties. In Atlantic City, it was the third wettest June on record (7.53 inches). The June precipitation total in Trenton was 10.16 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding along numerous roadways and smaller creeks in and around Atco in Waterford Township. The White Horse Pike (U.S. Route 30) and many yards were also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Andrea moving up the Eastern Seaboard, from the Southeast States to the Mid Atlantic and Northeast Coasts, led to waves of heavy rain and thunderstorms from the early morning hours through the late evening on the 7th. The initial burst of heavy precipitation arrived during the early morning on the 7th as moisture surged into the Mid Atlantic Region ahead of Tropical Storm Andrea, with the center of its low pressure located near the coast of Georgia. Through the course of the day, the cyclone became post-tropical as it accelerated northeastward along the East Coast of the United States, delivering another round of heavy rain with some strong thunderstorms to the Mid Atlantic States during the late afternoon and evening of the 7th. ||Doppler radar storm total estimates ranged from around 2 to 5 inches of rain for the event across New Jersey.  Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and flash flooding, which caused some smaller rivers across southern New Jersey to overflow their banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to flash flooding along some roadways and along smaller creeks and streams in Gloucester County. The Raccoon Creek at Swedesboro was above its 13 foot flood stage from 407 a.m. EDT through 1007 a.m. EDT on the 8th, and it crested at 13.15 feet at 730 a.m. EDT. Two downed trees were also reported in Gloucester County due to the combination of heavy rainfall and saturated grounds. Event precipitation totals included 4.45 inches in Glassboro, 4.22 inches in Woodbury, 4.15 inches in West Deptford Township, 3.98 inches in Sewell, 3.38 inches in Pitman, and 3.14 inches in Malaga.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a slowly moving cold front with a wave of low pressure along it and wet antecedent conditions helped develop a large area of light to moderate rain with embedded thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain in New Jersey primarily during the afternoon of the 18th. This led to urban and poor drainage flooding and also flash flooding near and along some of the smaller creeks and rivers in the state. Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 3 inches in the southern half of the state and in sections of Morris County in the northern part of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in Winslow Township. The flooding also affected the White Horse Pike (U.S. Route 30). Event precipitation totals included 2.21 inches within the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front moved towards the area, showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall, which resulted in isolated flash flooding in Union County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local fire department rescused a vehicle stuck in flood waters at Route 1 and Maple Ave. in Elizabeth.

Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 3 inches in the southern half of the state and in sections of Morris County in the northern part of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in Toms River Township.  The flooding also affected the eastbound lanes of New Jersey State Route 37. Event precipitation totals included 3.48 inches in Berkeley Township and 2.57 inches in Toms River Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Southampton and Pemberton Township borders. The flooding also affected New Jersey State Routes 70 and 72.  Event precipitation totals included 3.07 inches in Tabernacle Township, 2.15 inches in Pemberton Township and 1.98 inches in Oswego Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms with heavy downpours ultimately caused flash flooding in eastern Morris County. Event precipitation totals averaged two to three inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in the eastern part of Morris County. A few roadways were covered with water and the East Ditch overflowed its banks. Elsewhere in Morris County, some poor drainage flooding occurred. Event precipitation totals included 2.91 inches in Parsippany, 2.75 inches in Randolph,  2.63 inches in Roxbury,  2.62 inches in Denville, 2.58 inches in Boonton and 2.46 inches in Hanover Township.

Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two to three inches from Evesham Township through sections of Camden, Gloucester and Salem Counties.  Extremely wet antecedent conditions made it easier for flash flooding to occur. On  a statewide average, June 2013 was the wettest June on record dating back to 1895. The statewide average total of 9.55 inches was 5.55 inches wetter than average. On a county weighted average,  June rainfall totals ranged from 7.7 inches in Cape May County to 11.9 inches in Camden and Gloucester Counties. In Atlantic City, it was the third wettest June on record (7.53 inches). The June precipitation total in Trenton was 10.16 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding along roadways and small creeks in Glassboro. Roadway flooding included East High Street (U.S. Route 322).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey during the afternoon of the 30th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two to three inches from Evesham Township through sections of Camden, Gloucester and Salem Counties.  Extremely wet antecedent conditions made it easier for flash flooding to occur. On  a statewide average, June 2013 was the wettest June on record dating back to 1895. The statewide average total of 9.55 inches was 5.55 inches wetter than average. On a county weighted average,  June rainfall totals ranged from 7.7 inches in Cape May County to 11.9 inches in Camden and Gloucester Counties. In Atlantic City, it was the third wettest June on record (7.53 inches). The June precipitation total in Trenton was 10.16 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding along numerous roadways and smaller creeks in and around Woodstown and Pilesgrove Township in Salem County.  Event precipitation totals included 3.27 inches within Woodstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey during the afternoon of the 30th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two to three inches from Evesham Township through sections of Camden, Gloucester and Salem Counties.  Extremely wet antecedent conditions made it easier for flash flooding to occur. On  a statewide average, June 2013 was the wettest June on record dating back to 1895.
