On a county weighted average,  June rainfall totals ranged from 7.7 inches in Cape May County to 11.9 inches in Camden and Gloucester Counties. In Atlantic City, it was the third wettest June on record (7.53 inches). The June precipitation total in Trenton was 10.16 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding along roadways and small creeks near Mullica Hill in Harrison Township. Roadway flooding included the intersection of Walters Road and U.S. Route 322. The flooding also spread to the Raccoon Creek within Harrison Township. Event precipitation totals included 2.59 inches in Mullica Hill, 2.50 inches in Woolwich Township and 2.01 inches in South Harrison Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary front helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in southwestern New Jersey during the afternoon of the 30th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached two to three inches from Evesham Township through sections of Camden, Gloucester and Salem Counties.  Extremely wet antecedent conditions made it easier for flash flooding to occur. On  a statewide average, June 2013 was the wettest June on record dating back to 1895. The statewide average total of 9.55 inches was 5.55 inches wetter than average. On a county weighted average,  June rainfall totals ranged from 7.7 inches in Cape May County to 11.9 inches in Camden and Gloucester Counties. In Atlantic City, it was the third wettest June on record (7.53 inches). The June precipitation total in Trenton was 10.16 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding along roadways and smaller creeks in the southern part of Evesham Township.  Event precipitation totals included 2.10 inches in nearby Medford Lakes and 1.80 inches in Medford Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front encountered a highly unstable airmass as it approached from the west, which resulted in a line of showers and thunderstorms during the evening hours. High precipitable water levels preceding the front resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Ridgewood, the intersection of Sollas Ct. and Linwood Ave. was closed due to flooding.  Water rescues were also performed at the intersection of Hope St. and Spring Avenue. Washington Ave. was closed in both directions at Grant Ave. in Dumont due to flooding.  There were several stranded cars with water rescues performed at the intersection of Washington Ave. and River Dr. in Elmwood Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front encountered a highly unstable airmass as it approached from the west, which resulted in a line of showers and thunderstorms during the evening hours. High precipitable water levels preceding the front resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Paramus, Rt. 17 northbound between Carlough Dr. and Ridgewood Ave. were closed due to flooding.  Water rescues were performed at the intersection of Rodney St. and Waldron Ave. in Glen Rock.  In Saddle Brook, Pehle Ave. and New Pehle Ave. and N. 5th St. between Grace Ave. and Victor St. were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof in combination with an upper air disturbance triggered clusters of showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours over sections of central and southern New Jersey during the late morning into the early afternoon on the 2nd. This caused urban, poor drainage and small creek flash flooding. Some creek and river flooding persisted into the night in Gloucester and Camden Counties.  Event precipitation totals reached between 2.0 and 4.0 inches in parts of Camden, Gloucester and Hunterdon Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused creek and poor drainage flooding in central Gloucester County, affecting Glassboro Borough and Elk, Harrison and South Harrison Townships the most. In Glassboro,  significant roadway flooding was reported. At Rowan University, several parking lots quickly flooded and roadways leading into and through the university were also flooded. Event precipitation totals included 4.30 inches in Glassboro, 2.78 inches in Malaga, 2.58 inches in Franklin Township and 2.01 inches in Sewell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof in combination with an upper air disturbance triggered clusters of showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours over sections of central and southern New Jersey during the late morning into the early afternoon on the 2nd. This caused urban, poor drainage and small creek flash flooding. Some creek and river flooding persisted into the night in Gloucester and Camden Counties.  Event precipitation totals reached between 2.0 and 4.0 inches in parts of Camden, Gloucester and Hunterdon Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused creek and poor drainage flooding in west central Hunterdon County centered in and around Alexandria, Franklin, Holland and Union Townships.  Event precipitation totals included 3.22 inches in Pittstown, 2.58 inches in Franklin Township and 2.38 inches in Spruce Run.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof in combination with an upper air disturbance triggered clusters of showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours over sections of central and southern New Jersey during the late morning into the early afternoon on the 2nd. This caused urban, poor drainage and small creek flash flooding. Some creek and river flooding persisted into the night in Gloucester and Camden Counties.  Event precipitation totals reached between 2.0 and 4.0 inches in parts of Camden, Gloucester and Hunterdon Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused creek and poor drainage flooding in west central Camden County in and around Somerdale Borough and Gloucester Township. In Somerdale, significant street flooding was reported with several vehicles stuck in flood waters.  Event precipitation totals included 4.26 inches in Stratford, 4.10 inches in Clementon, 4.09 inches in Gloucester Township, 4.00 inches in Glendora and 3.50 inches in Blenheim.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof in combination with an upper air disturbance triggered clusters of showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours over sections of central and southern New Jersey during the late morning into the early afternoon on the 2nd. This caused urban, poor drainage and small creek flash flooding. Some creek and river flooding persisted into the night in Gloucester and Camden Counties.  Event precipitation totals reached between 2.0 and 4.0 inches in parts of Camden, Gloucester and Hunterdon Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused creek and poor drainage flooding in east central Camden County centered in and around Voorhees Township. Flooding along the Millard Creek and Kirkwood Lake reached some properties. Roadway flash flooding also occurred and some vehicles were trapped in flood waters. Event precipitation totals included 4.26 inches in Stratford, 4.10 inches in Clementon, 4.09 inches in Gloucester Township, 4.00 inches in Glendora and 3.50 inches in Blenheim.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a mid level shortwave trough moving through the Northeast and a weak surface trough of low pressure in the region triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms across the tri-state area.  Winds aloft were weak and resulted in slow moving storms, which produced heavy downpours and caused flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Franklin Ave. at S. Broad St. in Ridgewood and the intersection of Cornwall Rd. and Prospect St. were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Training thunderstorms (thunderstorms moving over the same areas) caused flash flooding in Hunterdon County on the morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Repeating thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in western Hunterdon County in Alexandria, Holland and Union Townships. Flash flooding inundated Sweet Hollow Road in Alexandria Township, one of several roads impacted in the township. Several roads were also flooded in Holland Township and included Rummel Road. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached around 3 inches along the heaviest rain axis in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front encountered a highly unstable airmass as it approached from the west, which resulted in a line of showers and thunderstorms during the evening hours. High precipitable water levels preceding the front resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Franklin Ave. and Catherine Ave. in Saddle Brook were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front encountered a highly unstable airmass as it approached from the west, which resulted in a line of showers and thunderstorms during the evening hours. High precipitable water levels preceding the front resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rt. 4 was closed with cars stranded in high water in Fair Lawn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front encountered a highly unstable airmass as it approached from the west, which resulted in a line of showers and thunderstorms during the evening hours. High precipitable water levels preceding the front resulted in heavy rain and flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rt. 17 was closed between Ridgewood Ave. and Linwood Ave. due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trof helped trigger showers and thunderstorms with torrential downpours during the morning of the 9th in northwestern New Jersey. Event totals reached 2 to 6 inches in western portions of Warren and particularly Sussex County and caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding.  The runoff from the heavy rain caused the Delaware River water levels to be higher than average. The next day (the 10th) a 30-year-old man drowned in the river while tubing with about 10 other people off of Kingwood in Hunterdon County. They were tubing across the river toward Tinicum in Bucks County when he went into the river. Investigators say he was about fifteen feet from the shoreline when he fell off the tube and went missing. Divers searching for the body over the next week were hampered by the high water levels and poor visibilities and additional heavy rain. His body was apparently found on August 31st on a small island in the Delaware River. Lower Makefield (Bucks County) police were called to a report of a body on an island one mile north of the Calhoun Street Bridge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage as well as small stream flash flooding in the western part of Sussex County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2.5 inches from Stillwater and Walpack Townships northeastward through Montague and Wantage Townships. Storm total estimates exceeded 5 inches in Sandyston Township. The Papakating Creek at Pellettown started exceeding its 4 foot flood stage at 737 a.m. EDT. Event precipitation totals included 4.81 inches at High Point, 4.09 inches in Montague, 2.85 inches in Wantage and 2.66 inches in Flatbrookville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in central and southwest New Jersey on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 5.0 inches. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected the Raccoon Creek in Gloucester County, the Cooper River in Camden County and the Great Egg River in Atlantic County. The flooding caused the suspension of Amtrak Northeast Corridor train service and sixty minute delays on the North Jersey Coastal Commuter Rail Service on the 13th. There was system-wide cross honoring of commuter tickets. Sections of major roadways that were flooded and closed included Interstate 76 and New Jersey State Routes 35, 42 and 55. Numerous vehicles were trapped in flood waters and rescues were performed. But, no serious injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of many roadways and streams in Salem County on the morning of the 13th.  Many roadways were closed and these included Broadway in Salem City and U.S. Route 40 in Pilesgrove and Pennsville Townships. A motorist was rescued from the U.S. Route 40 extension in Pennsville. Pittsgrove Township expected runoff problems to affect the municipality into the 14th.  Event precipitation totals included 3.75 inches in Upper Pittsgrove and 3.17 inches in Woodstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in central and southwest New Jersey on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 5.0 inches. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected the Raccoon Creek in Gloucester County, the Cooper River in Camden County and the Great Egg River in Atlantic County. The flooding caused the suspension of Amtrak Northeast Corridor train service and sixty minute delays on the North Jersey Coastal Commuter Rail Service on the 13th. There was system-wide cross honoring of commuter tickets. Sections of major roadways that were flooded and closed included Interstate 76 and New Jersey State Routes 35, 42 and 55. Numerous vehicles were trapped in flood waters and rescues were performed. But, no serious injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of numerous roadways and creeks, especially in central and western Gloucester County.  Vehicles became trapped in flood waters and rescues were performed. Roadway closures included New Jersey State Route 55 and Delsea Drive in Deptford, Kings Highway in Woodbury, New Jersey State Route 44 in Paulsboro, Kings Highway in West Deptford, Main Street in Glassboro and New Jersey State Route 42 in Monroe Township. The Mantua Creek at Pitman was above its 5 foot flood stage from 1050 a..m. EDT through 338 p.m. EDT on the 13th. It crested at 5.80 feet at 1215 p.m. EDT.  The Raccoon Creek also flooded and crested at 14.69 feet at 2 p.m. EDT on the 13th. Event precipitation totals included 4.50 inches in Washington Township, 4.28 inches in Monroe Township, 4.14 inches in Clayton, 3.80 inches in Glassboro and 3.19 inches in Pitman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak short wave trough moving through the upper flow triggered slow moving heavy showers and thunderstorms that resulted in flash flooding in Bergen, Essex and Union Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Elizabeth River at Ursino Lake in Elizabeth exceeded its flood stage of 20.0 ft at 1300 EST, crested at 20.92 ft. at 1430 EST and fell back within its banks at 1530 EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak short wave trough moving through the upper flow triggered slow moving heavy showers and thunderstorms that resulted in flash flooding in Bergen, Essex and Union Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The southbound lanes of the Garden State Pkwy. between exits 153A (Rt.3) and 149 (Rt. 506) were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak short wave trough moving through the upper flow triggered slow moving heavy showers and thunderstorms that resulted in flash flooding in Bergen, Essex and Union Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Elizabeth, Grove St. was closed due to flooding.  In addition, vehicles were stuck in flood waters on Rt. 22 between Spring St. and Bloy St. in Hillside.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak short wave trough moving through the upper flow triggered slow moving heavy showers and thunderstorms that resulted in flash flooding in Bergen, Essex and Union Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local responders rescued a motorist trapped in flood waters at the intersection of Central Ave. and Mozart St. in E. Rutherford and also on Wysocki Place in Hackensack. Additionally, Rt. 17 southbound was closed in Hasbrouck Heights due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof preceding a cold front (that moved through overnight on thee 22nd) helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain across the central third of New Jersey from the morning into the middle of the afternoon on the 22nd.  Event precipitation totals reached 1.5 to 3.5 inches across sections of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris and Somerset Counties and even reached close to 6.0 inches in far northwest Somerset County which had the greatest impact. The heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams, roadways and rivers and also led to flooding along the North Branch of the Raritan River that persisted into the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and streams in northwestern Somerset County and hit Bedminister, Peapack-Gladstone and Bernardsville the hardest. The flash flooding affected New Jersey Commuter Rail Service. Eastbound commuter rail service along the Morris and Essex Line was suspended for the day after flash flooding caused four to six washouts of stone supports along the Gladstone Branch tracks. Westbound service continued, but delays averaged 45 minutes.  Substitute eastbound bus service was provided. About ten people in Peapack-Gladstone self evacuated to the Municipal Building. The runoff from the heavy rain and also caused flooding along the Lamington River and Middle Brook.  Event precipitation totals included 5.85 inches in Peapack-Gladstone, 5.14 inches in Pottersville, 4.94 inches in Far Hills and 3.99 inches in Middlebush.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof preceding a cold front (that moved through overnight on thee 22nd) helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain across the central third of New Jersey from the morning into the middle of the afternoon on the 22nd.  Event precipitation totals reached 1.5 to 3.5 inches across sections of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris and Somerset Counties and even reached close to 6.0 inches in far northwest Somerset County which had the greatest impact. The heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams, roadways and rivers and also led to flooding along the North Branch of the Raritan River that persisted into the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams in southern Morris County in Chester, Mendham and Washington Townships.  Event precipitation totals included 2.00 inches in New Vernon, 1.76 inches in Washington Township,  1.59 inches in Chester Township and 1.53 inches in Mendham Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof preceding a cold front (that moved through overnight on thee 22nd) helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain across the central third of New Jersey from the morning into the middle of the afternoon on the 22nd.  Event precipitation totals reached 1.5 to 3.5 inches across sections of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris and Somerset Counties and even reached close to 6.0 inches in far northwest Somerset County which had the greatest impact. The heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams, roadways and rivers and also led to flooding along the North Branch of the Raritan River that persisted into the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams mainly in the northwestern and central sections of Mercer County.  The afternoon thunderstorms were most concentrated in Hopewell and Lawrence Townships. Roadway and creek flooding were reported in Hamilton, Princeton and Lawrence Townships.  Event precipitation totals included 2.62 inches in Hamilton Township, 2.23 inches in Pennington, 2.11 inches in Lawrence, 2.05 inches in Hopewell and 1.80 inches in Trenton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof preceding a cold front (that moved through overnight on thee 22nd) helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain across the central third of New Jersey from the morning into the middle of the afternoon on the 22nd.  Event precipitation totals reached 1.5 to 3.5 inches across sections of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris and Somerset Counties and even reached close to 6.0 inches in far northwest Somerset County which had the greatest impact. The heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams, roadways and rivers and also led to flooding along the North Branch of the Raritan River that persisted into the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams in northeastern Hunterdon County and affected Clinton, Tewksbury and Readington Townships the hardest.  In Tewksbury Township, a car became trapped in five feet of flood waters from the Lamington (Black) River on McCan Mill Road near the bridge at Black River Road. A front end loader was used to rescue the female driver. A vehicle was also stuck in flood waters on Rockaway Road. Flooding and road closures also occurred along U.S. Route 22 in Readington and Clinton Townships. Event precipitation totals included 3.15 inches in Lebanon Township, 3.06 inches in Califon and 1.62 inches in Clinton and Readington Townships.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof preceding a cold front (that moved through overnight on thee 22nd) helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain across the central third of New Jersey from the morning into the middle of the afternoon on the 22nd.  Event precipitation totals reached 1.5 to 3.5 inches across sections of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris and Somerset Counties and even reached close to 6.0 inches in far northwest Somerset County which had the greatest impact. The heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams, roadways and rivers and also led to flooding along the North Branch of the Raritan River that persisted into the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams again in Somerset County, this time in the southern part of the county. The heaviest rain from this cluster of thunderstorms fell in Hillsborough and Franklin Townships.  In Hillsborough Township, U.S. Route 206 and Brooks Boulevard were flooded and closed. In Franklin Township, How Lane and New Jersey State Route 27 were flooded and closed. Event precipitation totals included 3.52 inches in Hillsborough, 3.50 inches in Manville, 2.90 inches in Franklin and 1.88 inches in Montgomery Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in central and southwest New Jersey on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 5.0 inches. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected the Raccoon Creek in Gloucester County, the Cooper River in Camden County and the Great Egg River in Atlantic County. The flooding caused the suspension of Amtrak Northeast Corridor train service and sixty minute delays on the North Jersey Coastal Commuter Rail Service on the 13th. There was system-wide cross honoring of commuter tickets. Sections of major roadways that were flooded and closed included Interstate 76 and New Jersey State Routes 35, 42 and 55. Numerous vehicles were trapped in flood waters and rescues were performed. But, no serious injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of numerous roadways and creeks, especially in central and western Camden County. Many vehicles became trapped in flood waters. Flooding also occurred along the Cooper River. Flooding forced the closure of Interstate 76 in Gloucester City, New Jersey State Route 42 near Interstate 295 and New Jersey State Route 70 in Cherry Hill. In Lindenwold, one vehicle was totally submerged in flood waters on the South White Horse Pike. Event precipitation totals included 4.68 inches in Winslow Township, 3.80 inches in Berlin Township, 2.94 inches in Lindenwold and 2.01 inches in Camden.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lee side trof preceding a cold front (that moved through overnight on thee 22nd) helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms with heavy rain across the central third of New Jersey from the morning into the middle of the afternoon on the 22nd.  Event precipitation totals reached 1.5 to 3.5 inches across sections of Mercer, Middlesex, Morris and Somerset Counties and even reached close to 6.0 inches in far northwest Somerset County which had the greatest impact. The heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams, roadways and rivers and also led to flooding along the North Branch of the Raritan River that persisted into the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams in central and northern Middlesex County affecting North Brunswick and East Brunswick the hardest. In East Brunswick, numerous roadways were flooded (including New Jersey State Routes 18 and 27) and traffic was described as at a standstill. In New Brunswick, the basement of the Middlesex County Family Court was flooded and Family Court was closed for the rest of the day.  Joyce Kilmer Avenue, George Street, Johnson Drive and Livingston Avenue were all flooded. Buccleuch Park was closed. In Edison, New Jersey State Route 27 was flooded. Street flooding was also reported in Woodbridge. Event precipitation totals included 2.00 inches in Cranbury and 1.90 inches in New Brunswick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in central and southwest New Jersey on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 5.0 inches. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected the Raccoon Creek in Gloucester County, the Cooper River in Camden County and the Great Egg River in Atlantic County. The flooding caused the suspension of Amtrak Northeast Corridor train service and sixty minute delays on the North Jersey Coastal Commuter Rail Service on the 13th. There was system-wide cross honoring of commuter tickets. Sections of major roadways that were flooded and closed included Interstate 76 and New Jersey State Routes 35, 42 and 55. Numerous vehicles were trapped in flood waters and rescues were performed. But, no serious injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and creeks, especially across the central third of Burlington County. In Evesham Township, a school bus became stuck in flood waters on Erindale Drive. Thirty-one children were rescued. Also within the township, a motorist was rescued from flood waters on New Jersey State Route 70 near Cropwell Road. Flooded and closed roadways also included Marlton Parkway in Evesham and Hartford Road in Medford. The flooding also affected the primary election as voting booths had to be moved after flooding occurred at some polling places. Event precipitation totals included 2.64 inches in Medford Township, 2.53 inches in Southampton Township, 2.35 inches in Pemberton Township and 2.30 inches in Tabernacle Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in central and southwest New Jersey on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 5.0 inches. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected the Raccoon Creek in Gloucester County, the Cooper River in Camden County and the Great Egg River in Atlantic County. The flooding caused the suspension of Amtrak Northeast Corridor train service and sixty minute delays on the North Jersey Coastal Commuter Rail Service on the 13th. There was system-wide cross honoring of commuter tickets. Sections of major roadways that were flooded and closed included Interstate 76 and New Jersey State Routes 35, 42 and 55. Numerous vehicles were trapped in flood waters and rescues were performed. But, no serious injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding on Long Beach Island from Surf City south through Beach Haven. Some poor drainage flooding also occurred in Point Pleasant and Little Egg Harbor Township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 to 3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms produced both wind damage and flash flooding in central and southwest New Jersey on the 13th. Doppler Radar storm total estimates averaged 2.5 to 5.0 inches. In addition to widespread poor drainage flooding, flooding also affected the Raccoon Creek in Gloucester County, the Cooper River in Camden County and the Great Egg River in Atlantic County. The flooding caused the suspension of Amtrak Northeast Corridor train service and sixty minute delays on the North Jersey Coastal Commuter Rail Service on the 13th. There was system-wide cross honoring of commuter tickets. Sections of major roadways that were flooded and closed included Interstate 76 and New Jersey State Routes 35, 42 and 55. Numerous vehicles were trapped in flood waters and rescues were performed. But, no serious injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding of roadways and creeks, especially in the eastern half of Monmouth County.  Sections of New Jersey State Routes 35 and 71 were flooded and closed.  Roadway closures occurred in Ocean Township, Long Branch, Manasquan, Deal, Wall and Neptune. Several dozen vehicles became struck in flood waters. In Long Branch, a mother and her nine-month-old son were rescued from a vehicle on Long Branch Avenue. Three other roadways were flooded. In Ocean Township, secondary roadways took a big flooding hit. In Manasquan, basement flooding occurred along Marcellus Avenue. Event precipitation totals included 4.11 inches in Ocean Township, 2.85 inches in Fair Haven, 2.68 inches in Red Bank, 2.57 inches in Rumson and 2.16 inches in Long Branch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough over the eastern United States and a frontal boundary stationary to the south of Long Island were the triggers for shower and thunderstorm development across the region.  Some of these storms produced heavy rainfall, which resulted in flash flooding in Passaic County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 23 northbound was closed at High Crest Drive in Smiths Mills due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a slowly moving cold front with a wave of low pressure along it and wet antecedent conditions helped develop a large area of light to moderate rain with embedded thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain in New Jersey primarily during the afternoon of the 18th. This led to urban and poor drainage flooding and also flash flooding near and along some of the smaller creeks and rivers in the state. Event precipitation totals averaged 1 to 3 inches in the southern half of the state and in sections of Morris County in the northern part of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding in Surf City on Long Beach Island. Vehicles were disabled by the flood waters on Central and Barnegat Avenues and Long Beach Boulevard. Nearby event precipitation totals included 1.90 inches in Harvey Cedars and 1.88 inches in Seaside Heights.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a stalled frontal boundary, extending from the Pennsylvania/Maryland border eastward across southern New Jersey, and a series of upper level disturbances resulted in numerous slow-moving thunderstorms from the afternoon of the 22nd through the early morning of the 23rd. These thunderstorms produced torrential rain and some wind damage.||Storm total rainfall measurements ranged mainly between 2 and 7 inches across central to northern New Jersey.  Run-off from waves of heavy precipitation resulted in areas of poor drainage and roadway flooding, with some creeks and streams also overflowing their banks. In Jackson (Ocean County), rainfall totals of 5 inches were reported in an hour.||In addition, the combination of the heavy rain and higher than normal astronomical tides associated with the full moon, caused minor tidal flooding along the tidal Delaware River and upper Delaware Bay during the overnight high tide cycles on the 22nd and lingered into the early morning high tide cycle on the 23rd. In Philadelphia, the highest tide reached 8.76 feet above mean lower low water early on the 23rd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.  At Reedy Island (New Castle County), the highest tide reached 7.52 feet above mean lower low water late on the 22nd. Minor tidal flooding starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell through the night of the 22nd and caused urban and poor drainage flooding to occur during the early morning of the 23rd. The Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Camden was closed due to flooding with vehicles reported to be stuck in high waters. Route 130 in Pennsauken near Browning Road was closed due to significant flooding. Event precipitation totals included 1.97 inches in Merchantville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough over the eastern United States and a frontal boundary stationary to the south of Long Island were the triggers for shower and thunderstorm development across the region.  Some of these storms produced heavy rainfall, which resulted in flash flooding in Passaic County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 46 was closed in both directions east of Piaget Ave. in Clifton. due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In addition to hail, thunderstorms produced heavy downpours in parts of Ocean and Monmouth Counties and caused flash flooding in Brick Township. Event precipitation totals reached as high as around 2 inches, most of which fell within an hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flash flooding within Brick Township. Motor vehicles were stuck in flood waters on Princeton Avenue and several motorists had to be rescued. Event precipitation totals included 2.34 inches in Brick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary focused slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain in southwestern New Jersey during the late afternoon and early evening of the 10th. This caused poor drainage flash flooding as well as flash flooding of some smaller creeks. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 to 4 inches in sections of Salem and Gloucester Counties and nearly 2 inches in Camden County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of the Scotland Run and the closure of U.S. Route 322 at Fries Mill Road in Williamstown (Monroe Township). Event precipitation totals 2.69 in the township, most of which fell within an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a line of severe thunderstorms that produced heavy rain and resulted in flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 208 on the border of Wyckoff and Midland Park was closed in both directions due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a line of severe thunderstorms that produced heavy rain and resulted in flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 10 was closed between Hillside Ave. and Livingston Ave. in Livingston due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered a line of severe thunderstorms that produced heavy rain and resulted in flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dawes Highway in Pompton Lakes was impassable and closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain and moist antecedent conditions caused isolated flash flooding in northern New Jersey during the evening of the 3rd. Event precipitation totals reached between 2 and 4 inches in Somerset County as well as parts of western Sussex and eastern Morris Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of roadways and smaller streams in central Somerset County. The flash flooding resulted in a rescue of a stranded motorist on Somerset Street in Somerville. Event precipitation totals included 2.35 inches in Montgomery Township and 1.72 inches in Hillsborough Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along the barrier islands of Cape May County starting on the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in Ocean City.  Water was reported as high as three feet on some roadways with flooding up to the entrance of some homes and businesses. Event precipitation totals included 4.48 inches at Beesley's Point, 3.65 inches in Woodbine, 2.44 inches in Upper Township and 2.32 inches in Dennis Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short wave trough, embedded in a deep, broad mid-level trough, passed through the northeast triggering afternoon showers and thunderstorms.  A weak steering flow caused slow moving, training storms with heavy rain which resulted in flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 17 in Waldwick was impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short wave trough, embedded in a deep, broad mid-level trough, passed through the northeast triggering afternoon showers and thunderstorms.  A weak steering flow caused slow moving, training storms with heavy rain which resulted in flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles were trapped in high water with water rescues performed by local authorities at the intersection of West Crescent Ave. and Myrtle Ave. in Allendale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass preceding a cold front helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused poor drainage and creek flash flooding in central New Jersey during the evening of the 2nd. Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to 3 inches, most of which fell in around one hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding along New Jersey State Route 12 in Kingwood Township around where it crosses the Lockatong Creek. Event precipitation totals included 2.64 inches in Kingwood Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass preceding a cold front helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused poor drainage and creek flash flooding in central New Jersey during the evening of the 2nd. Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to 3 inches, most of which fell in around one hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain also caused flash flooding along Reaville Road in Flemington along tributaries to the Neshanic River. One vehicle was stuck in flood waters. Event precipitation totals included 1.51 inches in Flemington, most of which fell within an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of weak low pressure around the Northern Great Lakes and an upper level disturbance passing over portions of northern New Jersey produced scattered strong thunderstorms with heavy rainfall that resulted in areas of flash flooding and poor drainage flooding from the late evening of the 21st into the early morning of the 22nd.  Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to around 4 inches across portions of northern New Jersey, especially through Warren and Somerset Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused small stream and poor drainage flash flooding in northern Somerset County mainly in Bernards, Bridgewater and Warren Townships. An intersection in Somerville was closed due to flooding. Event precipitation totals included 2.96 inches in Bridgewater Township and 2.30 inches in Bedminster Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short wave trough, embedded in a deep, broad mid-level trough, passed through the northeast triggering afternoon showers and thunderstorms.  A weak steering flow caused slow moving, training storms with heavy rain which resulted in flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Linwood Ave. was closed between Maple Ave. and Fairfield Ave. in Ridgewood due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass preceding a cold front helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused poor drainage and creek flash flooding in central New Jersey during the evening of the 2nd. Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to 3 inches, most of which fell in around one hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding in Perth Amboy with significant flooding reported along New Brunswick Avenue (County Route 616). Event precipitation totals included 2.03 inches in Woodbridge Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass preceding a cold front helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused poor drainage and creek flash flooding in central New Jersey during the evening of the 2nd. Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to 3 inches, most of which fell in around one hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding in Sayreville and South Amboy. Multiple high water rescues were performed around the intersections of U.S. Route 9, New Jersey State Route 35 and New Jersey State Route 444. Event precipitation totals included 2.03 inches in Woodbridge Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable airmass triggered showers and thunderstorms on multiple surface boundaries, with some of the thunderstorms becoming severe. Several rounds of storms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maple Ave. was closed just west of Rock Rd. in Glen Rock due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable airmass triggered showers and thunderstorms on multiple surface boundaries, with some of the thunderstorms becoming severe. Several rounds of storms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: River St. in Paterson was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very moist and unstable airmass triggered showers and thunderstorms on multiple surface boundaries, with some of the thunderstorms becoming severe. Several rounds of storms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Saddle River Rd. and Ackerman Ave. as well as 5th St. in Saddle Brook were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall which resulted in isolated flash flooding in Essex County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple motorists were rescued from flood waters in Newark.  A woman and her five children as well as two other adults were rescued at the Meeker Ave. underpass.  Flood waters were even higher at the Freilinghuysen Ave. underpass and closed to traffic.  Another woman was also rescued from flood waters at the intersection of Hawkins St. and Ferry Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very humid air mass combined with a passing surface trough to trigger numerous showers and thunderstorms, with embedded severe thunderstorms. Some of these storms produced very heavy rain which led to isolated flash flooding in Essex County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All exits in both directions on the Garden State Parkway in Newark, East Orange and Bloomfield were under water with a water rescue needed at the underpass at exit 147 southbound.  A water rescue was also needed on Hoffman Ave. in East Orange after a car became trapped in flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with additional heavy rain for the third consecutive day coupled with wet antecedent conditions to cause additional flash flooding across central and southern New Jersey on the 15th. Runoff flooding then persisted along parts of the Millstone River in Somerset County into the 17th. Dopper Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 4 inches in sections of Salem County northeast into parts of Monmouth and Ocean Counties. The thunderstorms were caused by a slow moving cold front that cleared the New Jersey coast around 7 a.m. EDT on the 16th. This put an end to a couple of days of thunderstorms with heavy downpours affecting the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused poor drainage, small creek and field flash flooding in Winslow Township. A few roadways were flooded.  Event precipitation totals included 3.89 inches in Ancora and 2.19 inches in Winslow Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass preceding a cold front helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused poor drainage and creek flash flooding in central New Jersey during the evening of the 2nd. Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to 3 inches, most of which fell in around one hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain also caused flash flooding along New Jersey State Route 12 in Raritan Township near the Plum Brook. One vehicle was trapped in the flood waters. Event precipitation totals included 2.64 inches in Kingwood Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving warm front and a low pressure system that formed along it that enhanced the convergence brought flash flooding rains to southeastern New Jersey during the evening and overnight on the 12th. Hardest hit was Cumberland County where rainfall amounts reached as high as nine inches. Some homes were damaged and one injury occurred. A series of thunderstorms with very heavy rain formed and moved along a very slowly northward moving warm frontal boundary. The rain did not end until an occluded front passed through New Jersey just before sunrise on the 13th. Numerous showers and thunderstorms started during the afternoon of the 12th and the heaviest rain fell during the evening. The rain ended during the early morning on the 13th. Event precipitation totals averaged 3 to 9 inches with the highest amounts in Atlantic and Cumberland Counties. Homeowners that were affected by the flooding became eligible for disaster loans through the United States Small Business Association.  ||In addition to the fresh water flooding, the onshore flow combined with unusually high spring tides associated with the full moon to produce the most widespread minor tidal flooding during the evening and overnight high tide cycle on the 12th. This extended up the Delaware Bay and Delaware River. Minor tidal flooding also occurred during the evening high tide cycles on the 9th through the 11th, but the crests were lower. Minor tidal flooding also occurred with the morning high tides at Sandy Hook (Monmouth County) on the mornings of the 12th and 13th.  The highest tides of the event occurred on the 12th and included 6.59 feet above mean lower low water in Atlantic City (Atlantic County), minor tidal flooding starts at 6.0 feet above mean lower low water;  7.26 feet above mean lower low water in Cape May (Cape May County), minor tidal flooding starts at 6.7 feet above mean lower low water and 7.27 feet above mean lower low water in Sandy Hook (Monmouth County), minor tidal flooding starts at 6.7 feet above mean lower low water. The tidal affected Watson Creek in Manasquan (Monmouth County) had minor flooding on the evening of the 12th also. It crested at 6.13 feet, minor flooding starts at 5.5 feet. Minor tidal flooding extended into the tidal sections of the Delaware River on the early morning of the 13th. On Reedy Island (New Castle County), the high tide reached 7.60 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water.  In Philadelphia, the high tide reached 8.44 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding within Vineland. Flooded roadways included New Jersey State Route 47. There were several vehicle rescues from flooded roadways. Event precipitation totals included 8.94 inches in Millville, 8.60 inches in Newport, 6.51 inches in Vineland, 5.43 inches in Fairfield Township, 4.62 inches in Upper Deerfield and 4.51 inches in Bridgeton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in Deal. Numerous roadways were flooded. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front slowly moved across the area, moisture from Tropical Cyclone Arthur passing to the south and east converged along the boundary resulting in severe thunderstorms, heavy rain and flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maple Ave. in Ridgewood was closed between Spring Ave. and Ridgewood Ave. due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused creek and poor drainage flash flooding in Millville. Hardest hit were homes along Rhonda Drive near the White Marsh Run. Three homes suffered collapsed basement walls. One woman was injured when the basement walls collapsed and she became trapped. The high water mark on some homes reached two feet above their ground level and evacuations occurred. Elsewhere in Millville, numerous vehicles were stranded along New Jersey State Route 47.||Event precipitation totals included 8.94 inches in Millville, 8.60 inches in Newport, 6.51 inches in Vineland, 5.43 inches in Fairfield Township, 4.62 inches in Upper Deerfield and 4.51 inches in Bridgeton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Rodgers Blvd. and Somerset St. in Harrison was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in parts of central New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of the 14th.  Runoff flooding occurred overnight in Ocean County. There were two corridors of very heavy rain: one from far western Burlington County northeast through eastern Middlesex and western Monmouth Counties and a second across northeast Ocean County and southeast Monmouth County. In the former Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the latter Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused widespread street flooding with several impassable roadways within the township.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 6 inches in the township and in nearby Howell (Monmouth County), 5.91 inches of rain fell.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in eastern Ocean County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 9 inches. In Stafford Township, several vehicles were stranded in high water on New Jersey State Route 72.  Also in the township, an oil tanker was stuck on a washed out section of New Jersey State Route 72 in the bridge construction area.  In Seaside Park, New Jersey State Route 35 was closed north of 5th Avenue. In Point Pleasant, many roadways were flooded, up to two feet deep. Flooding affected the New Jersey Transit Commuter Coast Line Depot in Bay Head. Crews could not access the trains. Buses honored train tickets along the line on the 13th.||Actual precipitation event totals included 8.35 inches in Lacey Township, 7.50 inches in Little Egg Harbor Township, 7.24 inches in Stafford Township, 6.55 inches in Lavallette, 6.02 inches in Point Pleasant, 5.87 inches in Brick Township, 5.43 inches in Berkeley Township,  4.59 inches in Seaside Heights, 4.39 inches in Toms River, 4.02 inches in Lakewood and 2.51 inches in Jackson Township.

Runoff flooding occurred overnight in Ocean County. There were two corridors of very heavy rain: one from far western Burlington County northeast through eastern Middlesex and western Monmouth Counties and a second across northeast Ocean County and southeast Monmouth County. In the former Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the latter Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage and small creek flash flooding in southeastern Monmouth County in Wall and Howell Townships. New Jersey State Route 35 was flooded in Wall Township between New Jersey State 138 and the Shark River Bridge. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 6 inches and 5.91 inches of rain was measured in Howell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in parts of central New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of the 14th. There were two corridors of very heavy rain: one from far western Burlington County northeast through eastern Middlesex and western Monmouth Counties and a second across northeast Ocean County and southeast Monmouth County. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused poor drainage flash flooding within Perth Amboy. Market Street, Maple Street, Fayette Street and New Brunswick Avenue were all flooded and closed. Residents were using kayaks and at least one vehicle was stranded in flood waters. The flash flooding forced the suspension of New Jersey Transit Service between Woodbridge and South Amboy. Event precipitation totals in Middlesex County included 3.13 inches in Matawan, 3.11 inches in New Brunswick, 2.98 inches in East Brunswick and 2.92 inches in Old Bridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of weak low pressure around the Northern Great Lakes and an upper level disturbance passing over portions of northern New Jersey produced scattered strong thunderstorms with heavy rainfall that resulted in areas of flash flooding and poor drainage flooding from the late evening of the 21st into the early morning of the 22nd.  Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to around 4 inches across portions of northern New Jersey, especially through Warren and Somerset Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding in southern Warren County. Road closures were reported in Phillipsburg (Route 22) and Washington (Route 31 and Highway 57). Entire event precipitation totals included 3.80 inches in Phillipsburg, 3.37 inches in Stewartsville, 1.93 inches in Riegelsville, 1.90 inches in Blairstown, 1.88 inches in Hackettstown, and  1.54 inches in Washington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours produced flash flooding in parts of central New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of the 14th.  Runoff flooding occurred overnight in Ocean County. There were two corridors of very heavy rain: one from far western Burlington County northeast through eastern Middlesex and western Monmouth Counties and a second across northeast Ocean County and southeast Monmouth County. In the former Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches, while in the latter Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached as high as 6 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused the closure of Interstate 295 in Bordentown Township near Blacks Creek.  Event precipitation total included 2.62 inches in Burlington Township.

Event precipitation totals in Middlesex County included 3.13 inches in Matawan, 3.11 inches in New Brunswick, 2.98 inches in East Brunswick and 2.92 inches in Old Bridge.

Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 2.5 and 3.0 inches in the area. Event precipitation totals included 2.62 inches in Burlington Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with additional heavy rain for the third consecutive day coupled with wet antecedent conditions to cause additional flash flooding across central and southern New Jersey on the 15th. Runoff flooding then persisted along parts of the Millstone River in Somerset County into the 17th. Dopper Radar storm total estimates reached between 2 and 4 inches in sections of Salem County northeast into parts of Monmouth and Ocean Counties. The thunderstorms were caused by a slow moving cold front that cleared the New Jersey coast around 7 a.m. EDT on the 16th. This put an end to a couple of days of thunderstorms with heavy downpours affecting the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused poor drainage flash flooding in southeastern Monmouth County from Wall and Howell Townships northeast through Long Branch.  In Howell Township, Blake Drive was flooded. Event precipitation totals included 4.55 inches in Belmar, 3.07 inches in Wall Township, 2.94 inches in South Howell, 2.52 inches in Howell, 2.09 inches in Brielle, 1.95 inches in West Belmar and 1.85 inches in Ocean Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low level shortwave swung through the Northeast with a trough at the surface. A line of strong thunderstorms formed along the trough and pushed through the area late in the afternoon into the evening. Some of these storms produced heavy rainfall, which resulted in flash flooding in portions of northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was stuck in flood waters on Dubois St. in East Rutherford.

Event precipitation totals included 3.62 in Millstone Township, 3.42 inches in Holmdel, 3.30 inches in Middletown and 3.13 inches in Matawan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain and moist antecedent conditions caused isolated flash flooding in northern New Jersey during the evening of the 3rd. Event precipitation totals reached between 2 and 4 inches in Somerset County as well as parts of western Sussex and eastern Morris Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused poor drainage, field and small creek flash flooding in parts of Wantage and Montague Townships. Event precipitation totals included 3.69 inches in Wantage Township. Three inches of rain also fell in Sussex Borough.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused poor drainage and small creek flash flooding in Brick Township. Flash flooding closed the northbound exit to Brick Township off of the Garden State Parkway near the Cedar Bridge Branch.  Event precipitation totals included 3.73 inches in Brick Township, one of the highest amounts to fall in New Jersey on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with additional heavy rain for the third consecutive day coupled with wet antecedent conditions to cause additional flash flooding across central and southern New Jersey on the 15th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy downpours caused poor drainage, small creek and field flash flooding in Salem County from Lower Alloway Township northeast through Upper Pittsgrove Township. Event precipitation totals included 2.80 inches in Woodstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front triggered thunderstorms with heavy downpours across northern New Jersey during the second half of the afternoon into the early evening of the 13th.  This was in addition to the heavy rain that fell across northern New Jersey from the afternoon of the 12th into the morning of the 13th preceding the same system's warm front. Total event precipitation totals averaged between 2.0 and 3.5 inches. The initial shot of heavy rain left the ground nearly saturated and vulnerable to flash flooding which occurred in parts of Warren, Morris and Middlesex Counties that afternoon and early evening. ||In addition, the combination of the preceding onshore flow and spring tides associated with the full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the evening high tide cycle on the 13th along the ocean. The high tide reached 6.30 feet above mean lower low water at Atlantic City (Atlantic County). Minor tidal flooding starts at 6.00 feet above mean lower low water. The high tides reached 7.16 feet above mean lower low water at Cape May (Cape May County) and 6.98 feet above mean lower low water at Sandy Hook (Monmouth County). Minor tidal flooding starts at 6.70 feet above mean lower low water.  The tidal influenced Watson Creek at Manasquan (Monmouth County) crested just barely above its 6 foot flood stage at 6.02 feet at 851 p.m. EDT on the 13th. While the highest tides occurred on the evening of the 13th, lesser minor tidal flooding also occurred on the evening of the 12th in Sandy Hook, the evenings of the 11th, 12th and 14th in Atlantic City and the evenings of the 11th, 12th, 14th and 15th in Cape May.  Minor tidal flooding also occurred along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries overnight on the 13th. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flash flooding in Metuchen. Flooding was reported along Main Street and New Jersey State Route 27 in Metuchen.  Entire event precipitation totals included 2.00 inches in Woodbridge.

The high tides reached 7.16 feet above mean lower low water at Cape May (Cape May County) and 6.98 feet above mean lower low water at Sandy Hook (Monmouth County). Minor tidal flooding starts at 6.70 feet above mean lower low water.  The tidal influenced Watson Creek at Manasquan (Monmouth County) crested just barely above its 6 foot flood stage at 6.02 feet at 851 p.m. EDT on the 13th. While the highest tides occurred on the evening of the 13th, lesser minor tidal flooding also occurred on the evening of the 12th in Sandy Hook, the evenings of the 11th, 12th and 14th in Atlantic City and the evenings of the 11th, 12th, 14th and 15th in Cape May.  Minor tidal flooding also occurred along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries overnight on the 13th. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 8.46 feet above mean lower low water early on the 14th. Minor tidal flooding starts at 8.20 feet above mean lower low water.

Road closures were reported in both municipalities. Entire event precipitation totals included 3.52 inches in Mansfield Township, 3.29 inches in Greenwich Township, 3.11 inches in Stewartsville, 2.88 inches in Washington Township and 2.57 inches in Hope.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage and small stream flooding in East Hanover Township. New Jersey State Route 10 was closed within the township with some underpasses totally submerged. Entire event precipitation totals included 2.41 inches in Denville, 2.28 inches in Mendham Township and 2.11 inches in Mine Hill Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary focused slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain in southwestern New Jersey during the late afternoon and early evening of the 10th. This caused poor drainage flash flooding as well as flash flooding of some smaller creeks. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 to 4 inches in sections of Salem and Gloucester Counties and nearly 2 inches in Camden County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks and roadways in and around Pitman. Event precipitation totals included 4.11 inches within the borough.

This caused poor drainage flash flooding as well as flash flooding of some smaller creeks. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2 to 4 inches in sections of Salem and Gloucester Counties and nearly 2 inches in Camden County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding along the Mantua Creek near Pitman. The creek crested at 5.32 feet (flood stage is 5 feet). Event precipitation totals included 4.11 inches in Pitman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary focused slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain in southwestern New Jersey during the late afternoon and early evening of the 10th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks and roadways in Pilesgrove Township just to the northwest of Woodstown. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached between 3.0 and 3.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure slowly worked its way through the region, which caused isolated severe thunderstorms that produced large hail and flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Motorists were stranded and rescued from flood waters on Tonelle Ave. in Jersey City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure slowly worked its way through the region, which caused isolated severe thunderstorms that produced large hail and flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous cars were trapped in flood waters and were rescued by local authorities on Route 21 near the viaduct in Newark.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Garden State Pkwy. southbound was closed at Route 46 in Clifton due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding in and around Glassboro. The flooding also affected a shopping center where water accumulated around one foot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure slowly worked its way through the region, which caused isolated severe thunderstorms that produced large hail and flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 21 southbound at 3rd Ave. in Newark was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid air mass preceding a cold front helped trigger thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused poor drainage and creek flash flooding in central New Jersey during the evening of the 2nd. Event precipitation totals reached as high as 2 to 3 inches, most of which fell in around one hour.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding along U.S. Route 9 in Woodbridge Township. Multiple water rescues occurred, but no serious injuries were reported. Event precipitation totals included 2.03 inches in Woodbridge Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a cold front slowly moved across the area, moisture from Tropical Cyclone Arthur passing to the south and east converged along the boundary resulting in severe thunderstorms, heavy rain and flash flooding in portions of Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A motorist was stranded in flood waters and had to be rescued by local authorities at the intersection of Carnot Ave. and Glen Rd. in Woodcliff Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Livingston Street in Norwood was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Washington Ave. and Grant Ave. in Dumont was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Southbound lanes of Route 17 in Paramus, south of Midland Ave., were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lincoln Blvd. at the railroad tracks in Emerson was closed due to flooding with a car stuck in flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was stuck in flood waters near the railroad tracks on Van Houten Ave. in Passaic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was stuck in 3 feet of flood waters at the intersection of Newbridge Rd. and Old Newbridge Rd. in Teaneck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Charlottes Circle in Jersey City was closed due to flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of an approaching cold front and a sea breeze front helped trigger slow moving thunderstorms that caused flash flooding in Ocean County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms caused flash flooding in Toms River Township. New Jersey State Route 37 was flooded from Vaughn Avenue to the Thomas A. Mathis Bridge. Multiple vehicles were trapped in the flood waters with water up to their windows. No serious injuries were reported. Between 20 and 30 water rescues occurred. Flooding was also reported along Adams Avenue and Bash Road near New Jersey State Route 37 in Toms River.  Event precipitation totals within Toms River included 5.24 inches and 4.60 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Liberty Ave. and Hillside Ave. in Hillside was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 22 at Bloy St. in Hillside was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 7 at Fish House Rd. in Kearny was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Frelinghuysen Ave. and Meeker St. in Newark was closed due to severe flooding. Eleven people were rescued by the Newark EMS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approaching the area triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain leading to flash flooding across Northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Forest Ave. between McKinley Blvd. and Concord Dr. in Paramus was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary and a low pressure system moving along it combined to develop thunderstorms that produced isolated damaging wind gusts as well as more widespread flash flooding across the southern half of New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of June 1st. Hardest hit with the flash flooding were locations in extreme northern Cumberland County as well as along the Atlantic and Gloucester County borders. Three to six inches of rain fell in this area mainly between 4 p.m. EDT and 10 p.m. EDT on the 1st.  As both the low pressure system and frontal boundary sagged southeast, the severe and heavy rain threat ceased.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in Buena Vista Township and Folsom Borough in Atlantic County.  While flash flooding started with the first wave of thunderstorms during the late afternoon,  a second wave of thunderstorms continued it into the evening. In the Collings Lake area of Buena Vista Township as well as in Folsom, several roadways were flooded and closed. The fire department rescued some stranded motorists in Collings Lake.  Event precipitation totals included 6.37 inches in Folsom, 4.60 inches in Hammonton, 4.40 inches in Mullica Township, 4.24 inches in Buena Vista Township, 3.20 inches in Estell Manor and 2.99 inches in Mays Landing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front triggered showers and thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused flash flooding across sections of the Raritan Valley in central New Jersey during the evening of the 31st.  Doppler Radar estimates as well as Skywarn spotter reports showed that storm total estimates reached between 2.5 and 5.0 inches across parts of the northern halves of Hunterdon, Somerset and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in and around Sayreville. Several roadways were flooded.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded three inches, most of which fell within 90 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front triggered showers and thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused flash flooding across sections of the Raritan Valley in central New Jersey during the evening of the 31st.  Doppler Radar estimates as well as Skywarn spotter reports showed that storm total estimates reached between 2.5 and 5.0 inches across parts of the northern halves of Hunterdon, Somerset and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in and around Clinton Township.  Several roadways were flooded and a couple of vehicles became trapped in high waters.  No serious injuries were reported.  Event precipitation totals within Hunterdon County included 3.56 inches in Lebanon, 2.95 inches in Stockton, 2.93 inches in Clinton and 2.75 inches in Franklin Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front triggered showers and thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused flash flooding across sections of the Raritan Valley in central New Jersey during the evening of the 31st.  Doppler Radar estimates as well as Skywarn spotter reports showed that storm total estimates reached between 2.5 and 5.0 inches across parts of the northern halves of Hunterdon, Somerset and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential downpours caused flash flooding in and around South Amboy.  The flash flooding also affected New Jersey State Route 35. A storm total amount of 4.50 inches was measured in the city, most of which fell within 90 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms, particularly during the first half of the evening on the 27th brought very heavy rain to New Jersey and caused poor drainage and flash flooding in the southern half of the state. Soil conditions were wetter than usual for late June leading into this event and made it easier for flooding to occur. Event precipitation totals reached two to five inches in central and southern New Jersey and one to two inches in the northern third of the state. Lighter showers arrived during the morning on the 27th. Precipitation remained fairly light until later in the afternoon. The heaviest rain fell during the first half of the evening. The showers and thunderstorms ended during the late evening on the 27th. The heavy precipitation was caused by an anomalously strong low pressure that moved through the Ohio Valley on the 27th. Its warm front moved northeast through the southeast half of New Jersey during that evening as a secondary low pressure system formed along it. Thunderstorms with the very heavy rain developed in the warm sector south of the front and waves of thunderstorms moved through the southeast part of the state.||The heavy rain on the 27th continued the trend of a very wet month of June across New Jersey.  The June New Jersey statewide average precipitation of 8.21 inches (nearly twice of the 4.19 inch normal) was the fourth wettest on record dating back to 1895. At the Atlantic City International Airport, the monthly precipitation total of 8.36 inches was the 2nd wettest June on record. In Trenton (Mercer County), the June precipitation total of 6.33 inches was 1.92 inches wetter than normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding in northern Atlantic County, mainly in and around Hammonton and Folsom.  In Hammonton Township, Packard Street and Bellevue Avenue were closed due to flash flooding. Flooding was also reported along New Jersey State Route 54.  Event precipitation totals included 3.49 inches in Hammonton, 3.22 inches in Folsom and 2.69 inches at the Atlantic City International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure passed to the south of the Tri-State Area along a frontal boundary, which brought heavy rain to the region and resulted in isolated flash flooding in Passaic and Union Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two men from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration were in the Weasel Brook inspecting the President Street Bridge in the town of Passaic when it started raining profusely.  The heavy rains caused the water level to rise from several inches to approximately eleven feet in minutes sweeping both men away. One man was rescued, but the other was not and was found deceased in the Passaic River the following day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front in the vicinity along with a weak area of low pressure triggered showers and thunderstorms that produced heavy rain that resulted in isolated flash flooding in Bergen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Hackensack Street and East Union Avenue in East Rutherford was closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding in eastern Ocean County from Toms River Township south through Little Egg Harbor Township.  Event precipitation totals included 4.71 inches in Brick Township, 4.49 inches in Berkeley Township, 4.41 inches at Robert J. Miller Airport, 4.26 inches in Toms River, 3.73 inches in Little Egg Harbor Township, 3.70 inches in Pine Beach, 3.51 inches in Stafford Township, 2.90 inches in Tuckerton and 2.25 inches in Lacey Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in central Cumberland County affecting Millville and Vineland the hardest. In Vineland, vehicles were submerged on Butler and Sherman Avenues. Flooding also occurred along New Jersey State Route 47. Event precipitation totals included 4.20 inches in Vineland, 4.07 inches in Millville and 2.94 inches in South Vineland.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding in southern Camden County in Winslow Township.  Flooding was reported along New Jersey State Route 73 as well as on U.S. Route 30 (White Horse Pike). Event precipitation totals included 2.86 inches in Winslow Township, 2.67 inches in Berlin Township and 1.93 inches in Haddonfield.
