EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding on Long Beach Island. Roadways near Barnegat Inlet were impassable. Surf City also closed Barnegat Avenue Event precipitation totals included 2.26 inches in Point Pleasant Beach, 1.70 inches in Surf City and 1.63 inches in Seaside Heights.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated flash flooding occurred during the afternoon and evening in Union County as a series of disturbances tracked along a frontal boundary located just south of the region.  Precipitable water values were anomalously high for early June, ranging from 1.5-2.0 inches across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: East Lincoln Avenue was closed from Walnut Street to Hemlock Street in Roselle Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure passed to the south of the Tri-State Area along a frontal boundary, which brought heavy rain to the region and resulted in isolated flash flooding in Passaic and Union Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Springfield Rd. at Hobart Ave. in Summit was closed due to flooding with a partial road collapse.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain preceding and accompanying a warm front caused flash flooding in adjoining sections of Salem and Cumberland Counties as well as some poor drainage flooding in parts of southern Gloucester, southern Camden and northern Atlantic Counties.  Doppler Radar estimates as well as actual storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches where the flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains from thunderstorms caused flash flooding along New Jersey State Route 77 in the Parsonage Run basin in Upper Deerfield Township between County Routes 540 and 611 during the early morning of the 14th. The roadway was flooded and closed. It reopened later that morning. Event totals included 3.95 inches in Upper Deerfield Township and 3.41 inches in Seabrook Farms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain preceding and accompanying a warm front caused flash flooding in adjoining sections of Salem and Cumberland Counties as well as some poor drainage flooding in parts of southern Gloucester, southern Camden and northern Atlantic Counties.  Doppler Radar estimates as well as actual storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches where the flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains from thunderstorms caused flash flooding in Upper Pittsgrove Township. Within the Alloway Creek basin, flooding closed the intersections of Newkirk Station and Daretown Roads. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 3 inches within the township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in Buena Borough. U.S. Route 40 was flooded and closed near the Deep Run. Event precipitation totals included 3.27 inches in Buena Vista Township.

In Trenton (Mercer County), the June precipitation total of 6.33 inches was 1.92 inches wetter than normal.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller streams as well as poor drainage flooding in southeastern Burlington County.  Event precipitation totals included 4.46 inches in Chatsworth, 3.39 inches in Oswego Lake, 2.53 inches in Shamong Township and 2.23 inches in Westampton Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy showers and thunderstorms developed across portions of New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania in a zone of slightly more moist and unstable air just west of the northern stream ridge axis.  By mid afternoon one of these thunderstorms became nearly stationary over portions of Union and Essex counties in New Jersey.||In Mountainside (Western Union County), 6.31 inches of rain fell in 3 hours which caused significant flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All lanes were closed on US-22 between Bonnie Burn Road and Mountain Avenue in Scotch Plains due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy showers and thunderstorms developed across portions of New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania in a zone of slightly more moist and unstable air just west of the northern stream ridge axis.  By mid afternoon one of these thunderstorms became nearly stationary over portions of Union and Essex counties in New Jersey.||In Mountainside (Western Union County), 6.31 inches of rain fell in 3 hours which caused significant flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple water rescues were underway on Diamond Hill Road between Valley Road and Mountain Avenue in Berkeley Heights.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy showers and thunderstorms developed across portions of New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania in a zone of slightly more moist and unstable air just west of the northern stream ridge axis.  By mid afternoon one of these thunderstorms became nearly stationary over portions of Union and Essex counties in New Jersey.||In Mountainside (Western Union County), 6.31 inches of rain fell in 3 hours which caused significant flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County Road (CR)-22 was closed between Mountain Avenue and New Providence Road in Mountainside due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front coupled with a warm, moist airmass triggered scattered showers and thunderstorms across southeastern Pennsylvania and into central and southern New Jersey during the late evening of the 20th through the early morning of the 21st. The thunderstorms were accompanied by heavy rainfall, leading to areas of flash flooding. In addition, isolated wind damage also occurred. Doppler radar estimates, as well as actual storm total measurements, ranged from around 2 to 4 inches where the flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced torrential rainfall across portions of Cape May County in far southern New Jersey during the early morning hours of the 21st. Flash flooding was reported in North Wildwood where numerous streets were flooded and impassable. Event precipitation totals included 3.03 inches in North Wildwood, 2.97 inches in Cape May, 2.76 inches at the Cape May County Airport in Wildwood, and 2.61 inches in Middle Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist airmass coupled with daytime heating allowed widely scattered thunderstorms to develop during the afternoon of the 19th. A few thunderstorms produced torrential downpours, leading to localized flash flooding. Doppler radar estimates reached 3 to 4 inches where the flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm produced torrential rainfall in Watchung Township in the far northeastern part of Somerset County and into adjacent parts of neighboring Union County during the afternoon of the 19th. Resulting flash flooding in Watchung Township caused cars to be stuck in two to three feet of water along Route 22 at the intersection of Terrill Road. At the nearby Weldon Materials Quarry, the partial collapse of a 100 foot by 30 foot retaining wall was reported near the intersection of New Providence Road and Union Avenue. Multiple vehicles were crushed along with heavy flooding off the mountain as a result of the retaining wall collapse. In addition to Route 22 being gridlocked in both directions, standing water and flooded exits caused multiple mile backups along nearby Interstate 78. A CoCoRahs observer in nearby New Providence (Union County) measured 4.02 inches of rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms which rode along a wavy cold frontal boundary brought heavy rain into New Jersey on the 10th. The heaviest rain fell along the Interstate 95/295 corridor (especially in Gloucester County) and along coastal sections of New Jersey.  This caused poor drainage as well as some creek flash flooding, mainly in Gloucester County where some event precipitation totals exceeded 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm caused flash flooding from Gibbstown (Greenwich Township) through northern East Greenwich Township and Paulsboro. Many roadways were flooded in the area and closed.  Vehicles were stuck in flood waters, but no serious injuries were reported.  Two event precipitation totals  from East Greenwich Township were 4.28 inches and 4.05 inches respectively.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms which rode along a wavy cold frontal boundary brought heavy rain into New Jersey on the 10th. The heaviest rain fell along the Interstate 95/295 corridor (especially in Gloucester County) and along coastal sections of New Jersey.  This caused poor drainage as well as some creek flash flooding, mainly in Gloucester County where some event precipitation totals exceeded 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm caused flash flooding in Logan Township. The flash flooding affected Interstate 295 as the left and center southbound lanes between exits 11 and 14 were flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms which rode along a wavy cold frontal boundary brought heavy rain into New Jersey on the 10th. The heaviest rain fell along the Interstate 95/295 corridor (especially in Gloucester County) and along coastal sections of New Jersey.  This caused poor drainage as well as some creek flash flooding, mainly in Gloucester County where some event precipitation totals exceeded 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm caused flash flooding in Woodbury. Vehicles were stuck in flood waters at the intersection of Glassboro Road and Evergreen Avenue near the Hesters Branch. No serious injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorms which rode along a wavy cold frontal boundary brought heavy rain into New Jersey on the 10th. The heaviest rain fell along the Interstate 95/295 corridor (especially in Gloucester County) and along coastal sections of New Jersey.  This caused poor drainage as well as some creek flash flooding, mainly in Gloucester County where some event precipitation totals exceeded 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms caused flash flooding in Mantua Township and Wenonah Borough in the Mantua Creek Basin. In Mantua Township, New Jersey State Route 45 was closed and a few vehicles were trapped in the flood waters.  No serious injuries were reported. Event precipitation totals included 5.79 inches in Wenonah and 2.88 inches in Pitman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southern New Jersey during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of Salem, Gloucester, Atlantic and Ocean Counties.  The flash flooding in Gloucester and Salem Counties was exacerbated because of the heavy rain and flooding that occurred just the previous morning. Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.  The combined heavy rain that fell on both the 14th and 15th along the Cumberland and Salem County border also led to river flooding that lasted into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused poor drainage flash flooding in both Millville and Vineland. In Vineland water 2 to 3 feet deep was reported on roadways. Sections of West Avenue, Plum Street, Chester Avenue and Southwest Boulevard were all flooded and closed.  In Millville, 2nd Street was also flooded. Some roadway flooding was also reported along New Jersey State Route 77 in Upper Deerfield Township. Event precipitation totals included 3.27 inches in Vineland and 2.00 inches in Millville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rain preceding and accompanying a warm front caused flash flooding in adjoining sections of Salem and Cumberland Counties as well as some poor drainage flooding in parts of southern Gloucester, southern Camden and northern Atlantic Counties.  Doppler Radar estimates as well as actual storm total estimates reached 3 to 4 inches where the flash flooding occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rains from thunderstorms caused flash flooding in Elmer and adjacent parts of Pittsgrove Township. Within the Muddy Run basin, flooding forced the closure of  U.S. Route 40 in Elmer.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 4 inches in and around Elmer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over the Finger Lakes region of New York State helped trigger a cluster of showers and thunderstorms with very heavy rain that moved over northwest New Jersey mainly during the evening of the 26th. The heaviest rain fell over western parts of Warren County and especially in far northwest Sussex County. Doppler Radar storm total estimates exceeded 4 inches in the latter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms with torrential rain caused poor drainage and small creek flash flooding in the Shimers Brook Basin in Montague Township. Event precipitation totals included 4.74 inches in Montague. A mesonet site within Montague measured 2.57 inches of rain in 70 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southern New Jersey during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of Salem, Gloucester, Atlantic and Ocean Counties.  The flash flooding in Gloucester and Salem Counties was exacerbated because of the heavy rain and flooding that occurred just the previous morning. Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.  The combined heavy rain that fell on both the 14th and 15th along the Cumberland and Salem County border also led to river flooding that lasted into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy caused small creek and roadway flash flooding in Upper Pittsgrove Township.  This was the second morning in a row that heavy rain fell in Salem County. Roadway flooding was reported along Bridgeton Road in the township. Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2.5 to 3.0 inches in the northern part of the county. In Pennsville, 2.10 inches of rain fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southern New Jersey during the morning of the 15th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy caused small creek and roadway flash flooding in Franklin Township.  Sections of Marshall Mill Road and New Jersey State Route 47 were flooded and closed near the Malaga Branch.  Two day event precipitation totals included 4.33 inches in Franklin Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southern New Jersey during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of Salem, Gloucester, Atlantic and Ocean Counties. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy caused small creek and roadway flash flooding in Washignton Township in the Bells Lake drainage basin. Sections of Greentree Road and the Black Horse Pike (New Jersey State Route 42) were flooded and closed.  Doppler Radar storm total estimates reached 2.5 inches in the township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southern New Jersey during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of Salem, Gloucester, Atlantic and Ocean Counties.  The flash flooding in Gloucester and Salem Counties was exacerbated because of the heavy rain and flooding that occurred just the previous morning. Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.  The combined heavy rain that fell on both the 14th and 15th along the Cumberland and Salem County border also led to river flooding that lasted into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy caused small creek and roadway flash flooding across eastern sections of Atlantic County including parts of Hamilton, Egg Harbor and Galloway Townships, Northfield and Absecon. In Hamilton Township, the Black Horse Pike (U.S. Route 322) was flooded near the Hamilton Mall and Liepzig Avenue. In Northfield, Tilton Road was closed between Hingston and Cresson Roads. In Absecon, widespread occurred along the White Horse Pike (U.S. Route 30). Some vehicles were stuck in the flood waters.  The roadway itself was closed between U.S. Route 9 and County Route 646 (Delilah Road). Shopping center parking lots were turning into lakes. In Galloway Township, the White Horse Pike was also flooded. In Egg Harbor Township, sections of the Black Horse Pike (U.S. Route 322/40) were also flooded.  Elsewhere in the county, some poor drainage flooding also occurred.  Event precipitation totals included 3.85 inches in Galloway Township, 3.02 inches at the Atlantic City International Airport, 2.96 inches in Folsom and 2.20 inches in Hammonton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southern New Jersey during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of Salem, Gloucester, Atlantic and Ocean Counties.  The flash flooding in Gloucester and Salem Counties was exacerbated because of the heavy rain and flooding that occurred just the previous morning. Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.  The combined heavy rain that fell on both the 14th and 15th along the Cumberland and Salem County border also led to river flooding that lasted into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy also caused flash flooding on the barrier islands in Atlantic County. Roadways were closed with vehicles trapped in flash flood waters in Brigantine, Margate and Atlantic City.  In Atlantic City, roadways had up to two feet of water on them and many parking lots were flooded. In Margate City, Ventnor Avenue was flooded and closed. Event precipitation totals included 2.63 inches at the Marina within Atlantic City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southern New Jersey during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of Salem, Gloucester, Atlantic and Ocean Counties.  The flash flooding in Gloucester and Salem Counties was exacerbated because of the heavy rain and flooding that occurred just the previous morning. Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.  The combined heavy rain that fell on both the 14th and 15th along the Cumberland and Salem County border also led to river flooding that lasted into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy also caused flash flooding on the barrier island in  Ocean County. Flash flooding and road closures were reported on Long Beach Island in Long Beach Township and Beach Haven. In Long Beach Township, Long Beach Boulevard was flooded and closed in sections. In Beach Haven, flood waters on Bay Avenue forced detours. Event precipitation totals included 3.32 inches in Beach Haven.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front triggered showers and thunderstorms with heavy downpours that caused flash flooding across sections of the Raritan Valley in central New Jersey during the evening of the 31st.  Doppler Radar estimates as well as Skywarn spotter reports showed that storm total estimates reached between 2.5 and 5.0 inches across parts of the northern halves of Hunterdon, Somerset and Middlesex Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy downpours caused flash flooding in and around North Plainfield.  Vehicles became trapped in high waters on U.S. Route 22 within the township.  Five people were trapped in those vehicles, but no serious injuries were reported.  Event precipitation totals within Somerset County included 2.52 inches in Bernards Township and 2.20 inches in Branchburg Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Double barrel cold fronts helped trigger a series of showers and thunderstorms across southern New Jersey during the morning of the 15th. Thunderstorms that were accompanied by very heavy rain caused flash flooding in parts of Salem, Gloucester, Atlantic and Ocean Counties.  The flash flooding in Gloucester and Salem Counties was exacerbated because of the heavy rain and flooding that occurred just the previous morning. Actual rainfall amounts in these locations were as high as 2 to 4 inches, most of which fell during a three hour period.  The combined heavy rain that fell on both the 14th and 15th along the Cumberland and Salem County border also led to river flooding that lasted into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy caused flash flooding in the Mystics Island section of Little Egg Harbor Township. Major street flooding was reported with numerous people and vehicles stuck in flood waters. No major injuries however were reported. Event precipitation totals included 4.16 inches in Little Egg Harbor Township and 2.27 inches in Tuckerton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms that formed in the warm sector of the Susquehanna Valley and moved through southern New Jersey during the first half of the evening on the 9th. It produced some wind damage along its leading edge and then dropped heavy rain that caused some flash flooding later that evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain and flash flooding forced the suspension of the commuter train River Line in Camden between the Walter Rand Transportation Center and the Entertainment Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary and a low pressure system moving along it combined to develop thunderstorms that produced isolated damaging wind gusts as well as more widespread flash flooding across the southern half of New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of June 1st. Hardest hit with the flash flooding were locations in extreme northern Cumberland County as well as along the Atlantic and Gloucester County borders. Three to six inches of rain fell in this area mainly between 4 p.m. EDT and 10 p.m. EDT on the 1st.  As both the low pressure system and frontal boundary sagged southeast, the severe and heavy rain threat ceased.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The second wave of thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding in Vineland. Several roadways were severely flooded within the city.  Event precipitation totals included 4.65 inches in Fairfield Township, 4.60 inches in Vineland, 3.83 inches in Millville, 3.56 inches in Greenwich, 3.10 inches in Newport, 2.98 inches in Upper Deerfield Township and 2.71 inches in Bivalve.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary frontal boundary and a low pressure system moving along it combined to develop thunderstorms that produced isolated damaging wind gusts as well as more widespread flash flooding across the southern half of New Jersey during the afternoon and evening of June 1st. Hardest hit with the flash flooding were locations in extreme northern Cumberland County as well as along the Atlantic and Gloucester County borders. Three to six inches of rain fell in this area mainly between 4 p.m. EDT and 10 p.m. EDT on the 1st.  As both the low pressure system and frontal boundary sagged southeast, the severe and heavy rain threat ceased.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The second wave of thunderstorms with very heavy rain caused flash flooding of smaller creeks and roadways in Franklin and Monroe Townships near the border with Atlantic County.  Event precipitation totals included 4.91 inches in Piney Hollow (Franklin Township) and 3.12 inches in South Harrison Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of thunderstorms associated with several shortwaves and a cold front became nearly stationary over Mercer County on the 29th and Hunderdon County on the morning of the 30th. Heavy rainfall over 5 inches occurred in these areas. The persistent heavy rain resulted in severe flash flooding including a state of emergency being issued in West Windsor Twp. Thousands were left without power as a result of the storms. The Monmouth county fair and New Jersey Balloon festival were cancelled due to weather on 7/31.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of thunderstorms associated with several shortwaves and a cold front became nearly stationary over Mercer County on the 29th and Hunderdon County on the morning of the 30th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: West Windsor Twp declared a state of emergency Due to widespread flash flooding, numerous water rescues occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary frontal boundary was located across the region. This frontal boundary led to the formation of showers and thunderstorms. Some of the thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall which resulted in flooding. Severe weather was also reported with several of the storms. Thousands were left without power due to thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were quickly flooded due to heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving north through the Great Lakes region, combined with its associated warm front and cold front, copious amounts of moisture, and low level jet, produced strong to severe thunderstorms, heavy rain, flash flooding, and stream flooding in New Jersey late Wednesday afternoon and evening, February 24th, with stream flooding continuing into Thursday, February 25th. Thousands were without power for a period across the state, focused in South Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Southbound Interstate 295 was closed around mile marker 27 (near Bellmawr) due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving north through the Great Lakes region, combined with its associated warm front and cold front, copious amounts of moisture, and low level jet, produced strong to severe thunderstorms, heavy rain, flash flooding, and stream flooding in New Jersey late Wednesday afternoon and evening, February 24th, with stream flooding continuing into Thursday, February 25th. Thousands were without power for a period across the state, focused in South Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gage on the Neshanic River at Reaville reached its 6.5 foot flood stage at 2355EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system moving north through the Great Lakes region, combined with its associated warm front and cold front, copious amounts of moisture, and low level jet, produced strong to severe thunderstorms, heavy rain, flash flooding, and stream flooding in New Jersey late Wednesday afternoon and evening, February 24th, with stream flooding continuing into Thursday, February 25th. Thousands were without power for a period across the state, focused in South Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gage on Stony Brook at North Plainfield reached its flood stage of 7 feet at 2340EST.  The stream gage on Stony Brook at Watchung reached its flood stage of 7 feet at 2340EST. All lanes closed to due to flooding on Shepard Ave and River Road in Middlesex due to flooding overnight 2/24 and the morning of 2/25. Flooding on the Raritan river occurred in High Bridge and Clinton near the Red Hill Museum.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong area of low pressure passing west of the area produced heavy rain that lead to isolated flash flooding across portions of Union County, New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stalled in flood water on Massachusetts Street in Westfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved eastward into the region during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 28th. Thunderstorms formed ahead of the cold front and produced hail, strong winds and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on West-Washington Ave and West-Johnston Ave with portions of the pavement washed away.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold frontal boundary along with several shortwaves and a seabreeze produced numerous showers and thunderstorms across the southern and central portions of New Jersey during the afternoon and evening hours of the 16th. A few strong wind gusts not associated with damage were measured or estimated at 53 mph in Toms River, 57 mph in Berkeley Twp and 50 mph in northern Howell Twp.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall led to flash flooding. A person drove into the water and had to be rescued from the car.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary frontal boundary was present over the region on the 8th. This allowed for the development of showers and thunderstorms. Heavy rainfall along with strong to severe thunderstorms occurred formed as instability grew in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall from thunderstorms led to quick water rises on roads with water several inches deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough of low pressure moved through the region which led to the development of showers and thunderstorms. Some of the storms became severe and produced heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Neshanic river was out of it's banks around Reaville USGS River Gauge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a very moist environment ahead of an approaching cold front, resulting in flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey. Newark Airport received 1.84 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Route 22 and Park Avenue in Scotch Plains was impassable due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall developed north of a stationary front and associated weak wave of low pressure located across central New Jersey on the evening of July 31st. With precipitable water values approaching 2 over the area, this resulted in flash flooding across Passaic and Bergen counties, including several water rescues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue was conducted for a vehicle and occupants in deep water on Hamburg Turnpike between Mountain Ridge Drive and Old Homestead Road in Wayne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of gusty convective showers moved through during the morning hours in association with the remnants of tropical storm Cindy. Several reports of damage were reported from the winds. Thousands lost power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A section of interstate 287 near Possumtown flooded due to heavy rain. Unusual spot for flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms formed in a hot and humid airmass ahead of a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The river gauge on the Neshanic at Reaville rose above flood stage for a few hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms formed in a hot and humid airmass ahead of a cold front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several water rescues occurred in South Amboy and Sayerville near Victory circle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass with weak boundaries led to slow moving strong to severe thunderstorms with damaging winds, hail and flooding. Over 2,000 people lost power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue occurred near the intersection of Meadow and Clifton roads as a nearby creek overflowed it's banks and a vehicle became trapped in high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass with weak boundaries led to slow moving strong to severe thunderstorms with damaging winds, hail and flooding. Over 2,000 people lost power.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water entering a house on Cornell road due to a nearby creek overflowing it's banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching upper level disturbance combined with increasing instability resulted in the development of afternoon showers and thunderstorms. With weak steering flow and precipitable water values of 1.5 or greater, these storms produced flash flooding across parts of Passaic County. Over one inch of rain was reported in southern Passaic County, with a CoCoRaHS gauge in Little Falls Township recording 1.59 of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 202 was closed at the Mountainview Boulevard exit in Wayne due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Willowbrook Boulevard was closed at North Leg Road in Wayne with cars stuck in water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms moved across the area during the early morning hours ahead of an approaching cold front. These storms developed in a high moisture environment, with precipitable water values on the 8am EDT Upton sounding exceeding 2. This led to isolated flash flooding in Passaic County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US 46 was closed in both directions west of CR 625 and Randolph Avenue in Clifton due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass with weak boundaries led to slow moving strong to severe thunderstorms with damaging winds, hail and flooding. Over 2,000 people lost power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were flooded and impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass with weak boundaries led to slow moving strong to severe thunderstorms with damaging winds, hail and flooding. Over 2,000 people lost power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding at the intersection of route 10 and 222 with many other roads impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front approaching the area combined with a strong low level jet ushering in precipitable water values in excess of 1.5 inches, resulted in flash flooding across parts of northeast New Jersey. Newark Airport (3.05 inches) and Teterboro Airport (3.01 inches) received just over 3 inches of rain during the event, with the majority of that rain falling during a three hour period. Hourly rainfall rates of up to 1.5 inches were reported at Teterboro, with rates over one inch per hour at Newark.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle was stuck in flood waters on Main Street in Hackensack with a water rescue in progress.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass was present ahead of a frontal boundary which slowly moved southeast toward and then through the state. Several rounds of thunderstorms moved through the region ahead of this front over the course of a few days. 2,800 people lost power in Ocean county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several care flooded to rooftop level in Bridgeton and a mudslide on pearl street. 2.16 inches of rain fell in 28 minutes at ASOS site KMIV.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rare summertime Nor'easter tracked just offshore producing heavy rain, thunderstorms and wind. Coastal flooding and beach erosion also occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several water rescues occurred due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass was present ahead of a frontal boundary which slowly moved southeast toward and then through the state. Several rounds of thunderstorms moved through the region ahead of this front over the course of a few days. 2,800 people lost power in Ocean county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles trapped in water on Lincoln Ave.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were impassable including Old Egg harbor road and Pinehurst drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary was the focus for several rounds of thunderstorms that produced damaging winds and flooding in spots. Several thousand people lost power throughout the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A sedan was stuck in high water at the intersection of Tulip and Masters streets. Riverline service was suspended.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated convection developed across parts of northeast New Jersey in the afternoon in response to an upper level shortwave passing north of the area. Light flow aloft resulted in slow storm motions, which resulted in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 202 was flooded with a vehicle disabled in the road at 555 Terhune Drive in Wayne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary was the focus for several rounds of thunderstorms that produced damaging winds and flooding in spots. Several thousand people lost power throughout the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dorms at Rowan University were evacuated due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall developed across the area on the morning of April 16th ahead of a slow moving warm front. This rain developed in an environment with precipitable water values greater than 1.25 inches, well above normal for mid April. Rainfall totals generally ranged from 2.5 to 4.5 inches across northeast New Jersey, with the majority of the rain falling in a 3-4 hour period. This resulted in flash flooding across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Third River at Bloomfield rose above its flood stage of 6.0 feet at 10:05am EDT, crested at a height of 6.25 feet at 11:00am EDT, and fell back below flood stage at 11:50am EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall developed across the area on the morning of April 16th ahead of a slow moving warm front. This rain developed in an environment with precipitable water values greater than 1.25 inches, well above normal for mid April. Rainfall totals generally ranged from 2.5 to 4.5 inches across northeast New Jersey, with the majority of the rain falling in a 3-4 hour period. This resulted in flash flooding across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pascack Brook at Pine Ridge rose above its flood stage of 5.2 feet at 10:30am EDT, crested at a height of 5.94 feet at 12:45pm EDT, and fell back below flood stage at 3:00pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain developed across the area ahead of an approaching warm front, consolidating into a slow-moving band of heavy rain across northeast New Jersey by late morning. Precipitable water values increased from 1.84 on the morning sounding from Upton, NY to 2.13 by evening. Both of these values are above the 90th percentile based on a sounding climatology, with the 2.13 precipitable water value on the evening of the 25th a record for the date. Rainfall amounts generally ranged from 3-5 inches, with one CoCoRaHS observer reporting 5.56 inches of rain in Palisades Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Car stuck in flood waters on Route 440 southbound near Port Jersey Boulevard in Bayonne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals of 3 to 5 inches fell in parts of northeastern Maryland, Delaware, and southern and central New Jersey on the night of October 11.  There were a few reports of rainfall amounts in excess of 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 34 was closed in Wall Township to the north of Belmar Boulevard due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals of 3 to 5 inches fell in parts of northeastern Maryland, Delaware, and southern and central New Jersey on the night of October 11.  There were a few reports of rainfall amounts in excess of 5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Salem River at Woodstown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms with damaging winds, and flash flooding affected parts of New Jersey.  Locally heavy rainfall occurred in a short amount of time.  Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches fell in northeastern Middlesex County.  Rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches fell in western Cumberland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Perth Amboy.  There was one water rescue.

Rainfall totals of 3 to 6 inches fell in northeastern Middlesex County.  Rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches fell in western Cumberland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Stow Creek Township, Greenwich Township, Fairfield Township, Hopewell Township and Shiloh.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rain fell in southern New Jersey on the afternoon of July 17, 2018.  Some locations in Ocean County and in southeastern Monmouth County received 3 to 5 inches of rain in a short amount of time. Wind damage also occurred from from these storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in Toms River were flooded and impassable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding in Seaside Heights.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Woodbridge Township and Carteret.  There was significant flooding on the New Jersey Turnpike between Exits 11 and 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy rain fell in parts of eastern Somerset County and northwestern Middlesex County on the night of September 12-13.  Rainfall totals ranged from 3.5 to 5.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding in South Plainfield with many roads becoming impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts around 1.5 to 2.5 inches fell in parts of Middlesex County during the late morning and early afternoon of September 18.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in North Brunswick Township.  Jersey Avenue was closed near Huron Road due to high water.  Several vehicles were trapped in flood waters on Milltown Road north of US Route 1.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough developing out ahead of an approaching cold front initiated scattered afternoon showers and thunderstorms across northeast New Jersey. With very slow storm motions and precipitable water values rising from 1.5 to 2.0 inches, this resulted in isolated flash flooding across the region. The Caldwell, NJ ASOS reported 1.89 inches of precipitation, and a COOP observer in Harrison, NJ reported 1.00.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rescues were being conducted at the intersection of Chestnut Street and High Street in Cranford.

A woman was rescued from her car stuck in four feet of water under the West Crescent Avenue underpass. A spotter reports that these locations typically flood in heavy rain.

With very slow storm motions and precipitable water values rising from 1.5 to 2.0 inches, this resulted in isolated flash flooding across the region. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Westfield Road was closed due to flooding in Fanwood after sewage drains could not handle the volume of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approached the Mid-Atlantic following a prolonged heat wave over the 4th of July holiday week. High precipitable water values along with surface convergence allowed storms with high rainfall rates to form. Areas along the I-195 corridor saw the heaviest rainfall near and above 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred along Interstate 195 in Robbinsville Township.  The westbound ramp at Exit 7 to County Road 526 was under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick 1 to 2 inches of rain fell in parts of southwestern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and early evening of September 25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding in Trenton.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway flooding at the Interstate 195 and Interstate 295 interchange in Hamilton Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a moist and unstable airmass ahead of an approaching cold front, leading to isolated flash flooding in Bergen County, New Jersey. Precipitable water values during the afternoon were around 2 inches, and an automated observing station in Oakland, NJ recorded 1.88 inches of rain, the majority of which fell within a 2-3 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 208 was closed due to flooding southbound between Summit Avenue and Ewing Avenue in Wycoff.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moist southerly flow ahead of an approaching cold front helped produce afternoon showers and thunderstorms across the region. With precipitable water values at or above 2 inches, these showers and storms produced isolated flash flooding across parts of Passaic County, NJ.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tremont Terrace was closed due to high water in Wanaque.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approached the Mid-Atlantic following a prolonged heat wave over the 4th of July holiday week. High precipitable water values along with surface convergence allowed storms with high rainfall rates to form. Areas along the I-195 corridor saw the heaviest rainfall near and above 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 70 in Lakehurst was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front approached the Mid-Atlantic following a prolonged heat wave over the 4th of July holiday week. High precipitable water values along with surface convergence allowed storms with high rainfall rates to form. Areas along the I-195 corridor saw the heaviest rainfall near and above 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused a large sinkhole to develop along Main Street in Lakewood near the intersection of Clifton Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted north across the area through the day on October 2nd, leaving the local area in the warm sector. Multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms developed and moved through the region. With wet antecedent conditions from recent rainfall and plenty of available moisture as precipitable water values approached two inches, these showers and storms resulted in flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey. Rainfall totals across the region generally ranged from 1-3 inches, with a CoCoRaHS observer in Oakland reporting 2.30 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was floating on Calumet Avenue in Oakland due to flooding. In addition, street flooding was reported on both Seminole Avenue and Pine Crest Drive.

Rainfall totals across the region generally ranged from 1-3 inches, with a CoCoRaHS observer in Oakland reporting 2.30 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was flooding at and around the Princeton Junction train station in West Windsor Township.  Sections of the parking lot were under water and a pedestrian tunnel was flooded.  Also, there was flooding on Wallace Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted north across the area through the day on October 2nd, leaving the local area in the warm sector. Multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms developed and moved through the region. With wet antecedent conditions from recent rainfall and plenty of available moisture as precipitable water values approached two inches, these showers and storms resulted in flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey. Rainfall totals across the region generally ranged from 1-3 inches, with a CoCoRaHS observer in Oakland reporting 2.30 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hohokus Brook rose above its flood stage of 3.0ft at 10:30pm EDT October 2nd, crested at a height of 3.51 ft at 11:00pm EDT, and fell back below flood stage at 2:15am EDT October 3rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms caused wind damage across portions of southwestern New Jersey on the evening of July 3.  Rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches fell along the Interstate 95/New Jersey Turnpike Corridor in a short amount of time.  A few locations received 3 to 4 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was widespread roadway flooding in Willingboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough developing out ahead of an approaching cold front initiated scattered afternoon showers and thunderstorms across northeast New Jersey. With very slow storm motions and precipitable water values rising from 1.5 to 2.0 inches, this resulted in isolated flash flooding across the region. The Caldwell, NJ ASOS reported 1.89 inches of precipitation, and a COOP observer in Harrison, NJ reported 1.00.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gloria Lane was closed due to flooding in Fairfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed out ahead of an approaching cold front and stalled over parts of northeast New Jersey, producing 1-2 inches of rain in a matter of hours resulting in isolated reports of flash flooding in Union and Essex counties. The Newark Airport ASOS reported 1.16 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Union Avenue was closed due to flooding between Marsh Street and Lexington Avenue due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain developed across the area ahead of an approaching warm front, consolidating into a slow-moving band of heavy rain across northeast New Jersey by late morning. Precipitable water values increased from 1.84 on the morning sounding from Upton, NY to 2.13 by evening. Both of these values are above the 90th percentile based on a sounding climatology, with the 2.13 precipitable water value on the evening of the 25th a record for the date. Rainfall amounts generally ranged from 3-5 inches, with one CoCoRaHS observer reporting 5.56 inches of rain in Palisades Park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All lanes closed on US Routes 1 & 9 in Newark approaching the Pulaski Skyway starting before Wilson Avenue due to flooding. This included the ramp from Routes 1 & 9 north to the Turnpike toll plaza at interchange 15E.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled stationary boundary within a very moist airmass provided a focusing mechanism for several rounds of heavy rain that resulted in widespread flash flooding across northeast New Jersey. The Caldwell, NJ ASOS recorded 4.92 inches of rain, and multiple other stations across northeast New Jersey received between 2.5 inches and 4 inches of precipitation. The Little Falls area of Passaic County was particularly hard hit when rising water from the Peckman River swept away numerous cars from the Route 46 Chrysler, Jeep, Dodge dealership.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding reported across the town of Fanwood, including two water rescues from vehicles.

The adjacent section of the Garden State Parkway was flooded and some of the northbound lanes were closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Peckman River at Verona rose above its flood stage of 3.5 feet at 4:50pm EDT. The river continued to rise above its moderate flood stage of 4.0 feet (4:55pm EDT) and major flood stage of 5.0 feet (5:10pm EDT) before cresting at a height of 6.36 feet at 5:35pm EDT. The river fell back below flood stage at 6:50pm EDT. The crest of 6.36 feet was within about 0.2 feet of the record crest at this location of 6.6 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Third River at Bloomfield rose above its flood stage of 6.0 feet at 6:40pm EDT, crested at a height of 7.15 feet at 7:40pm EDT, then fell back below flood stage at 9:30pm EDT.

Cars were underwater in the Best Buy parking lot. Overall, approximately 210 homes, 70 businesses, and 22 parked cars were impacted by flooding in Woodland Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled stationary boundary within a very moist airmass provided a focusing mechanism for several rounds of heavy rain that resulted in widespread flash flooding across northeast New Jersey. The Caldwell, NJ ASOS recorded 4.92 inches of rain, and multiple other stations across northeast New Jersey received between 2.5 inches and 4 inches of precipitation. The Little Falls area of Passaic County was particularly hard hit when rising water from the Peckman River swept away numerous cars from the Route 46 Chrysler, Jeep, Dodge dealership.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple cars parked at the Route 46 Chrysler Jeep Dodge dealer along the Peckman River in Little Falls were swept into the river when it flooded.||Media reports later indicated that a total of 42 cars were swept away from the Chrysler Jeep Dodge dealership and that an additional 200 cars were damaged due to the flooding at the McGuire Buick dealership next door. Overall, approximately 190 homes and numerous vehicles were impacted by flood waters in Little Falls, with 32 homes deemed uninhabitable. All of the uninhabitable homes were located in the Jackson Park area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a warm and humid environment ahead of an approaching cold front, resulting in isolated flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey. These storms brought 1-2 inches of rain to the region in a matter of hours, with a cooperative observer in Harrison, NJ recording 1.79 inches of rain during the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars were stuck in flood waters with water rescues underway on Frank E Rodgers Boulevard at the PATH train station in Harrison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A developing area of low pressure along a surface trough helped produce heavy rainfall across parts of northeast New Jersey on the morning of August 4th that resulted in flash flooding. Rainfall amounts ranged from 1-3 inches in many places. Between the afternoon of August 3rd and the afternoon of August 4th, the Caldwell, NJ ASOS measured 2.75, and CoCoRaHS observers in Park Ridge and Hawthorne measured 2.90 and 2.95, respectively, with a CWOP station in Scotch Plains reporting 2.42.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding closed all westbound lanes of US Route 22 in Scotch Plains at the intersection with Bonnie Burn Road and Park Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain fell in Cumberland County on the afternoon of June 9, 2018.  Rainfall totals up to 3 to 5 inches occurred in a short period of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred from Bridgeton to Millville.  Many vehicles were stranded in the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain occurred on the night of June 10 across parts of southeastern Pennsylvania, and central and southern New Jersey. Rainfall totals up to 3 to 6 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rescues along and around Willow Bend Drive in Delran Township.  At least five individuals were rescued from vehicles that were stranded in flood waters.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding along Route 130 between Route 90 and Route 73 in Pennsauken.  The northbound lanes were closed to traffic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving up the spine of the Appalachians resulted in widespread heavy rainfall and reports of flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey. A record high precipitable water value of 1.66 inches was recorded on the 12Z sounding from Upton, NY. Rainfall amounts across the region ranged from 1.5 to 3. A CoCoRaHS observer near West Milford reported 2.94 inches of rain from this event, while a trained spotter in Westwood reported 2.66 inches. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 1.76 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Memorial Drive was closed at Main Street in Lodi due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted north across the area through the day on October 2nd, leaving the local area in the warm sector. Multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms developed and moved through the region. With wet antecedent conditions from recent rainfall and plenty of available moisture as precipitable water values approached two inches, these showers and storms resulted in flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey. Rainfall totals across the region generally ranged from 1-3 inches, with a CoCoRaHS observer in Oakland reporting 2.30 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fire Department was dispatched to a home on Park Avenue in Park Ridge due to flood waters entering the basement.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving along a nearly stationary boundary triggered an area of convection that moved across the region during the evening of May 30th, resulting in isolated flash flooding across northeast New Jersey. Rainfall totals generally ranged from 1-1.5 inches, with the majority of the rain falling in a one to two hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hohokus Brook at Ho-Ho-Kus rose above it's flood stage of 3.0 feet at 7:15pm EDT, crested at a height of 3.37 feet at 7:30pm EDT, and fell back below flood stage by 8:45pm EDT.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads in South Brunswick Township were closed due to flash flooding.  The list includes US Route 1 around Promenade Boulevard, US Route 130 around Fresh Ponds Road, and Summerfield Boulevard.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place along Homestead Avenue in the Avenel section of Woodbridge Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles became trapped in flood waters along US Route 130 in Pennsauken.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cokesbury Road and several adjacent roads in Clinton Township became impassable due to flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle became trapped in flood waters in Tewksbury Township, requiring a water rescue.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along US Route 9 near NJ Route 34 in Old Bridge Township, resulting in lane closures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several road closures in the Port Monmouth section of Middletown Township due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of northern, central and southwestern New Jersey on the afternoon of August 7.  Rainfall totals of 2 to around 4 inches fell in parts of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 35 was closed in both directions around Birchwood Drive in Old Bridge Township due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a sub-tropical environment ahead of the remnants of Post Tropical Cyclone Barry, resulting in flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey. Based on the 12Z upper air sounding from Upton, New York, precipitable water values across the region were around 2.25 inches. Rainfall amounts across much of northeast New Jersey ranged from 1-2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cars were stranded by high water in both directions on the Garden State Parkway in Irvington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a sub-tropical environment ahead of the remnants of Post Tropical Cyclone Barry, resulting in flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey. Based on the 12Z upper air sounding from Upton, New York, precipitable water values across the region were around 2.25 inches. Rainfall amounts across much of northeast New Jersey ranged from 1-2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets flooded in Hoboken with water at least halfway up car tires, including Madison Street between 9th and 10th Streets and 1st Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon as precipitable water values rose above 1.50 inches, resulting in isolated flash flooding in urban northeast New Jersey. Rainfall amounts varied widely across the area, with areas that received the most prolonged rainfall such as Newark Airport and Harrison reporting 1.60 and 1.17 inches, respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads closed around Elizabeth due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another wave of low pressure moved along a frontal boundary stalled over the region during the early morning hours of Tuesday, July 23rd. After widespread rainfall totals of 1-2 inches the night before, additional rainfall amounts of around one inch increased the two day rainfall totals to 2-3 inches across much of the area, with the majority of that rain falling within roughly an 18 hour period. This resulted in additional flash flooding, particularly across urban areas. Two day rainfall totals included 2.38 inches at Newark Airport and 3.32 inches at Teterboro Airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple streets were closed due to flooding with cars stuck in high water in Hackensack. Street closures included Lodi Street between Polify Road and South State Street and Green Street between Wesley Street and Essex Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania and northern New Jersey on the night of October 31.  Rainfall totals of 1.0 to 2.5 inches were common from Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and the Pocono Region in Pennsylvania into northwestern New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roseberry Street in Phillipsburg was closed due to flash flooding.  US Route 22 was closed near NJ Route 57 in Lopatcong Township due to flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flow parallel to a stalled frontal boundary across the region allowed showers and thunderstorms to train across the area during the afternoon and evening hours. These storms developed in an environment with precipitable water values around 2.25 inches and produced widespread 1-2 inch rainfall amounts across the region. The Newark Airport ASOS reported 1.69 inches of rain in this event, while a trained spotter in Bloomingdale reported 2.15 inches of rain. Much of the rain fell within a 1-2 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All lanes were closed in both directions due to flooding on NJ 27 (Lincoln Highway) at St. Georges Avenue (NJ 35) in Rahway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flow parallel to a stalled frontal boundary across the region allowed showers and thunderstorms to train across the area during the afternoon and evening hours. These storms developed in an environment with precipitable water values around 2.25 inches and produced widespread 1-2 inch rainfall amounts across the region. The Newark Airport ASOS reported 1.69 inches of rain in this event, while a trained spotter in Bloomingdale reported 2.15 inches of rain. Much of the rain fell within a 1-2 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed and water rescues were conduced in Harrison, East Newark, and Kearny, including along Frank E. Rodgers Boulevard South in Harrison and along Passaic Avenue in both East Newark and Kearny.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed across the area during the afternoon in response to an approaching warm front. These showers developed within an environment with increasing precipitable water values, resulting in a several hour period of heavy rain. Widespread rainfall totals of 1-2 inches were reported across northeast New Jersey, with several reports of 2.5-3 inches. A CoCoRaHS observer in Oakland, NJ reported 3.46 inches of rain in this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All lanes closed and detoured due to flooding in both directions on NJ-21 (McCarter Highway) in the area of I-280 in Newark.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brookfield Avenue was flooded at Passaic Avenue in Nutley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of northern New Jersey on the afternoon and early evening of July 22.  Rainfall amounts of 2 to near 4 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along NJ Route 23 in the Kinnelon and Butler area, washing out part of the roadway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed across northeast New Jersey ahead of a cold front during the afternoon of August 7th. These storms developed in an environment with precipitable water values close to 2 inches. Multiple rounds of showers and storms exacerbated the flash flood threat, with many locations receiving 1-3 inches of rain, much of which fell in only a few hours. CoCoRaHS observers reported 2.76 inches of rain near Little Falls and 3.21 inches of rain near Livingston Township, and a trained spotter reported 3.05 inches in Cedar Grove.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roseland Avenue closed in both directions due to flooding in Caldwell.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Peckman River at Little Falls rose above its minor flood stage of 7.0 feet at 3:25pm EDT, crested at a height of 7.21 feet at 3:30pm EDT, and fell back below flood stage by 3:35pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours as a warm front slowly approached the region from the south. With precipitable water values near 2 inches and relatively slow storm movement, isolated flash flooding was reported in Hudson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One foot of flowing water was observed in a video from Union City. Water was also flowing into a building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along a pre-frontal trough ahead of an approaching cold front. With weak steering flow in place, these storms were able to produce 1-2 inches of rainfall in a short amount of time, leading to isolated reports of flash flooding across portions of Bergen County. The ASOS at Teterboro Airport reported 1.52 inches of rain during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple vehicles were stranded on Broadway under the railroad overpass at the Broadway Fair Lawn train station in Fair Lawn. Water was reported higher than the car windows. Police were conducting water rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along a pre-frontal trough ahead of an approaching cold front. With weak steering flow in place, these storms were able to produce 1-2 inches of rainfall in a short amount of time, leading to isolated reports of flash flooding across portions of Bergen County. The ASOS at Teterboro Airport reported 1.52 inches of rain during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of vehicles stranded due to high water on Route 208 in Fair Lawn including at Berdan Avenue, Morlot Avenue, and near the Maple Avenue Fire Company. Additional flooding was reported on Berdan Avenue with occupied vehicles stranded in high water, including at the intersection with Ruskin Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak wave of low pressure offshore combined with a warm front lifting north through the region resulted in the development of widely scattered showers and thunderstorms west of New York City. While overall storm coverage was low, these storms resulted in isolated reports of flash flooding in parts of urban northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: East Peddie Street was closed due to flooding in Newark.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed along a pre-frontal trough ahead of an approaching cold front. The ASOS at Teterboro Airport reported 1.52 inches of rain during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous vehicles were stranded by high water on River Drive at Columbia Street in Elmwood Park. Additional flooding was also reported along Mola Boulevard.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The basement of a house on Orchard Street between Mola Boulevard and Spruce Street flooded with 3-4 feet of water in Elmwood Park.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Central Avenue in Newark was closed due to flooding near McCarter Highway, south of St. Michael's Medical Center.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported on Raymond Boulevard in Newark with cars stranded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought 1 to 2 inches of rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hutchinson River Road in Harmony Township was under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought 1 to 2 inches of rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Passengers were rescued from two vehicles at the intersection of Flemington-Whitehouse Road and Pleasant Run Road in Readington Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought 1 to 2 inches of rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred along US Route 22 in Bridgewater Township and Bound Brook.  The highway was closed at North Adamsville Road and at Mountain Avenue.  Also, one of the exit ramps from Interstate 287 northbound was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought 1 to 2 inches of rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sections of Changewater Road and Kinnaman Avenue in Washington Township and sections of Rockport Road in Mansfield Township were under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 29.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches fell in a short amount of time, with some locally higher amounts reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding in Riverside and Delran.  Many roads were impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong to severe thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of eastern Pennsylvania, and to parts of northern and central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 29.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches fell in a short amount of time, with some locally higher amounts reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A section of Lows Hollow Road in Lopatcong Township was washed out due to the heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moving along a nearly stationary boundary triggered an area of convection that moved across the region during the evening of May 30th, resulting in isolated flash flooding across northeast New Jersey. Rainfall totals generally ranged from 1-1.5 inches, with the majority of the rain falling in a one to two hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The southbound ramp on NJ 208 was closed due to flooding at Ewing Avenue in Franklin Lakes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a stalled frontal boundary resulted in additional flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey. These storms developed within a moisture-rich environment with slow storm motions, and came after widespread 1-2 inch rainfall totals the day before. Precipitable water values from the Upton, NY sounding ranged from 2.25-2.5 inches during the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: West Broad Street was closed in the vicinity of White Oak Road and Hetfield Avenue in Scotch Plains after a nearby brook overflowed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a stalled frontal boundary resulted in additional flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey. These storms developed within a moisture-rich environment with slow storm motions, and came after widespread 1-2 inch rainfall totals the day before. Precipitable water values from the Upton, NY sounding ranged from 2.25-2.5 inches during the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were multiple reports of people rescued from vehicles in Clark due to high water. In addition, a car was reported stranded by high water on Gibson Boulevard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wave of low pressure riding along a stalled frontal boundary resulted in additional flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey. These storms developed within a moisture-rich environment with slow storm motions, and came after widespread 1-2 inch rainfall totals the day before. Precipitable water values from the Upton, NY sounding ranged from 2.25-2.5 inches during the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cranford Police Department reported numerous water rescues of people who drove into flood waters around town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to much of central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening of June 5.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common with some locations receiving up to 2 to 3 inches in a relatively short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US Route 9 was closed at 10th Street in Lakewood due to flooding.  A few vehicles were trapped in the high water.  A number of side streets in the north end of Lakewood were also closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to much of central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening of June 5.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common with some locations receiving up to 2 to 3 inches in a relatively short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 35 was closed in Eatontown between Broad Street and Wyckoff Road due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 71 was closed in Deal between Brighton Avenue and Roseld Avenue due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 33 was closed near NJ Route 35 in Neptune Township due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred on NJ Route 35 from around H Street in Belmar to south of Belmar Boulevard in Wall Township.  All lanes of the highway were closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to much of central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening of June 5.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common with some locations receiving up to 2 to 3 inches in a relatively short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred on numerous roads in Brick Township.  Several roads were closed and a few vehicles were stranded in the high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to much of central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening of June 5.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common with some locations receiving up to 2 to 3 inches in a relatively short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 71 was closed south of Main Street in Manasquan due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to much of central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening of June 5.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common with some locations receiving up to 2 to 3 inches in a relatively short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 35 was closed between Washington Avenue and NJ Route 88 in Point Pleasant Beach due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms brought heavy rain to much of central New Jersey during the late afternoon and evening of June 5.  Rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common with some locations receiving up to 2 to 3 inches in a relatively short amount of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous road closures in Jackson Township due to flooding.  The list includes High Bridge Road, East Veterans Highway, Butterfly Road, Bennetts Mills Road, New Prospect Road and Faraday Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with the remnants of Hurricane Laura brought locally heavy rain to southwestern New Jersey during the morning and early afternoon of August 29.  Rainfall totals as high as 3 to 5 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along Mantua Creek in Pitman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with the remnants of Hurricane Laura brought locally heavy rain to southwestern New Jersey during the morning and early afternoon of August 29.  Rainfall totals as high as 3 to 5 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Salem River in Woodstown.
