EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along Chestnut Run in Woodstown near the Woodstown High School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to southern New Jersey on the afternoon of August 12.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sections of Princeton Boulevard in Deptford Township were inundated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to southern New Jersey on the afternoon of August 12.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: About 3 feet of water covered parts of the northbound side of the New Jersey Turnpike in Woodbury Heights.  Three cars and a tractor trailer were stranded in the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to central and southern New Jersey on August 13.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 3.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rosedale Road in Princeton was closed due to flooding.  Quaker Road in Princeton was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to southern New Jersey on the afternoon of August 12.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Parts of Glassboro Road and Livingstone Road in Mantua Township were closed due to flooding.  Bridgeton Road was closed at Barry Drive in Mantua Township due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front just south of the region gradually retreated back to the north during the morning hours. This boundary served as a focus for the development of showers and thunderstorms. With weak flow aloft and a moist environment, this resulted in flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Meeker Avenue was closed south of Route 22 in Elizabeth due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front just south of the region gradually retreated back to the north during the morning hours. This boundary served as a focus for the development of showers and thunderstorms. With weak flow aloft and a moist environment, this resulted in flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Raritan Road was closed between Overlook Way and Karen Court along the Ash Brook Golf Course in Scotch Plains due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to New Jersey on the afternoon of July 6.  Rainfall amounts as high as 2 to 4 inches fell in parts of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Union Mill Road in Mount Laurel was closed due to flooding.  Ramblewood Parkway in Mount Laurel was inundated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to New Jersey on the afternoon of July 6.  Rainfall amounts as high as 2 to 4 inches fell in parts of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in Moorestown.  West Central Avenue was impassable.  Marter Avenue was inundated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to New Jersey on the afternoon of July 6.  Rainfall amounts as high as 2 to 4 inches fell in parts of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding occurred in Morristown and in Morris Township.  Flood waters covered the junction of Madison Avenue and Interstate 287.  Franklin Street, Woodland Avenue and Pine Street were closed.  Minor flooding occurred along the Whippany River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to New Jersey on the afternoon of July 6.  Rainfall amounts as high as 2 to 4 inches fell in parts of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood waters covered US Route 202 near Tempe Wick Road in Harding Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to New Jersey on the afternoon of July 6.  Rainfall amounts as high as 2 to 4 inches fell in parts of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles were trapped in flood waters in Ocean City, around the intersection of West Avenue and Third Street, and on Asbury Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southern New Jersey on the afternoon of July 24.  Isolated locations received as much as 2 to 3 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: South Green Street in Tuckerton was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of central New Jersey during the early hours of July 31.  Rainfall amounts as high as 1.5 to 2.5 inches occurred in spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US Route 1 was closed due to flooding near Woodbridge Avenue in Edison Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of central New Jersey during the early hours of July 31.  Rainfall amounts as high as 1.5 to 2.5 inches occurred in spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US Route 9 was closed due to flooding south of NJ Route 440 in Woodbridge Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in a warm and humid environment along and ahead of a stationary front/prefrontal trough during the early afternoon hours of July 11th. With much of northeast New Jersey receiving 2-3 inches of rain the previous day during Tropical Storm Fay, flash flood guidance values were as low as one half inch per hour in some locations, allowing the additional rainfall to result in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: River Road was closed at Hendel Avenue in North Arlington due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a warm frontal passage in the morning, an increasingly hot and humid airmass built across the area during the day, with precipitable water values rising above 2 inches by evening based on the 00Z sounding from Upton, NY. A line of convection moving into the region from the west during the early evening hours resulted in flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey. CoCoRaHS observers reported 1-2 inches of rain across portions of central Union and extreme southern Essex counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in many locations around the town of Cranford. The Fire Department performed water rescues on both High Street and Chestnut Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a warm frontal passage in the morning, an increasingly hot and humid airmass built across the area during the day, with precipitable water values rising above 2 inches by evening based on the 00Z sounding from Upton, NY. A line of convection moving into the region from the west during the early evening hours resulted in flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey. CoCoRaHS observers reported 1-2 inches of rain across portions of central Union and extreme southern Essex counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was stranded in flood waters at the intersection of 9th Street and Madison Street in Hoboken.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Energy rotating around an upper level low over the northeast resulted in the development of scattered showers and thunderstorms. With light steering flow, this resulted in slow moving convection and isolated flash flooding. Rainfall amounts varied significantly over small distances, with a COOP observer in Harrison reporting 2.79 inches, while nearby Newark Airport only received 0.23 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple water rescues were conducted due to flash flooding on Frank E Rodgers Boulevard South south of Bergen Street in Harrison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Energy rotating around an upper level low over the northeast resulted in the development of scattered showers and thunderstorms. With light steering flow, this resulted in slow moving convection and isolated flash flooding. Rainfall amounts varied significantly over small distances, with a COOP observer in Harrison reporting 2.79 inches, while nearby Newark Airport only received 0.23 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All lanes were closed in both directions on NJ21 (McCarter Highway) at Clay Street due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front slowly sank across the area through the day, eventually settling just southwest of the region by evening. Moderate to strong instability ahead of this front aided in the development of showers and thunderstorms across northeast New Jersey during the early evening hours. The ASOS at Newark Airport reported 1.11 inches of rain, while a COOP observer in Harrison reported 1.16 inches. Most of this rain fell in less than an hour, resulting in isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue was conducted at the intersection of Passaic Avenue and Bergen Avenue near the K-Mart in Kearny.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a warm frontal passage in the morning, an increasingly hot and humid airmass built across the area during the day, with precipitable water values rising above 2 inches by evening based on the 00Z sounding from Upton, NY. A line of convection moving into the region from the west during the early evening hours resulted in flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey. CoCoRaHS observers reported 1-2 inches of rain across portions of central Union and extreme southern Essex counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US Route 22 was closed due to flooding in Hillside.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a warm frontal passage in the morning, an increasingly hot and humid airmass built across the area during the day, with precipitable water values rising above 2 inches by evening based on the 00Z sounding from Upton, NY. EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was standing water up to the tops of car tires on West Side Avenue (CR 641) at the intersection with Sip Avenue in Jersey City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front slowly sank south across the area during the morning. With plenty of instability in place, showers and thunderstorms developed along the front and slowly moved south across northeast New Jersey during the morning hours. The 12Z sounding from Upton, NY indicated precipitable water values around 2 inches, which combined with fairly slow storm motions, resulted in isolated flash flooding. While most locations received less than an inch of rain, Newark Airport reported 2.12 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported on West 55th Street in Bayonne with manhole covers lifted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon across northeast New Jersey ahead of an approaching backdoor cold front. With relatively weak flow aloft, these storms moved slowly, resulting in heavy rain across some areas. CoCoRaHS observations indicate a widespread 0.5-2 inches of rain in areas that received storms, with the ASOS at Teterboro Airport reporting 2.89 inches of rain. Much of this rain fell over a 1-2 hour time period, resulting in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple mPING reports of streets flooded and vehicles stranded in Bogota.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A woman drove into deep water near High Street and Benson Avenue in Passaic. After escaping the car, both the woman and the car were carried towards a viaduct opening. The woman traveled through the viaduct for about one mile before it emptied into the Passaic River, where she was able to swim to safety and exit the river, uninjured, along Carneer Avenue in Rutherford. Her car was later located in the viaduct under Brook Avenue near River Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hackensack Fire Department rescued at least 17 people from vehicles stuck in high water, including at the intersection of Green Street and Lodi Street and West Pleasantview Avenue near the entrance to Stop and Shop. The fire department reported that the water was as high as three quarters of the way up car doors.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of central New Jersey on the night of July 23 to 24.  Rainfall amounts as high as 3 to 5 inches occurred in parts of Middlesex County and Monmouth County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A vehicle became trapped in flood waters on College Avenue in New Brunswick.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought heavy rain to parts of central New Jersey on the night of July 23 to 24.  Rainfall amounts as high as 3 to 5 inches occurred in parts of Middlesex County and Monmouth County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue took place on Clark Street along the border between Keyport and Hazlet.  NJ Route 35 was closed at Holmdel Road in Hazlet due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 36 was closed at Valley Drive near the border between Atlantic Highlands and Middletown Township due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Fay tracked northward along the New Jersey coast before passing west of New York City. Several rounds of heavy rain occurred over the New York City metro area as the storm approached. This rain developed in a tropical airmass, with precipitable water values over 2 inches, resulting in numerous reports of flash flooding. Rainfall totals ranged from 1-3 inches across northeast New Jersey, with the ASOS in Caldwell, NJ reporting 2.75 inches, Newark Airport reporting 2.68 inches, and Teterboro Airport reporting. 2.62 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Western portions of Passaic Avenue were closed due to flooding in Wood Ridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical Storm Fay moved northward along the coasts of Delaware and New Jersey on the afternoon and evening of July 10.  The storm produced rainfall totals up to 3 to 6 inches in New Jersey, with the highest totals occurring in the southern part of the state. Some areas also experienced a period of tropical storm force winds, especially near the coast. Overall impacts from wind were limited.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 47 was closed to the south of US Route 322 in Glassboro due to flooding.

The storm produced rainfall totals up to 3 to 6 inches in New Jersey, with the highest totals occurring in the southern part of the state. Some areas also experienced a period of tropical storm force winds, especially near the coast. Overall impacts from wind were limited.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 45 was closed between Point Airy Road and Oldmans Creek in Pilesgrove Township due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An impulse riding along a west to east boundary stalled near the Mason-Dixon line produced severe thunderstorms and heavy rain across sections of South Jersey from late afternoon through the evening hours on August 7th. Strong winds knocked down trees, and torrential downpours on ground already saturated from the remnants of Hurricane Isaias produced flash flooding on many roadways and small streams in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles were trapped in flood waters in Logan Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Swedesboro.  A section of Oliphant's Mill Road in Woolwich Township was washed away by flood waters.  The New Jersey Turnpike was closed in Woolwich Township, south of Interchange 2, due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to New Jersey on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the northern half of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NJ Route 73 in Palmyra was closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Sussex County with numerous road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. Rainfall totals ranged from 5-8+ inches across much of the region, with much of that rain falling in just a few hours. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hackensack River at River Vale exceeded its minor flood stage of 5.5 feet at 11:30pm EDT. The river then continued to rise quickly, surpassing moderate flood stage (6.5 feet) by 12:15am EDT September 2nd and major flood stage (8.0 feet) by 12:30am EDT. The river then crested at a height of 11.05 feet at 4:00am EDT September 2nd. After falling through much of the morning, the river experienced a secondary crest of 10.73 feet at 3:45pm EDT September 2nd. The river did not fall back below flood stage until 11:45am EDT on September 3rd.||The crest of 11.05 feet is the third highest on record at this location behind crests of 12.26 feet in August 2011 and 12.19 feet in April 2007.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. Rainfall totals ranged from 5-8+ inches across much of the region, with much of that rain falling in just a few hours. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 66 year old man and his 46 year old daughter died as a result of flooding after going into the basement of their home on Lincoln Place in Irvington to secure it as the Elizabeth River began to overflow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pascack River at Westwood rose above its minor flood stage of 5.0 feet at 9:45pm EDT. It then continued to rise, surpassing moderate flood stage (6.0 feet) by 1:00am EDT September 2nd and major flood stage (6.5 feet) at 3:15am EDT. The river crested at a height of 7.42 feet at 5:15am EDT September 2nd. The river receded throughout the morning, falling back below flood stage at 11:15am EDT September 2nd.

This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car carrying two Seton Hall University students was overcome by flood waters on Main Avenue near Benson Avenue in Passaic. The body of one of the students, a 21 year old man, was later found in Newark after being swept down the Passaic River.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hackensack River at New Milford rose above its minor flood stage of 6.0 feet at 11:15pm EDT. It then continued to quickly rise to moderate flood stage (8.0 feet) by 1:30am EDT September 2nd. The river ultimately rose above major flood stage (10.0 feet) at 5:00am EDT before cresting at a height of 11.03 feet at 9:15am EDT September 2nd. Thereafter the river gradually receded, falling below flood stage at 7:30am EDT September 3rd.||The crest of 11.03 feet is the third highest on record behind crests of 12.36 feet in April 2007 and 11.45 feet in September 1999.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Third River at Bloomfield rose above its minor flood stage of 6.0 feet at 8:10pm EDT. The river then continued to rise, surpassing moderate flood stage (8.0 feet) at 8:45pm EDT and major flood stage (9.0 feet) at 9:05pm EDT before cresting at a height of 10.14 feet at 11:30pm EDT. After cresting, the river quickly fell back below minor flood stage by 3:45am EDT September 2nd. The crest of 10.14 feet is the highest on record for this location, exceeding the previous record crest of 9.97 feet in September 1999 due to Hurricane Floyd.

Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Prospect Avenue, Old Hook Road, and Broadway were all closed due to flooding and cars with occupants trapped.

The river then gradually fell overnight, eventually receding below minor flood stage again at 6:15am EDT September 2nd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Peckman River at Ozone Avenue in Verona rose above its minor flood stage of 3.5 feet at 8:00pm EDT. It then continued to rise, surpassing moderate flood stage (4.0 feet) at 8:10pm EDT, then major flood stage (5.0 feet) at 8:25pm EDT before cresting at a height of 6.20 feet at 9:20pm EDT. The river then slowly fell over the next few hours, returning to its banks at 12:40am EDT on September 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. Rainfall totals ranged from 5-8+ inches across much of the region, with much of that rain falling in just a few hours. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Saddle River at Upper Saddle River rose above its minor flood stage of 4.5 feet at 9:00pm EDT. It then continued to rise, reaching moderate flood stage (5.0 feet) at 9:15pm EDT before cresting at a height of 5.43 feet at 10:45pm EDT. This crest was the second highest on record, falling just short of the record crest of 5.64 feet in September 1999 associated with Hurricane Floyd. The river then fell back below minor flood stage at 1:45am EDT on September 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pascack River at Park Ridge rose above its minor flood stage of 5.2 feet at 9:15pm EDT. It then continued to rise, surpassing moderate flood stage (6.2 feet) at 9:45pm EDT and major flood stage (7.2 feet) at 11:30pm EDT. The river then crested at a height of 7.44 feet at 12:15am EDT September 2nd. The river then gradually receded overnight, falling back below minor flood stage at 4:30am EDT September 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. Rainfall totals ranged from 5-8+ inches across much of the region, with much of that rain falling in just a few hours. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rahway River near Springfield rose above its minor flood stage of 7.0 feet at 8:30pm EDT. It then continued to rise, surpassing moderate flood stage (8.5 feet) at 9:15pm EDT and major flood stage (10.5 feet) at 11:45pm EDT before cresting at a height of 10.81 feet at 1:15am EDT on September 2nd. The crest of 10.81 feet is the second highest on record, behind only a crest of 10.88 feet in August 2011 associated with Tropical Storm Irene. The river then gradually fell through the overnight hours, eventually fallign back below minor flood stage at 12:45pm EDT on September 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with weakening Hurricane Henri caused significant flash flooding in New Jersey on the morning of August 22.  Most of the flood damage was confined to the central part of the state.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 4.0 to 9.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Musconetcong River overflowed its banks, flooding a section of NJ Route 173 in Greenwich Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing shortwave combined with a surface trough resulted in the development of showers and thunderstorms across northeast New Jersey during the early afternoon hours. These thunderstorms developed in an environment with weak steering flow and high precipitable water values, resulting in several reports of flash flooding. Based on upper air soundings from Upton, NY, precipitable water values increased from around 1.75 inches on the morning of June 8th to just over 2 inches that evening. Rainfall amounts varied widely across the area. The ASOS at the Teterboro Airport reported 1.66 inches of rain, while the Newark Airport ASOS reported 2.19 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An occupied vehicle was stranded in flood waters at the intersection of Pleasantview Avenue and Summit Avenue in Hackensack.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with weakening Hurricane Henri caused significant flash flooding in New Jersey on the morning of August 22.  Most of the flood damage was confined to the central part of the state.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 4.0 to 9.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding resulted in road closures near the Millstone River in Rocky Hill and Montgomery Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with weakening Hurricane Henri caused significant flash flooding in New Jersey on the morning of August 22.  Most of the flood damage was confined to the central part of the state.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 4.0 to 9.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rock Brook overflowed its banks in Montgomery Township, resulting in the closure of Hollow Road to the north of Grandview Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing shortwave combined with a surface trough resulted in the development of showers and thunderstorms across northeast New Jersey during the early afternoon hours. These thunderstorms developed in an environment with weak steering flow and high precipitable water values, resulting in several reports of flash flooding. Based on upper air soundings from Upton, NY, precipitable water values increased from around 1.75 inches on the morning of June 8th to just over 2 inches that evening. Rainfall amounts varied widely across the area. The ASOS at the Teterboro Airport reported 1.66 inches of rain, while the Newark Airport ASOS reported 2.19 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An occupied vehicle was stuck in rapidly rising flood waters in Old Tappan. Multiple fire departments were requested in addition to a marine unit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. Rainfall totals ranged from 5-8+ inches across much of the region, with much of that rain falling in just a few hours. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four people died due to flooding at the Oakwood Plaza apartment complex on Irvington Avenue in Elizabeth. All four people were found in one apartment and included a 74 year old woman, her 71 year old husband, their 38 year old son, and a 33 year old neighbor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. Rainfall totals ranged from 5-8+ inches across much of the region, with much of that rain falling in just a few hours. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Passaic River at Dundee Dam in Clifton rose above its minor flood stage of 4.5 feet at 10:15pm EDT and crested at a height of 4.98 feet at 12:45am EDT September 2nd. The river then fell back below flood stage at 3:45am EDT on September 2nd. Flooding from the Passaic River resulted in three fatalities. A 70 year old man died when his car became stranded in 6 feet of water at the intersection of Passaic Avenue and Lackawana Place in Passaic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure meandering along a stalled frontal boundary produced scattered showers and thunderstorms across the region. With light upper level flow, these storms were generally slow moving, resulting in flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey. Rainfall amounts in the heaviest storms ranged from around 1 to 1.5 inches, including 1.47 inches reported by the Newark Airport ASOS.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to flooding in Jersey City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a stalled frontal boundary. With weak steering flow and precipitable water values approaching 2 inches on the 12Z Upton sounding, this resulted in widespread flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey during the mid to late afternoon hours. Rainfall totals include 2.28 inches recorded by the Newark Airport ASOS and 2.17 inches reported by a COOP observer in Harrison. This rain fell across an area with wet antecedent conditions as a result of several rounds of heavy rainfall during the previous week to week and a half.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: All lanes on NJ 21 were closed due to flooding at Emmet Street in Newark.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple motorists were stranded in significant flash flooding in the Ironbound section and South and East Wards of Newark. Public safety was responding to multiple calls to assist people trapped inside their vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain associated with weakening Hurricane Henri caused significant flash flooding in New Jersey on the morning of August 22.  Most of the flood damage was confined to the central part of the state.  Rainfall amounts were as high as 4.0 to 9.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread and significant flash flooding occurred in Monroe Township.  About 95 houses in the Rossmoor development were impacted by the flood waters, with many of the structures sustaining quite a bit of damage.  Numerous roads in the township were closed and many vehicles were stranded in the flood waters.  A section of NJ Route 33 to the east of Applegarth Road was closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front across the area during the early morning hours gradually sank southward towards evening, providing a focusing mechanism for the development of showers and thunderstorms across northeast New Jersey. These storms developed in a moist environment, with precipitable water values greater than 2 inches, and relatively weak low level flow. In addition, antecedent conditions were quite wet, with 3-5+ inches of rain falling across the area the week before. These conditions combined to result in isolated flash flooding across portions of Passaic County, where a COOP observer in Charlotteburg measured 3.96 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ringwood Avenue in Wanaque was covered with two feet of water and impassable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NJ Transit bus was stuck in flood waters under the overpass on Meeker Avenue between Elizabeth Avenue and Frelinghuysen Avenue in Newark. The 22 people on board the bus were rescued by firefighters on a boat after climbing through the hatch on the roof of the bus.

With weak steering flow and precipitable water values approaching 2 inches on the 12Z Upton sounding, this resulted in widespread flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey during the mid to late afternoon hours. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A predecessor rainfall event resulted in flash flooding across portions of the area as moisture streaming northward ahead of Tropical Storm Elsa encountered a stationary boundary draped across the area. Rainfall amounts ranged 1.5-4 inches, with the ASOS at Teterboro Airport reporting 2.37 inches of rain from this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy flooding was reported in Hackensack with cars stuck on roads and multiple water rescues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southern New Jersey in the late afternoon and early evening of June 8.  Rainfall totals up to 3 inches were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Hammonton.  Water rescues took place at the intersection of North Packard Street and East Pleasant Street, and at the intersection of Central Avenue and Valley Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front brought slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain through the area on the evening of September 23rd into early morning on the 24th. Rainfall amounts generally ranged from 1-3 inches with some locally higher amounts. Most of the rainfall fell in a 1-2 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported Meisel Ave was closed due to flooding between Wabeno Ave and South Springfield Ave in Springfield, NJ.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front brought slow moving thunderstorms with heavy rain through the area on the evening of September 23rd into early morning on the 24th. Rainfall amounts generally ranged from 1-3 inches with some locally higher amounts. Most of the rainfall fell in a 1-2 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported West Inman Ave was closed due to flooding near New Brunswick Ave in Rahway, NJ.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ida overspread northeast New Jersey during the evening of September 1 and continued through the early morning hours of September 2. Rainfall totals ranged from 5-8+ inches across much of the region, with much of that rain falling in just a few hours. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded 8.44 inches of rain, while the ASOS at Teterboro Airport recorded 7.14 inches. A COOP observer in Harrison recorded 8.72 inches of rain. This resulted in widespread flash flooding leading to numerous road closures and water rescues in addition to extensive river flooding. Eight people died as a result of the flash flooding and one person remains missing.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 83 year old man was found on Chestnut Street in Union Township near Overlook Hospital. He is believed to have drowned after his car got stuck and he walked out into 3-4 feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to New Jersey on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the northern half of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in the southern half of Somerset County with numerous road closures.  There were two flood related fatalities in southern Somerset County, both in Hillsborough Township.  There were approximately 1200 water rescues in the entire county.  Many buildings and homes were either damaged or destroyed by the flood waters.  Most waterways in the county overflowed their banks, including the Raritan River, the Millstone River, Green Brook, Stony Brook and Middle Brook.

The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the northern half of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Morris County with numerous road closures.  Many waterways in the county overflowed their banks, including the Passaic River, the Whippany River, the Pompton River and the Pequannock River.

There were three flood related fatalities in northern Somerset County, all in Bridgewater Township.  There were approximately 1200 water rescues in the entire county.  Many buildings and homes were either damaged or destroyed by the flood waters.  Most waterways in the county overflowed their banks, including the Raritan River, the Millstone River, Green Brook, Stony Brook and Middle Brook.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several water rescues took place in Keyport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to New Jersey on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the northern half of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Hunterdon County with numerous road closures.  There were over 300 water rescues in the county.  A total of six flood related fatalities were reported, one in Milford, one in East Amwell Township, and four in Raritan Township.  Many buildings and homes were damaged by the flood waters.  Most waterways in the county overflowed their banks, including the South Branch of the Raritan River, the Neshanic River and Spruce Run.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Warren County with many road closures.  Several waterways overflowed their banks, including the Musconetcong River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to New Jersey on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the northern half of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Middlesex County with numerous road closures and over 500 water rescues.  A total of three flood related fatalities were reported in the county, one in South Plainfield, one in Piscataway Township, and one in Woodbridge Township.  There was significant damage to structures and vehicles, mainly in the northern part of the county.  Many waterways overflowed their banks, including the Lawrence Brook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated showers and thunderstorms developed late in the day along a weak frontal boundary. One of these storms was able to produce a quick 0.5-1 inch of rain, resulting in isolated flash flooding in Hudson County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rescues were conducted near Tonnelle Avenue in North Bergen due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a stalled frontal boundary. With weak steering flow and precipitable water values approaching 2 inches on the 12Z Upton sounding, this resulted in widespread flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey during the mid to late afternoon hours. Rainfall totals include 2.28 inches recorded by the Newark Airport ASOS and 2.17 inches reported by a COOP observer in Harrison. This rain fell across an area with wet antecedent conditions as a result of several rounds of heavy rainfall during the previous week to week and a half.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flooding was reported in the Ironbound section of Newark, with water above car tires and waist deep in many spots near the intersection of Ferry Street and Wilson Avenue.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall from Tropical Storm Henri resulted in widespread flash flooding across portions of northeast New Jersey With a tropical airmass in place (precipitable water values greater than 2 inches), rainfall totals generally ranged from 2-4 inches, with this rain coming in addition to the 1-3 inches that fell during the predecessor rainfall event the night before. This resulted in widespread rainfall amounts of 3-7 inches in many locations over a 24-36 hour period. The ASOS at Newark Airport recorded a total of 4.67 inches across the two days, while the COOP observer in Harrison reported a two day total of 8.02 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Molly Ann Brook at North Haledon rose above minor flood stage (6.0 feet) at 5:50pm EDT August 22, quickly crested at a height of 6.99 feet at 6:25pm EDT, and fell back below flood stage at 7:20pm EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifting north and an approaching shortwave trough combined to produce scattered showers and thunderstorms across northeast New Jersey during the late afternoon and early evening hours. These storms resulted in isolated reports of flash flooding in Essex, Passaic, and Bergen Counties. CoCoRaHS observations show a localized area of 1-3 inches of rain along the boarder of Passaic and Essex Counties, with reports of 1.69 inches 0.5 miles WNW of Little Falls Township, 1.95 inches 1.3 miles NE of West Caldwell Township, and 2.55 inches 0.7 miles north of Montclair.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A car was stuck in flood waters under the railroad trestle on Delafield Avenue near Court Avenue in Lyndhurst with a water rescue occurring.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A backdoor cold front approaching the area sparked a few widely scattered thunderstorms. These storms developed in a moisture-rich environment, with precipitable water values from the 8am Upton, NY sounding around 2 inches. With weak upper level flow resulting in slow storm motions and wet antecedent conditions as a result of rainfall associated with Tropical Storm Henri less than a week earlier, this resulted in isolated flash flooding in northeast New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Danforth Avenue in the Greenville section of Jersey City was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system developing over the area brought rounds of thunderstorms over the area during the evening on October 25th and into the 26th. Total rainfall amounts of 2-4 were observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to New Jersey on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the northern half of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flash flooding occurred in Mercer County with numerous road closures and nearly 100 water rescues.  There were two flood related fatalities in the county, both in Hopewell Township.  Many waterways overflowed their banks including the Assunpink Creek, Stony Brook and the Delaware River (with a highly unusual quick response to the runoff).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Post Tropical Cyclone Ida brought heavy rain to New Jersey on September 1.  Rainfall totals were as high as 5 to 10 inches.  The heavy rain caused significant flash flooding, mainly in the northern half of the state.  It resulted in widespread property damage.  There were several fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US Route 30 in Camden was closed at Federal Street due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in New Jersey on the afternoon of September 23.  Rainfall totals were as high as 2 to 3 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed in the vicinity of a stalled frontal boundary. With weak steering flow and precipitable water values approaching 2 inches on the 12Z Upton sounding, this resulted in widespread flash flooding across portions of urban northeast New Jersey during the mid to late afternoon hours. Rainfall totals include 2.28 inches recorded by the Newark Airport ASOS and 2.17 inches reported by a COOP observer in Harrison. This rain fell across an area with wet antecedent conditions as a result of several rounds of heavy rainfall during the previous week to week and a half.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported in Port Newark with all lanes closed on Corbin Street northbound at Tyler Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of southern New Jersey on the afternoon of July 21.  There were rainfall totals up to 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread roadway flooding occurred in Lumberton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms brought locally heavy rain to parts of New Jersey on the afternoon and evening of July 17.  Rainfall totals were as high as 4 to 6 inches in Hunterdon County and Somerset County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was widespread roadway flooding in Raritan Township and in Flemington.  Sections of US Route 202 southbound were closed.  Three vehicles were stranded in the flood waters along Old York Road near the Neshanic River.  Significant flooding was indicated by the river gauge at Reaville on the Neshanic River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of thunderstorms moved along a warm front of an approaching low pressure system on May 27th and into the 28th. These thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall over Northeast New Jersey resulting in several rounds of localized flash flooding. Several rounds of rainfall each with 0.75 to 1 inch of rain in an hour cause brief localized flash flooding. Total rainfall amounts in Northeast NJ were 1.5 to 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rescue at the intersection of Johnston Avenue and Passaic Avenue.

Training thunderstorms produced a widespread 1 to 3 inches of rainfall with localized spots up to 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms that developed along a warm front on August 22nd produced heavy rainfall and localized flash flooding in New Jersey. The thunderstorms developed in an environment with PWATs increasing from 1.6 to 1.9 inches and CAPE values around 2000 J/kg. The storms quickly dropped 1 to 2 inches of rainfall in less than 90 minutes over portions of urban Northeast New Jersey that resulted in localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Person trapped in a car and water rescue is underway in Scotch Plains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A batch of moderate rainfall with embedded heavy thunderstorms moved through the area on September 13th bringing flash flooding to the New York City metro area. These thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front with a low pressure developing overhead in an extremely moisture environment that had precipitable water values of 1.8-2. These thunderstorms dropped between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall in a several hour period resulting in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding on McClellan Street with traffic blocked.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front moving through sparked a line of thunderstorms which trained over Northeast New Jersey late on September 25th and into the 26th. They developed only in a marginally moist environment with precipitable water values near 1.2-1.4 inches. These thunderstorms dropped 1-3 inches of rain over the area in a several hour period resulting in localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on US 22 Eastbound West of Fairway Drive. All lanes closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary over the area provided a focus for convection to develop in the afternoon on July 4th. CAPE values of greater than 2000 J/kg and PWAT values near 1.8-2 allowed thunderstorms that developed along the stationary front to slowly drift southward while producing torrential rainfall rates of 1-2 per hour. Some areas saw 1-3 of rain over a 1 to 3 hour period which produced localized flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on US 22 Westbound between Glenside Ave and Terrill Road. All lanes closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Already saturated grounds from 1-3 inches of rain the previous days set the stage for a localized flash flooding event to unfold on April 30th when an additional 2-3 inches of rainfall fell over a period of several hours. A mesoscale moderate to locally heavy rain band with rainfall rates of 0.5 to 1 per hour set up over the NYC metro area during the afternoon of April 30th when a low pressure system was developing to the south of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Marin Blvd and Grove St. closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in central New Jersey on the afternoon and evening of September 11.  Rainfall totals were as high as 1 to 2 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US Route 9 became impassable due to flooding around Bordentown Avenue in Sayreville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall was focused in an area near the New York City Metropolitan area on September 29th, 2023. A bulk of the widespread flash flooding was in New York but was close enough to result in localized flash flooding in New Jersey. Rainfall totals in New Jersey were 1-2.5 inches, mainly near the NYC metro.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: De Baun Avenue is flooded with at least a foot of flowing water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front provided the focus for the development of slow moving heavy thunderstorms on the afternoon of September 8th 2023. The thunderstorms developed in an unstable environment with CAPE values of 3000-4000 J/kg and PWATs near 1.7 - 1.8 inches. These thunderstorms produced rainfall rates of 1-2 inches per hour with a total accumulation of 1-3 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple streets closed due to flooding in Paramus and in the vicinity.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front provided the focus for the development of slow moving heavy thunderstorms on the afternoon of September 8th 2023. The thunderstorms developed in an unstable environment with CAPE values of 3000-4000 J/kg and PWATs near 1.7 - 1.8 inches. These thunderstorms produced rainfall rates of 1-2 inches per hour with a total accumulation of 1-3 inches of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple local road flooded with up to 2 feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front ahead of a developing coastal low pressure system positions itself over the area late on December 17th and into December 18th. As the low pressure intensified and approached, significant amounts of moisture focused along the warm front ahead of the coastal low resulting in widespread areas of heavy rainfall that occurred over a 12-18 hour period. PWATs were 1.5-1.7 inches which were near record values. A widespread 2-5 inches of rain fell over the area. This resulted in many areas of flash flooding as well as significant rises in rivers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 7 closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal system over the area on August 18th produced heavy thunderstorms that were fairly slow moving over northeast New Jersey. A cold front moving in from the west late in the afternoon produced heavy thunderstorms with an environmental MUCAPE of 2000-3000 J/kg and PWAT values of 1.7-1.8 inches. These slow moving thunderstorms produce rainfall rates of 1-3 inches per hour over New Jersey with total rainfall amounts of 2-4 inches. This resulted in widespread flash flooding during the evening of August 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Green Brook at Seeley Mills reach flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy thunderstorms developed over the area on the afternoon of August 6th. A slow moving frontal system stalled out over the area. PWATs of 2-2.2 inches and a sharp gradient of MUCAPE peaking out over the area near 2500 J/kg allowed for the development of strong thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall with rates upwards of 1.5-2.5 inches per hour. Total rainfall was 1-3 inches with localized amount up to 4-5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding on US 46 Eastbound at CR 628 and Piaget Ave with all lanes closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front over the area on August 3rd was the focus for the development of several rounds of heavy thunderstorms across the area. CAPE values of near 2000 J/kg with PWATs of of around 2 inches resulted in thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall with rates upwards of 2 per hour. Rainfall totals were 1-3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Werimus Road is closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy thunderstorms developed over the area on the afternoon of August 6th. A slow moving frontal system stalled out over the area. PWATs of 2-2.2 inches and a sharp gradient of MUCAPE peaking out over the area near 2500 J/kg allowed for the development of strong thunderstorms producing torrential rainfall with rates upwards of 1.5-2.5 inches per hour. Total rainfall was 1-3 inches with localized amount up to 4-5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Video showing Grand Avenue closed with more than a foot of water and a stalled van in the flood waters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching cold front and trough produced thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening on July 17th that resulted in localized flash flooding in northern New Jersey. MUCAPE values of 1000-2000 J/kg and PWATs of 2-2.2 inches allowed the thunderstorms to produce heavy rainfall rates of 1-2 per hour. The thunderstorms produced rainfall totals of 1 to 2.5 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood rescues occurring on West Pleasant Street and Green Street in Hackensack.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms ahead of a cold front produced widespread showers and thunderstorms. A few storms produced damaging wind gusts, knocking down trees and power lines across portions of New Jersey.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads in Blairstown were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A predecessor rainfall event set up ahead of the remnants of Tropical Storm Debby. A hot and humid airmass was in place, resulting in a very moist and unstable airmass. A few showers and thunderstorms developed, producing damaging wind gusts across portions of New Jersey, downing trees and wires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: New Jersey state road 31 closed in Pennington in both directions due to flooding.
